title: Nord Stage 2 Program Collection
post_content: Due to several requests, I created a first version of a User Program Collection for the Nord Stage 2.This way, you don't need to browse thru all the posts but have at least the name and link to all patches uploaded so far in one patch.nord_stage_2_program_collection.phpNote that this is a raw version, and in particular, the samples necessary (be it from the Nord Sample Library or user created ones) that are needed for a particular patch still need to be loaded in your NS2 in order to make the patch work. So checking the corresponding topic is still needed in many cases.Also checkout the Nord Sample Library for Sample-Only programs!I know there is a lot to be done, but this is a first try. Also, many MP3 samples are probably missing, so if you find one, please PM or post the Patch number and the corresponding MP3 file download ID (when you hoover over a link to the MP3 file, you see something like download/file.php?id=1489 and I only need the ID to match it with the corresponding Patch.Cheers,Johannes

title: RE: Nord Stage 2 Program Collection
post_content: Well done, thanks!Suggest in what about linking the samples in the sample list and/or reference them in the NS Patch Collection list (would require and additional "Samples used" column, maybe)

title: RE: Nord Stage 2 Program Collection
post_content: Indeed, good point maxpiano. But will be a hassle and take lots of time, time I don't have for the moment, so if someone could do the job, I happily send you the Excel File and one just needs to add one (probably two for both panels!) columns with Sample Names (if Nord Library) or IDs (if user uploaded).

title: RE: Korg M1 Piano

title: RE: Korg M1 Piano
post_content: this immediately became the standard piano in reggae when it came out ~1990, compressed all to hell and sounds like garbage when playing solo, but it's the one that brings out the sound that most every reggae artist seems to want to hear, and does cut through the mix really well.Note that Nord includes an M1 piano sample in their sample libraries, and sample #76 in the sample collection in this forum is also M1 piano, but nice to have another one to add to the collection!  Too bad there's no mp3 audition file so that folks can hear it before downloading from web to computer hard drive and then from computer hard drive to instrument...bless, pablo

title: Dance To The Music
post_content: just thought i'd share these 3 small programs for Sly's Dance to the Music, I use with my band.part 1) for the opening through the first choruspart 2) after drum solo, 'add some bottom' I help the bass, with that F1 punch. Then... 'hear my organ' and switch topart 3) for the horn walk up (GBD-Eb, I add then EGA to the stretch), and after 'only squares...play the horn riff and control pedal to the organ for the clarinet riff.  Then horns and organ for the final chorus.will try to add mp3 at later date.this is my first time sharing.

title: RE: Uptown Funk - Bruno Mars Featuring
post_content: Here you go guys.  Not tried it on my nord yet as it's in a van.  Samples are as follows;D1, F1, G1 - 'Doos as per intro'C2 - 'Ahhhhh' (after the horn break)C#2 - 'Hot Damn'D2 - High D 'ooooo"I've also re-uploaded a patch which I got from another user here 'Prince_OBXa'I use this for the oberheim type noise, think Prince 1999 Intro.  This particular patch uses the two slots which screws you up, but I found that using slot B (I think!!) works fine by itself for the Uptown Funk tune.  I think I added like a rotary effect, or something, LFO, whatever, can't remember.  Use the other slot for the samples above.  I use a Fantom G for the horn sounds which sounds awesome.  Horn sounds I've heard for the nord are rank in general.For the sound some of you were talking about where it just rises in pitch, I use the iPad app Morphwiz with a sound I made up.Hope this pull y'all out of a hole.

title: RE: Uptown Funk - Bruno Mars Featuring
post_content: Thanks to all for the above patches - as an alternative to Morphwiz, I'm using the Oberheim patch copied to the next sequential patch with Voice Mode Mono and Glide set to 9.6 on both slots.Once changed to the patch, am just hitting an octave D3 and D4 with the D3 slightly before the D4. This will create a glide of one octave ascending.Hope that's of use!Cheers,Rob.

title: RE: Uptown Funk - Bruno Mars Featuring
post_content: So I downloaded morphwiz onto my iPad and super easy to use and program.  Seeing that the synth in this song is a chromatic synth sweep, I see why this iPad app makes sense.  My only challenge was getting the iPad to go into my sound system.So I went with the iRig 2 as a midi option.  However, I just bought a little mixer where I can stereo input my two Nord keyboards, and there's a 3rd input for my iPad.  Then I have one output  for the PA, jam hub, or wherever I'm plugging it into.My only thing now is to program the right sound in the Morphwiz but I think with trial and error I'll be able to come up with something close.  If anyone wants to share how they programmed the morphwhiz sounds for this, of course that'd save me time. But I'm in much better shape since my last post.MrSitcom - give Morphwhiz a try, pretty cool and I can see a lot of other ways I can use it.

title: RE: Uptown Funk - Bruno Mars Featuring
post_content: I did some sampling and try to combine most of it in 1 voice/slot. Resampled the brass section to get two octaves played with one note and included that in the sample. You can play the intro with just right hand. I repeated the clap on the B3 key, so you can combine it with the brass (last part of mp3). borrowed the synth form 1999. Enjoy!uptowndemo.mp3

title: RE: Uptown Funk - Bruno Mars Featuring
post_content: Hi,Well I've compiled all that was posted on this topic.I put my 3 NS2P patches + NSMP for the samples.I put also available an mp3 file that compiles all the samples to be able to put on any sampler.And an MP3 which I play my patches on top of the original song.For NSMP (present in the patch 1 and 2):A2: Cry for the introB2: clap for the entire songC3: Hoo CD3: Hoo DF3: Hoo FG3: G HooA3: sample Hoo G3 + F3 + Cymbal reversedB3: WhistleC4: Clap Reverse 1D4: Clap Reverse 2Play C4 and D4 togetherE4: Siren1F4: Siren 2Play E4 and F4 at the same timePatch 1 for the intro to the hornsPatch 2 for all versesPatch 3 for the chorus (split synth + Copper)good musicUptown Funk Samples.mp3

post_content: I play "Uptown Funk" in my current band, but I ignored the sounds of the original and came up with my own style on my Stage 2. This is a Juno 106 strings sample, the LP12 filter enabled and frequency cutoff controlled by the wheel, small amount of envelope modulation with attack on about 10 o'clock, and playing riffs and chords with one hand while twanging the pitch stick with the other. The rest of the band all said "wow, that sounds great" so I kept it like that.

title: RE: Nena - Leuchtturm -
post_content: Do you have Logic Pro X? Drag the file into a Logic arrange window, and hold the option key (alt key) while dragging the endpoint of the audio region. This will time-compress it (Stauchen) without changing the pitch. Then control-click on the Region to bounce it in place. This will create a new audio file that you can search out in the Finder and just drag into the Nord Sample Editor to create your .nsmp.Time-stretching is a feature of most modern DAW software. If you don’t have one, you can download Audacity for free and use that.

title: RE: Nena - Leuchtturm -
post_content: Leuchtturm Sample.mp3I use "Leuchtturm1" for the intro:Sample "Leuchtturm"C2: basic sound with sonarE2: handclapsG2: basic sound without sonarC3: plopin the middle of the keyboard are the bass Strings (original Nr 184 "SilkStrings__NLA1 mono 2.0")upper part of the keyboard is piano  EP 6 Sparkle TopI switch to Leuchtturm2 after the Intro for the rest of the songsame sample as in Leuchtturm1upper part for the synth solos: Nr. 188 "A1 The Prophet__NLA1 stereo 2.0"Hope i don´t breake the forum rules but should be ok, because the samples from original recording does not exceed one bar in length.Have fun!

title: RE: Nena - Leuchtturm -
post_content: Wow, thank you !

title: RE: Nena - Leuchtturm -
post_content: Just to note: the “one bar length” thing for samples is, and always has been, an urban myth.There is absolutely no legal minimum or maximum length for "permissible" sampling. You could argue "fair use", though.And of course: “Wo kein Kläger..."

title: RE: [REQ] No Doubt Hella Good
post_content: I spent some time with this tonight and created a program I'll attach for NS3. It uses three splits. I don't know how effective this will be in live performance because the parts are syncopated in a way that makes it difficult to play accurately.At any rate, the lowest split is the low rhythmic part that provides the song's pulse. This part is heard throughout except in the short little vocal and drum breaks.The middle split is the big riff synth for the chorus.The top split is for the bleepy blippy melody that occurs throughout. It's made with a clav and Farfisa. It's not perfect, but it's close.The lowest split would sound better if sequenced, but because of the breaks, this would be basically "playing to tracks." I plan to play the low pulse in the verses and the heavy riff in the chorus, skipping the low split part in the chorus. I'll see if that makes it feel like the groove drops out because the rhythm of that low part against the basic rock drum pattern isHella Good NoDbt.ns3f(592 Bytes) Downloaded 150 times

title: RE: [REQ] No Doubt Hella Good
post_content: I performed at a job last night where we played this song and had a chance to run it during soundcheck. The soundman said the low synth pulse keyboard part was getting lost in the mix, so I boosted hi-mid frequencies with the EQ to help give it more bite and added a chorus for more stereo width. He said that helped that sound cut through better. I wasn't able to play the high part, not sure how I'm going to pull that off...

title: Programs for Songs from "THE DOORS"
post_content: Dear all,I have been looking to create or find some good patches to play DOORS songs. But I have not found many and hence would like to start a topic about it, and also share some of my works.A simple Vox setting or Rhodes is not so difficult, but some of the Upright/Toy Pianos, Strings, "toy" organs (for the lack of a better word) (e.g., Love her madly for the last two) are quite intriguing and I could not manage to find good sounds, so would like to hear form other players if they play these  songs.Songs I have been looking for:1. Alabama Song (Whiskey Bar)2. Back Door Man3. Break On Through4. Five To One5. Hello, I Love You6. Indian Summer7. L.A. Woman8. Light My Fire9. Love Her Madly10. Love Me Two Times11. Moonlight Drive12. Peace Frog13. People Are Strange14. Riders On The Storm15. Roadhouse Blues16. Soul Kitchen17. Strange Days18. Take It As It Comes19. The Crystal Ship20. The End21. The Wasp (Texas Radio And The Big Beat)22. Touch Me23. Unknown Soldier24. Waiting For The Sun25. When The Music's Over26. Wild Child27. Wishful SinfulWill upoad my patches later today.Thanks!ChE

title: RE: Programs for Songs from "THE DOORS"
post_content: HI, When you'll post the doors patches? I play a lot of these songs with my band and I'm waiting for you to make my job easy, I'm a new Nord User...Thanks

title: RE: Programs for Songs from "THE DOORS"
post_content: Hi,I have many of those programs for DOORS songs I play with a DOORS tribute band. They are mainly based on my own hearing, but also lots of reasearch for drawbar settings etc.. There is certainly room for improvement, but it might serve you as a starting point.Also, I created some samples to include the sound effects used in Unknown Soldier, L.A. Woman, Riders on the storm, and The End.In general, I use a Swell pedal (set to SWELL or Volume as you prefer) and set the MOD Wheel to morph between different sounds (e.g., Love her madly) or increase volume a bit for Solos).The samples are assigned to the highest white keys (d7, e7, f7), you might need to transpose the synth section if you have a NS76 or NS88 (I have a NS73 Compact).Cheers!JohannesUPDATE: corrected some programs, added the RMI sample for "Hello I love you", and set up a split for "Alabama Song" plus some minor fixes.UPDATE: Overhauled the whole setUPDATE: Find a great website with lots of video tutorials including drawbar settings for the Vox for THE DOORS classics here:http://shelf3d.com/Search/Uploaded%20by ... ianduran17

title: RE: Programs for Songs from "THE DOORS"
post_content: Thanks a lot!! Really helpful, will see if I upload my own programs, but that already helps a lot!Gracias!!ChE

title: RE: Programs for Songs from "THE DOORS"
post_content: Glad it is of some use!Actually still working on the programs. I made some changes, notable tweaking the samples a bit, and setting up a split setup for "Alabama Song", and tried all the Harpsicords to find the best match which seems to be (at least for me) the "French Harpsi 1E L8 L4 U8", so be sure to have it loaded in the Piano Section.Also took me some time to figure out the sound of "Hello I love you" which is quite different from the Vox/Rhodes kind of sounds. Finally I found that Ray used a RMI Electric Piano on that song (probably a 300A) (http://graphikdesigns.free.fr/rmi-electra-piano.html)After trying hard for quite a while without success, I had another look at the Nord Sample Library and voilá, they have a sample set of its succesor the RMI 368X, which works greatWill upload the final version later this week.UPDATE: I uploaded the updated and fixed zip archive to my previous post.

title: RE: Programs for Songs from "THE DOORS"
post_content: LewTheKeysGuy wrote:Hi, Sorry about this, These don't work on a stage 3 sadly. Worst of it is that Nord Sound Manager 7.4.6 refuses to convert. Could anyone help please?As discussed a few times on this forum, all different Nord models (except EX versions of the same model) are not compatible at Program level due to their sound engine(s) differences, there is no way to automatically convert them (and Nord Sound Manager is just a librarian).Only chance is having someone who owns both NS2 and NS3 and willing to convert them manually.

title: RE: Sound für Helene Fischer - Atemlos
post_content: I  tried to recreate "Atemlos2HFischer.ns2p" and "Atemlos HFischer.ns2p" with Nord® Stage Program File Viewer (Online tool to review Nord Stage 2/2EX/3 program file settings) for my stage 3.

title: RE: Sound für Helene Fischer - Atemlos
post_content: Looks like a misunderstanding: There is no way to convert a NS2 program into a NS3 program. The features of the two instruments differ too much (mainly the synth), so no software of the world can convert that. You can only see the settings from one program and try to _recreate_ that sound on another instrument starting with similar settings. It's a fully manual process.That's why the software is only called "viewer": You can view the settings in the program without having the instrument at your side.

title: RE: Sound für Helene Fischer - Atemlos
post_content: Hi,that's what I thought and why I was asking - as FZiegler said the Program File Viewer does not create a Stage 3 program from a Stage 2 program, but it's a very helpful tool to visualize all settings of a Stage 2 program which makes it easier to create a as-close-as-possible version on for example the Stage 3

title: RE: Sound für Helene Fischer - Atemlos
post_content:
Hi,As I mentioned, I tried to transfer the sounds from “Atemlos” for Stage 2 to stage 3 by use of Nord® Stage Program File Viewer. I accurate brought in the specifications. But is wasn't the same sound. Far from it. Where did it went wrong? In the end I asked WannitBBBad to help me. His first remark was that the information sheet for the Stage 2 program indicated "Skip Samp Atk" for both synths what don’t occurred on the Stage 3 sheet. I must try adding the Fast Sample Attack (hold shift/exit button down while selecting the Attack option) to both synths. What I did, but it still didn't look like the original. Then I started all over again. And I create “Atemlos HFischer.ns3f”(Patch with Arpeggiator)and “Atemlos2HFischer.ns3f”(Patch without Arpeggiator).WannitBBBad’s reponse was as follows:I took your program "Atemlos2HFischer.ns3f" and modified it to give you a little more flexibility on the sound:a.	The Pad level is morphed to the Mod Wheel and backs down a little with the Control Pedal still like you programmed it.b.	The String level is morphed to the Control Pedal along with a DX7 piano and OSC2 to add a tone an octave higher than the strings when turned upc.	The String FREQ is morphed to the Control Pedal so it starts out muted and gets brighter with the Control Pedal.You may need to re-link the Samples after loading the program. I have the program attached with "W" at the end of the name so you know which one I sent.I downloaded the modified program (and indeed relinked the samples). It gives an extra dimension to the sound. Great. I also modified “Atemlos HFischer”(Arp) to “Atemlos HFisch1W”(no Arp).I had also previously asked in the public forum about the sound from bar 24. It wasn’t created for the Stage 2.WannitBBBad came up with the program “HF Atemlos 2 W.ns3f” for the second part of the Helene Fischer song at 00:45 in the video. Lacking better percussive sounds, I downloaded a small steel drum sample to use along with strings and use the control pedal to increase the FREQ and a couple levels. The program  is made so at the end the right hand is playing octaves across the split.It sounds great!Here are the results.Atemlos(2)HFischer.mp3Atemlos(2)HFisch1W.mp3HF Atemlos W 2.mp3Atemlos HFischer.ns3fPatch with Arpeggiator(592 Bytes) Downloaded 285 timesAtemlos2HFischer.ns3fPatch without Arpeggiator(592 Bytes) Downloaded 263 timesAtemlos HFisch1W.ns3fPatch with Arpeggiator(592 Bytes) Downloaded 258 timesAtemlos2HFisch1W.ns3fPatch without Arpeggiator(592 Bytes) Downloaded 268 timesHF Atemlos 2 W.ns3fSound after 00:45 s(592 Bytes) Downloaded 283 timesOrchStrings Marc HiVib_KH 3.0.nsmp3(4.29 MiB) Downloaded 277 timesPAD 4 - Synth brass(151).nsmp3[/attachment
[attachment=0]707_steeldrum.nsmpGyauhm

title: RE: A-HA - Take on me
post_content: Regarding Darren's excellent programs, I was having similar issues as Swannieboy today and found a solution.Apparently “sample 126” is missing from the first of the three programs (Take_On_Me_1.ns2p). But I think it's the same as sample 52 (DXPiano_ste_PH) in the Nord Stage 2’s factory settings.  So just set the synth in Slot A to sample 52 and the program works fine.I also noticed that after installation, these three programs weren’t displayed in Nord Sound Manager v6.18.  That is, not until I removed the first underline in each program’s name (using the NS2’s Store As… button.) That made all the underlines in the name disappear, and after saving the program’s new name, the program displays correctly in the Sound Manager’s program list.  Weird, huh?By the way, my Nord Stage 2 is using OS v1.64, in case that has something to do with it.

title: Major Tom-Peter Schilling
post_content: Hi to everyone-I have been busy learning to program my new Access Virus, so I haven't been on the forum much lately.  I did do some extensive synth programming recently for an 80s band, so I thought I would share some of the patches with you. The first is for Major Tom (what a fun song to play for a keyboardist!)The first patch loads with slot A enabled.  This works for the opening synth riff.  It also can be used for the D-G stab during the verses.  Slot B is the synth pad during the chorus.The second patch is the take-off effect.  I would program it next door to the first one, as it has to be a quick switch.  Hit A-E in the second octave, hold it down and then the same two notes three octaves above. It will last exactly as long as the second part of the chorus and will end right before the synth riff comes in again.Enjoy!-dj

post_content: Hello,I made some Patches for Enjoy the Silence by Depeche ModeThere are a lot of Synths in the recording so I made six different Patches for the Intro, Vers, Chorus and the Interlude and two Presets for the Outro.If you play the "Radio Edit" you don't need the Patch for the Intro and the Outro is a Fade Out so maybe you don't need the second Patch für Outro 2.Because of the limitation of two Slots it's not possible to play all Synths that you can hear on the recording at once. I always took the once that were most important for me in the different parts of the Song.I haven't made any .mp3s of the different Sounds but you can hear all sounds that I'm playing in the YouTube Video below.If you want please feel free to ask me for the sheet music of the keyboard part exactly the way I am playing it in the Video and live with my Band. I've also marked the changes between the Patches in the Sheet Music.Email me at:keyboardparts@gmail.comand I can send you the sheet music as .pdf or Sibelius file.I hope you like it. Leave a like or a comment on YouTube.Enjoy Sil Intro.ns2p(565 Bytes) Downloaded 1952 timesEnjoy Sil Verse.ns2p(565 Bytes) Downloaded 1646 timesEnjoy Sil Choru2.ns2p(565 Bytes) Downloaded 1605 timesEnjoy Sil Interl.ns2p(565 Bytes) Downloaded 1589 timesEnjoy Sil Outro1.ns2p(565 Bytes) Downloaded 1592 timesEnjoy Sil Outro2.ns2p(565 Bytes) Downloaded 1600 times

title: RE: Enjoy the Silence - Depeche Mode
post_content: rpossemo wrote:So, no way of loading all this into a NS3? Kind of new to Nord.nord-user-faq.phpCan I transfer my Programs across different Nord models?When it comes to Programs (patches) each Nord model is compatible only with itself, regardless the number of keys (for models which have multipleversions). So, for example: a transfer between a Nord Electro5D61 and Nord electro 5 HP 73 is possible, but a transfer between a Nord Electro5D61 and Nord electro 4D61 is not possible.The only exception to this rule are the "EX" versions of the Nord Stage (Classic/EX, 2/2EX), which anyway require special care due to the different amount of sample memory (higher on EX models)So that will be "no", not possible.

title: Stage 2 – For those new to programming...20+ programs
post_content: I posted something similar to this for the Stage 3 and thought it might be helpful to post one for the Stage 2.  For those of you new to programming, an excellent source of information on synthesizers and the keys to programming is the collection of SOS magazine old articles called Synth Secrets athttps://www.soundonsound.com/techniques ... d-on-sound(thanks for the link Mr_-G-)One of the best ways to learn the ins and outs of the Stage 2 is to download programs and go through the synth and morph settings to figure out what makes them tick. Prior to selling my Stage 2 EX, I posted quite a few Stage 2 programs that may not be something you’d use playing out, but could learn from if you don’t know how you would recreate it yourself. Below are samples of some of those programs and links to original posts. I use the "morph" function quite a bit with the Control Pedal, it's well worth getting one.  I hope you find these helpful. Take care.My Stage 2 "Utility" Program– I used this a lot but it is also a good starting point for other programs. Slot A has piano, strings, and a Hammond with "drawbars" morphed to the Mod Wheel. Slot B has a left-hand bass, and right-hand piano and strings.nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 15752.htmlUtility Program W.mp3Hammond with Leslie/Tremolo on Wheel, DX7, Bass– Somewhat similar to my “utility” program but this one focused on the Hammond with Leslie and tremolo effect on Mod Wheel. The tremolo makes for a more "pulsing" Leslie sound similar to a closer microphone setup. The MP3 includes holding a chord and turning the tremolo on and off.nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... tml#p48819HammondWheelDX W.mp310 Classic Rock and Other Programs (really 11)nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... t7676.htmlDX7 Rhodes W.mp3DX7 Rhodes2 W.mp3James Taylor W.mp3Hotel Calif W.mp3Hotel Calif2 W.mp3LedZep AcGuitarW.mp3Waiting4Girl W.mp3ELP FromBgning W.mp3Abacab 5thWeelmW.mp3Surf ImYurCptn W.mp3From the second page of the post atnord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... ml#p100028StevieHiRGroundW - Stevie Wonder - Higher Ground.mp3Ambrosia – “Biggest Part of Me”– Piano, Hammond, and Synth Brass are progressively used in the song.nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 15716.htmlAmbrosiaBigPartW - Biggest Part of Me.mp3Bruce Springsteen – “Glory Days”nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 15718.htmlGlory Days     W - Bruce Springsteen - Glory Days 13 4.mp3Bruce Springsteen – “Dancing In The Dark”- new version posted at:nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... ml#p104167Pedal Steel Patches– Two pedal steel patches for the Stage 2nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 15753.htmlTwoLaneHighway_W.mp3James Taylor – “Every Day”– Left-hand pad and right-hand Rhodes with soft analog brassnord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 15720.htmlJTEveryday MK1 W - James Taylor - Every Day.mp3Jaw Harp - Juice Harp– Synth-created Jaw Harp with control pedal on wahnord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... tml#p49346Jaw Harp W.mp3The Rolling Stones – “Miss You”– Wurlitzer Piano and Blues Harp with FREQ on control pedal to move into LFO range to emulate the hand over the harmonica providing the tremolo.nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 15719.htmlStones MissYou W 92.mp3The Who – “Baba O’Riley”– Samples providednord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 54-10.htmlMP3 - Who Baba ORiley.mp3LINK TO STAGE 3 POST WITH OVER 100 PROGRAMS -->nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.html

title: RE: Stage 2 – For those new to programming...20+ programs
post_content: I hope everyone is doing well.  It's been quite a while since I've updated this post as I'm no longer a Stage 2 owner, however below are some songs using NSMP samples I recently put together that could easily be covered on the Stage 2. Links to the samples and Stage 3 programs are provided where the file viewer by Florence can be used to put together a similar Stage 2 program if needed. Take care.Styx - "Too Much Time On My Hands" -A simple one but covering most of the bases, I put together a NSMP sample and Stage 3 program for "Too Much Time On My Hands" by Styx covering the Synth and sound effects. Two links are below, one to the thread on the Stage 3 program with a couple older programs and my latest one used for the MP3, and the other to the Samples Forum to make it available to other Nord users as well. Fun song to do from the 80s.The sample and more info can be found atLINK-->nord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/styx ... 20988.htmlThe Stage 3 program can be found atLINK-->nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... ml#p142510Styx 2MuchTime W Program with Sample.mp3Van Halen - "Jump"- I put together this sample using a Stage 3 program covering the synth and strings. My work is posted atLINK -->nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 57-30.htmlincluding the NSMP files. This is an example of the NSMP sample covering the synth and strings at the end.MP3 example of Van Halen Jump W Small NSMP.mp3Dua Lipa - "Levitating"- Forum memberLukedwas looking for a program for "Levitating", so I took a shot at simulating the intro chords at first and then decided to simply sample them. Stage 3 programs and samples can be found atLINK -->-->nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... ml#p140667DL Levitating - one-finger chords.mp3Van Halen - "When It's Love"- Recently I worked on a Stage 3 program for "When It's Love" by Van Halen to capture the synth along with the "click" at the beginning of notes played (posted atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... ml#p142083).  Here's a sample of that program adding Reverb and a White Grand only.  All notes to the right of the middle C split include the click that has a slap-back echo within the sampled note. The click level can be adjusted up or down somewhat with the EQ if needed, however if you want the level down a little, first try backing off the initial attack slightly by setting the AMP ENV Attack at 1 to 2 if you have that on your Nord. The NSMP sample can be found atLINK -->nord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/van- ... 20968.htmlVH WhenItsLove W NSMP Example.mp3Whitney Houston - "How Will I Know"- A request fromCosmic1for this song took me down a path of setting up three Stage 3 programs for the song and then deciding to create an all-encompassing sample.  In the attached MP3, I'm playing along with the intro percussion loop and all sounds you hear with the exception of the DX7, and later B3 and Piano reinforcing key change for the solo/ending, are within the single sample created.Programs with and without Samples-->nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... ml#p142073Sample, keyboard mapping, and other info -->nord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/my-f ... ml#p142072WH HowWillKnow W Program with Sample.mp3Toto - "Africa"- Here's my sample covering the beginning of "Africa" and mono synth used in the 2nd verse combining sounds from two of my Stage 3 programs posted atLINK -->post129601.html?hilit=toto#p129601The sample has the analog brass on the left, kalimba center, and mono synth on the right. On the MP3 I play along with a drum track and combine the sample with the Marimba in the piano section, and then add an example of the mono synth at the end; no effects added except reverb. The NSMP sample is posted atLINK -->nord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/toto ... ml#p143864Toto - Africa S1 Sample Demo.mp3

title: RE: Stage 2 – For those new to programming...20+ programs
post_content: Don Henley "Boys of Summer"NSMP Sample.  Here's an example of taking multiple Stage 3 programs and combining them into a single NSMP sample for use with other Nord keyboards.  To save sample memory space, I also created a smaller NSMP file where you can add your own analog brass sound with your other synth panel. For both samples, a few notes were included to allow transposing down a half step. The link to the NSMP samples and the keyboard mapping is provided below. Take care.NSMP Samples:LINK-->nord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/nsmp ... 21153.htmlDH_BoysOfSummer_W_Sample_Demo.mp3

title: RE: Stage 2 – For those new to programming...20+ programs
post_content: Cher "Believe" NSMP sample.  Similar to the last, here's another example of taking multiple Stage 3 programs and combining them into a single NSMP sample for use with other Nord keyboards including the Stage  2 and having another synth panel to work with. In this sample each note played for the middle synth was sampled as the phase shifter with stereo pan timing needed to be identical - using interpolation would have resulted in individual notes panning slowing or quicker than others. I hope you get some use out of this. Take careLINK-->nord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/cher ... 21261.htmlCher Believe NSMP Example.mp3

title: RE: Stage 2 – For those new to programming...20+ programs
post_content: Cameo "Word Up"NSMP Sample. With quite a few synth sounds in this song, I took a different approach for this one and did all my programming with the purpose of making the NSMP sample.  The "whistle" sound was created using a sine wave in Mono mode with slight vibrato, but the glide to quickly go between the two notes had to be manually changed to be slower for the last glide down when I recorded it.  The sample editor provided the fade out. As there was vibrato on two of the synths, I sampled each key played in the song so that the vibrato rate would be the same for each note.  Interpolation is great for a lot of sounds but it changes the rate of attack, decay, and other time-related aspects of a sound. The DX7 is the "DX7IIC FineTines_BR mono" sample (available on the Nord site) with overdrive applied. The horns at the end are a combination of "Brass Section Pop 1_BR" and "Brass Ensemble 2_KG". On the MP3 I play along with the sampled drum intro, but the looped drum track is also included for reference in the NSMP sample. No effects are used for the MP3 except reverb. I played around with the levels to get them fairly close for performance but the Amp Velocity on the Stage 2 can be used to provide more flexibility in the levels if needed. The sample and sound mapping across the keyboard can be found at the link below. Take care.NSMP Sample -->nord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/came ... 21294.htmlCameo - Word Up W NSMP Example.mp3

title: Katy Perry - Firework
post_content: Hai Guys.I have to play this (with my band) at a gig next week, so I thought I'd share the patches I made with you guys.Firework.mp3I recorded a quick mp3 to try and demonstrate how the 3 patches should be used. I did it all in realtime in one take. Unfortunately the audio cuts on the NS2 when changing patches, but I feel it can be hidden when playing with a band.  Also sorry for the mistakes in the recording.The sample I use for strings is "StringOrchestra". It is nr.10 if you haven't changed it from factory settings.Patches explanation:I use Firework1 Slot A for the vers and Slot B for the bridge.Then I switch to Firework2 for the chorus where I play chords in the left hand and the string "melodi" in the rightLast I use Firework3 Slot A for the "other part"(sorry don't know what such parts are called in english) late in the song. Then I switch to Slot B for the bridge before switching back to Firework2 for the last chorus.Hope someone might actually want/need this[youtube][/youtube]Have fun guys and tell me if you have any quesions.Best regardsCbas

So no (real) need for the NS2 yet my friendBut I can understand if you want one of these bad boys soon. It really is an awesome keyboard. Hope it works out for youHave funCbas

title: RE: Katy Perry - Firework
post_content: Nice patches - thank you very much.  I have made some slight changes to these that you may be interested in:1. Gated the synth in the first patch using a tremolo with tempo set against MST CLK (as I now use a midi clock foot switch).2. Added a ping pong delay to the synth in the first patch again tempo set by MST CLK3. Added a heavily overdriven organ with same tremolo gate and a phaser for the chorus patch (left hand) as I notice the same synth sound for the verse is used in the chorus, but both synth slots are already in use for the split strings.4. Replaced Firework 3 with a copy of Firework 1 - only difference being that I opened the tremolo up a lot more to make it a bit more 'paddy'.  This way I can get a smooth patch change out of the mid 8 into the bridge before the final chorus5. Added compression - with that much going on, don't want to overwhelm the mix.My patches an sample mp3 attached.  I have only learned this song this evening so not quite as fluent as I would like, but you get the idea!Firework.mp3Firework1.ns2pFirework1 - Patch for Intro, verse and bridge(547 Bytes) Downloaded 2214 timesFirework2.ns2pFirework2 - Patch for Chorus(547 Bytes) Downloaded 2096 timesFirework3.ns2pFirework3 - Patch for Mid8 and final bridge(547 Bytes) Downloaded 2135 timesGoing through the sample mp3, here's how i play it:1. Get a count from the drummer and tap it in (I will be tapping 2 and 4 throughout the song to keep in with the stick man)2. Hold the chords for the main synth sound and let the tremelo do the work3. Just before the strings part kicks in, I hold the synth on that C#Maj7add9 using the sustain and flick over to slot B to make the transition as smooth as possible4. Play the staccato string part 4 times5. Now this bit is tricky!  Just at the end of the 4th time round with the staccato, we are heading into the bridge (or pre-chorus if you like).  Here, I combine Slots A and B then use the sostenuto pedal on the 1st beat of every bar so that I can keep the synth going with the first chord without sustaining all the incidental notes in between.  Trick is to keep the staccato going but trust the sostenuto pedal to keep the tremelo synth line going.6. Heading into the Chorus itself, I switch to Firework2 and use the sustain pedal for the left hand strings/distorted organ sound.  The right hand continues the staccato line7. For the Mid8 section, I'm using Firework3 and holding the chords.  Nothing special here, again I use the sustain pedal on the last chord (Eb from memory) and change to slot B for the bridge8. Finally back to Firework2 to see out the track with.

title: RE: Katy Perry - Firework
post_content: Hi Darren,Great performing!There is a way to have 3 synths in a program to avoid cutting the sound when you change them. You just have to save the synth patches in consecutive order and then select them in the program while playing, rather than select the next program. It isn't always possible to achieve a good result, but mostly yes.Ramon

title: RE: Katy Perry - Firework
post_content: Hello everyone. I don't own Nord but I need patches to perform this song. I own KORG PA 800 and midi with logic pro and I can't seem to find any patches to play this song. Any help? Thanks

title: RE: Katy Perry - Firework
post_content: The best I can do is break down each of the sounds so you may be able to recreate a similar program on your setup.Intro / VerseThis is a Sync'd square wave with unison enabled (set to 2 oscillators) and a HP filter cut off at around 200Hz.  To get the tremolo effect on the Nord, I passed it through the on board effects section as this allows me to bind the tremolo tempo to the Master Clock (handy in a live situation as the tempo can be tapped / re-tapped).  Some synths provide LFO on the Amp section so you can get a similar effect there but whether you can easily adjust the tempo on the fly is a different matterBridge (1st verse)This is just a hard attack strings sound.  Layering a good strong pizzicato might be nice here here - I couldn't find one that really cut through the mix in the way I wanted so I opted for the String Orchestra from the Mellotron library.  There's bound to be a handful of reasonable String samples on the Korg that would fit the bill.Bridge (2nd + 3rd versesWhere in the first bridge we just have strings, the later bridges have everything going on.  With the Nord, I combine the string sound for the 1st bridge with the Intro / Verse sounds.  Notice on the video I roll the wheel up?  This is actually bound to to the tremolo effect so that it becomes less aggressive.ChorusIn the right hand is a strong hard attacking string sound - I used the same as I used for the bridge.In the left hand I have a layer of the strings used in the right (but at a lower volume).  Here I hit a limitation with the Nord, Ideally, I would have taken the square wave sound from the Intro and layered it over the strings in the left hand.  However I needed the strings in the left hand to be quieter than the right otherwise the chords would overwhelm the staccato in the right hand.  So, I 'approximated' a similar sound by using the organ section:- Farfisa - Off, Off, On, On, On, Off, Off, Off, Off, leslie sim on slightly overdriven- This is fed through the Tremelo effect (bound to the master clock) and then through a small amp simulator to lose excessive bottom end and make it sound a bit more 'synth'.With your Korg, I expect you will have the flexibility to just use the square wave from the Intro, but I thought I'd explain this as others may find it interesting.That's it.  Sorry I can't give you a file that sorts this all out for you, maybe you could just buy a NS2?  FWIW, I also now own a Korg Kronos and the one thing that limits it is the inability to easily share programs in the same way as we can here.  Korg really need to sort this out.Anyway, good luck and please let me know how you get on.  If you have any questions on the above (like if I missed something), please let me know!

title: RE: Disco inferno
post_content: Hi there mrsmac!The programs I use are attached.For Somebody else's Guy, it's a keyboard split with a synth sound at the top for the recurring motif and a Grand Piano on the left for filling and the beginning piano/vocal only part.For Disco Inferno - again a keyboard split, right hand side is a large brass sound for the brass chords and stabs, left hand side a Mk V Rhodes for filling and giving a wash.For the Disco Inferno program, you'll also need some of the samples that are already available on this forum:Full_Brass - availablehere.Sax Sus_Dbl_F - available on the Nord sitehere.Hope that helps!Cheers,Rob.

title: ABBA - Medley Setup
post_content: Hi there,does anybody build a "ABBA - Medley" Setup? So it misses the seccond Piano/Harpsichord and maybe, somebody has build a better one? I´m not lucky with mine :-/Regards,Thomas

title: RE: ABBA - Medley Setup
post_content: I've done an ABBA medley on every single gig for 3 years now but sadly we chose a different set of 3 songs...= SOS, Gimme, and Does Your Mother KnowMy setup is a- Piano + Strings for SOS- Marc strings (2 octaves layered) on Gimme. Volume and filter freq mapped to Control Pedal.- Straight up basic B3 on the last one. Leslie, some drive, and drawbar settings by ear and feel.EDIT: so not really what you asked for, but as you can see, I'm not even trying to copy the original. That's both because I don't want to, and because I can't. In my experience people don't care if for example the synth lead is there. As long as it's dancable and recognisable.

post_content: Ahah, I also have an Abba medley but with the following order : Gimme gimme/Money money/Voulez-vousStarted to program using the flute found on the forum. Will post the bundles of the songs once I got it all together if interested.Fred

title: Lady Marmalade - Moulin Rouge
post_content: Hello,this is my first post in this amazing forum which I am using since many years and I was able to benefit a lot from it.I made a preset for “Lady Marmalade” in the film version from Moulin Rouge performed by Christina Aguilera, Lil'Kim, Mya and Pink.It's not exactly the synth on the recording.The original synth has more phaser effect but I realized when I turn on the phaser in the effect section the Basssynth loses it's power and in a live context together with a band it doesn't come out anymore. Even if I put the amount of the phaser on very low. So I left it out.I also made a Youtube Video playing the whole song and I have written the sheet music of the keyboard part exactly the way I am playing it in the Video and live with my Band. When you're interested in the sheet music send me an Email tokeyboardparts@gmail.comand I can send you the sheet music as .pdf or Sibelius file.I hope you like it. Leave a like or a comment on youtube.Lady Marmalade - Moulin Rouge.mp3Lady Marmalade.ns2p(565 Bytes) Downloaded 1905 times

title: These Eyes by the Guess Who
post_content: still trying to find the best sound for "These Eyes".Any suggestions?Thanks,Dale

title: RE: These Eyes by the Guess Who
post_content: Hi Dale,at first sight resp. listening it’s a rather dry Wurlitzer, so no or almost no reverb. Maybe a little bit of short Flanger or Chorus.I guess who’s trying with this as a base gets already close to it.Cheers and good luck.

title: RE: These Eyes by the Guess Who
post_content: Tasten-Bert is correct.  The studio version of the song is clearly a Wurlitzer.  [Edit):  Tasten-Bert and ("Clearly") I were both wrong.... It's a Hohner Pianet.....The OP's question made me think again about how much time I spend trying to find the closest possible match to a keyboard part's sound on a recording.  Consider this; Burton Cummings, who wrote, sang and played the "keyboard" on These Eyes, wasn't all that interested in reproducing the sound of that studio's Wurlitzer when when performed the song after it was released.  Here's evidence of that:  He's playing a grand piano on the TV show Midnight Special.I suspect that - in most cases - my time is better spent getting the left hand part, the phrasing and the feel of songs correct than getting the patches exactly like some recording of the sound. There are exceptions.  I'm still trying to find a way to reproduce the sound of the intro on Won't Get Fooled Again.  Even The Who used the pre-recorded track of that when playing live (and so did my bands!).

title: RE: These Eyes by the Guess Who
post_content: It sounds like a Pianet to me.

Here's evidence of that:  He's playing a grand piano on the TV show Midnight Special.I suspect that - in most cases - my time is better spent getting the left hand part, the phrasing and the feel of songs correct than getting the patches exactly like some recording of the sound. post_content: changearound wrote:It sounds like a Pianet to me.After listening carefully to These Eyes and to Pianet recordings (early Chicago tour videos are one example), as well as Nords Pianet sample, I think changearound is right.  It's a Hohner Pianet.https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... r-pianet-n.

title: RE: These Eyes by the Guess Who
post_content: Hmm, I must admit that I never had a Pianet under my fingers.Having thought a bit about these two sound sources - Pianet or Wurlitzer - and the way a nord can handle a piano sample with various dynamic levels and touch feel in the piano section or a sample of the Sound Library with one dynamic level only in the Synth/Sample section I think I‘d always choose the piano file if the sounds are so close together as they are here. Inspiration grows while playing.Cheers, for the next two weeks from sunny Italy

title: RE: These Eyes by the Guess Who
post_content: These Eyes Pianet.mp3I've never played a real Pianet either but it's my understanding that they are extremely limited when it comes to touch sensitivity so the synth section can do a reasonable job at emulating it with a single layer sample.Here's my attempt at recreating the sound. I'm using the Pianet PH sample with some tremolo and the JC amp sim. The Filter is  at 88 Hz with  Freq Mod 2 Velocity 10 and Mod Env Velocity and Amp Env Velocity both on.

title: RE: These Eyes by the Guess Who
post_content: Nice sound!

title: RE: These Eyes by the Guess Who
post_content: Main issue is no sustain pedal with a Hohner Pianet.Lent mine to Burton Cummings on four gigs I opened for Guess Who BEFORE These Eyes in 1968.Wurli reeds close enough along with a synth to produce a 'pluck',mine was NEW and IN TUNE in 1968,and why Burton 'borrowed' mine.His was trashed.In 1977 he returned the favor and lent me the White Steinway...when opening for him again.....yes he remembered my Pianet.

title: what is the best grand piano for live
post_content: Dear All,I've been using the Nordstage 2 88 for several years. I'm still not really happy with the piano sound I use. I may be using the wrong piano sound or setting. (Also because I recently bought a digital piano grand from Yamaha. (That really sounds better). When I just listen to a youtube video again, I'm almost sure I'm doing something wrong.Which grand piano do you recommend. Really for live use. Two good piano sounds on stage is more than enough for me. With fewer different pianos, I can also load a heavier sample, I suppose.While I'm at it, what's the most useful electric piano on the stage?thanks for your opinion.gr. henk

title: RE: what is the best grand piano for live
post_content: If you are not happy with the piano sound you get, amplification issues come to my mind. Which monitors do you have? And do you use stereo amplification?

title: RE: what is the best grand piano for live
post_content: For live playing, I use the Silver grand almost exclusively--dj

title: RE: what is the best grand piano for live
post_content: I would say it depends on what and in which kind of setup you use it.Do you play classics, rock, pop, jazz or something else?Do you play on your own, in a typical rock band, pop band, jazz trio or a brass orchestra?Which amplification do you use?I for instance play in a band together with a drummer, a guitar player, a bass player and 2 singers, we play kind of classic 70s/80s rock and pop music. I use 3 grand pianos, the white, the silver and the bright since they cut well through the mix. It might be completely different if the band setup and style of music changes

title: RE: what is the best grand piano for live
post_content: Thank you for responding and thinking along. I appreciate that.I play in both a duo (along with a guitarist) and a 5-man band. In both cases a lot of pop music, from the 60s to the present.Coincidentally, I just saw this video (and thought... that's how it should sound.I also think I work with a good PA set. Everything from QSC. I also work with IEM.Even if I listen to the sound directly through the PA, then I am not satisfied. That's why I think that your advice that you use on the stage will help me a lot.Thank you for all the advice.You are dealing with limitation of the internal memory. So very heavy samples is not possible. Which version do you use then?gr. HenkNetherlands

title: RE: what is the best grand piano for live
post_content: Do you go stereo or mono into your PA and also into your IEM mix? The Nord pianos do not sound well in mono ..

title: RE: what is the best grand piano for live
post_content: Yes that's right, I use stereo. My IEMs also give a stereo sound.

title: RE: what is the best grand piano for live
post_content: Do you mean you use two channels and they are both fully panned in opposite directions? (You probably knew this, but many people here have raised similar comments but not noticed that important detail in the mixer).

title: RE: what is the best grand piano for live
post_content: Sorry for my somewhat late response. Not online for a few days.I use a digital mixer. The QSC 16. It has two stereo inputs. So I go twice mono out (Nord) to 1 x stereo in. Will there be the problem. Doesn't seem to me...By the way, I want to change my sound library, which also means that I want to use other piano sounds.Thanks for this support.Nice this forum.GreetingHenk

title: RE: what is the best grand piano for live
post_content: hspeulman wrote:Sorry for my somewhat late response. Not online for a few days.I use a digital mixer. The QSC 16. It has two stereo inputs. So I go twice mono out (Nord) to 1 x stereo in. Will there be the problem. Doesn't seem to me...By the way, I want to change my sound library, which also means that I want to use other piano sounds.Thanks for this support.Nice this forum.GreetingHenkI apologize for the rise of the old topic. But perhaps my experience will be useful to someoneI have the same situation - I am also not too pleased with the piano sounds. I get out of the situation in this way:I reduce the volume in the piano section (so that there is no overload of the output signal), and then I add the necessary frequencies to the filters section. (More often, these are high frequencies). Plus configuration of dynamics

title: RE: Billy Idol - Rebel Yell
post_content: The intro part is actually played on electric guitar. If you can find a clean "Stratocaster" type sound that should work. Add some chorus and compression.

title: RE: Billy Idol - Rebel Yell
post_content: I find the NS2 clav with phaser or flanger, maybe even a bit of wah and a bit of amp sim, drive and eq, gives a very attractive guitar-esque sound.Whilst it may not sound as close to a guitar as a sample (you can get pretty close with a little tweaking), it is far more responsive musical to play and sounds more like a 'real' instrument.After all, the clav used plucked strings as the sound source did it not?

title: RE: Billy Idol - Rebel Yell
post_content: visionmusic wrote:After all, the clav used plucked strings as the sound source did it not?More like "tapped" strings, like tapping on a guitar. And it still uses them -- plenty of them still out there!

title: RE: Billy Idol - Rebel Yell
post_content: Hi folks, sorry it took a few weeks. I don't have my NS2 hooked up to the computer very often and I was off at NAMM for the better part of a week. I'm attaching my Rebel Yell sounds as bundles so you can get the full content. I don't have a good way to create MP3s of these, but I'll try to explain how they are set up.Rebel Yell 1 is for the intro sound (which repeats in the middle of the song just before the guitar solo). I have a CP80 and D-50 percussive sample layered together and I think it sounds pretty close to the original recording.Rebel Yell 2 has an organ sound on the lower part of the keyboard that I use as for chords during the verse and chorus (switch to Preset II for chorus to get a fuller organ sound). The upper part of the split has a layered synth sound that I use for the high part during the verse and also for the synth lead towards the end of the song, while droning organ with my left hand. Please note that I use a Vent for my organ sounds, so I have the output for organ routed to Output 3. If you're using the internal sim, you'll just need to edit this parameter.I just figured out that the bundle sound for Rebel Yell 1 is too large to upload, so I'll try to figure out a different way to post it (perhaps as just the sound vs. a bundle).

title: RE: Billy Idol - Rebel Yell
post_content: I've attached just the sound file for Rebel Yell 1, not sure how this would work without the bundle, but I have the CP80Amped piano and in the sample section I have loaded Perc Release in Slot A and SynthPad2 in Slot B.

title: RE: Billy Idol - Rebel Yell
post_content: I now also did some work on my own samples which I would like to share with you. The programs only use Nord Library samples, all of them are available from Nord website. So the Sound Manager will tell you which samples you need, just download them.The MP3 is a full length version of the song's synth track using the programs. So you will get an idea how to use them. Control pedal and aftertouch are used by some parts, pitch stick as well.Intro contains just the arpeggios at the beginning and in the middle.Main contains the synth pad LH and the lead synth sample RH.Bridge is that modded rect synth  with AT in RH and the crescendo synth LH (controlled with pedal)I hope you enjoy!P.S.: Sorry for my bad playing, didn't had much time to do a better demo, so the quick and dirty one will have to do. Should hopefully be ok with youRebel Yell

title: Rolling Stones - Miss You with Blues Harp
post_content: I just purchased a Nord Stage 3, so taking a little time to post some more programs from my Stage 2 EX that you might have fun with. Note that most of my programs use the control pedal morph even if only to bring instruments in and out of a mix. You may need some additional samples for some of the programs.The memory locations in my Nord Stage 2 EX for the samples used in the program are:Slot A - 142 - "Harmonica__DV mono 2.0"Slot B - 115 - "Steel Guitar_Finger_DV mono 2.0"I believe these samples are preloaded in the locations given for a Stage 2 EX.  If you have to load them, it doesn't matter which sample memory locations you store the new samples in your Nord Stage 2, just make sure that after you load a program, that you point the Slot A and/or Slot B Synth to the correct sample in your system. For example, if you load "Harmonica__DV mono 2.0" into your sample location 140 (142 in mine), then you just need to point Slot A to 140 rather than 142. I'll revise this post as needed based on questions, so feel free to comment.Take care.Stones MissYou W 92.mp3Stones MissYou W.ns2pProgram - Stones - Miss You by WannitBBBad(547 Bytes) Downloaded 441 timesLINK "Stage 2 - For Those New To Programming" -->nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 16863.html

title: RE: Carly Rae Jepsen - Call Me Maybe
post_content: Hey Darren! quick question regarding the call me maybe string samples for the chorus.  I'm planning on doing this live in a different key live (male vox) - what do you reckon is the best way to re-pitch these samples?  Nord Sample Editor perhaps? I have actually recorded this song in the new key but we cheated and pitch shifted it in cubase!

title: RE: Carly Rae Jepsen - Call Me Maybe
post_content: Depends how far down you're going.  The Nord will play samples at a slower rate which is fine if you're going down a tone or so but beyond that, it starts to sound weird.I guess for best results, you could sample as is back into Cubase, do a pitch shift there and then bring the new samples back in to the Nord Sample editor.  Not tried it myself, but in theory should give you the best result.

title: RE: Carly Rae Jepsen - Call Me Maybe
post_content: Yep makes sense to me, since we've already done most of the work.  We have shifted it quite a way - into G I think. The samples of course started to sound a bit thin so doubled it with a decent string program from the NS2 and it works a treat

title: Hella Good - No Doubt
post_content: Hella Good - Program for Nord Stage 2Hi! Back in 2016, for a gig, I decided to program the song Hella Good (No Doubt) for Nord Stage 2.The program is generally speaking to play the song as loops on Voice Mode Mono with the Left Hand -mostly 4/4 bars- and have freedom to add the details with the RH.On a technical note, the bar samples allow the band to avoid using a Backing Track, having total freedom to interact with the audience and continue the song regardless if there any perfomance mistakes. To blend each note, the program uses voice mode mono, decay at 10, almost no release, attack at 0, HP at 0, an extra quarter note on each bar sample, and a subtle analog delay close to quarter note triplets.The Nord program does NOT use samples from the song. It was fully done by imitating the sounds using synths from the Nord Library, and altering those synths with the Nord Stage 2 and DAW.The program is at 115BPM.The .zip file contains the WAV Samples, Nord Projects, Nord Samples and the Nord Program.Here is a video performing the song, to demonstrate the program functionality:Cheers!HellaGood.mp3

title: RE: Bee Gees - Stayin' Alive
post_content: Just saw this, but what got my attention was the overal quality of the video! and the things in the "intro" how did you record it/made the awesome intro transition?

title: RE: Bee Gees - Stayin' Alive
post_content: My HD camera (actually an iPhone 5) is mounted on a boom mic stand using a 'gripper' mic clip over my head. I record a stereo feed from the board into my DAW (Logic Pro).I don't do any production in Logic, just normalise and bounce the audio out to AIFF.The footage is imported into iMovie where I start by syncing the audio stream to the footage then mute the audio picked up by the phone (so you don't hear button presses or keybed noise).Finally add the titles and a fade to black transition. With iMovie you can just drag a transition or title you like over the video stream and in the immortal words of Steve Jobs: 'Boom'.This takes about 10 minutes or so to get a project ready to export.Only thing left is to render and export the complete movie. iMovie can export direct to YouTube, however I tend to do a session at a time where I record 4-5 of these so I always have a few in the bank in case I'm too busy to get something out on time. I'm putting one video out per week.The only challenge I had was syncing the audio up. My less than scientific approach was simply to click a count with one hand before starting to play. This click is picked up on the camera's audio stream and it gives me a better idea of where to place the audio stream in iMovie.

title: FM Synth deciphered
post_content: This is a continuation of a conversation I was having with MonsterJazzLicks, HandSolo and Mr_G_ a few days ago...I've started a new thread here because it's more relevant in this section - i'll be posting some new programs here shortlyThe conversation was about the FM Synth on the Nord Stage 2. I know that the Synth section is identical on the Stage 2 EX, and although there are some differences on the Stage and Stage EX, it may still be relevant. Hey, even may have some relevance to NLA1 owners...If you don't know what FM is, think of any popular song from 1983 to the end of the eighties across practically all genres and you will remember those iconic synth sounds... that's FM.It's baffling at first - especially because a lot of the existing tutorials focus on subtractive ('analog') synthesis and then add a throwaway comment about FM as if it's either of no interest, or so easy you can figure it out... so i'm willing to share some FM how-to tutorials if there is any appetite for this? I'm no guru - for sure there's a bunch of old synth-heads on this forum who know this stuff inside-out and backwards, but may not have as much time to spare as meIf you aren't using the FM synth on your Stage then you have an amazing synth engine which is wastedIf you own/previously owned a DX7 (or one of its kin), then you probably took one look at the FM capabilties on the Stage and murmured "Meh." before moving on. You did it an injustice...If you are a synth head and know this stuff inside out and backwards, you can correct my errors!The best thing about Synth sounds (as opposed to samples) is that they are more capable of expressive control, take up practically no space in memory, and allow you the freedom to create completely new sounds on the fly without relying on hooking up to your laptop. Also they can't be used by Electro owners, so you can feel more comfortable in why you splurged out extra $$$ for a Stage and not an Electro.Anyway, let me know and I will post some how-to stuff. If there is a lack of interest, I will put my energies to other uses

title: RE: FM Synth deciphered
post_content: Hey. A few people PM'd me, and I see the odd post appear in reply to this thread. I feel ashamed not to have delivered on my promises, but life gets in the wayI figured I should respond here...I haven't touched that guide in about 4 years. I got some great feedback, but I also found it took a lot more work than I originally anticipated, doing screenshots of waveforms, creating recordings, and working through step-by-step recipes.Then I figured I should probably generalise it, something that doesn't just apply to the NS2, otherwise it's quite a bit of effort for a limited audience (even if it is an audience with great taste in gearSo part of it turned into a general synth book - which is still a work in progress - kind of a back-burner project.I also spent too much time being distracted by forums, and not enough time actually 'doing' - after a few troll experiences i stepped away.TBH my workflow has changed a bit - I was impressed by the NS2 for the first year - "new gear syndrome", but ultimately I found the synth section pretty limited and stopped using it in favour of other hardware. The NS2 makes a great controller, and that's what I mainly use it as - I only use the piano section and Hammond sim as actual sound sources. It's still a great and powerful synth section, considering it only has a few controls.So now i've been poked once again by a PM, so I will at least re-read the guide - but I know better than make any promisesAnyway - who even uses the NS2 these days? now there are newer, shinier models available... I recall that @Marlowes sent his into the attic long agoso anyway - keep up the music making - you are (mostly) a good crowd on here!

title: RE: Synth Stormbringer Deep Purple
post_content: Milord wrote:Thank you for the excellent patch AlexNagel! And thanks to frantzkb for the explanation!AlexNagel, when you have time, can you tell me the steps to get to that sound? What parameters have changed and how ... so that even I can understand how to work on certain sounds! Thank you very much!Milord, I'm glad you like the sound. I don't have the time to go in details, it's basically a detuned (root + fifth, 7 hafltones above) saw sound if I remember it correctly, don't have my NS2 here right now.  Add a lowpass filter with resonance controlled by envelope, and some velocity sensitivity for the filter and the envelope. Doing this you can set all the knobs to their actaul position and learn how they change the sound.By the way, the synth part of the original track is almost panned hard to one channel (the right one?), so by only listening to this one channel of the stereo recording you can hear the original sound nearly alone without guitars, drums etc. -  this really helps finding the right sound.Alex

title: How to create new program based on sample in sample library?
post_content: Hi all,Simply stated, I'm trying to figure out how to create a program on my stage 2 ex based on a sample that is in my sample library, but not used by any existing programs. I can see the sample I want to use in Nord sound manager... but can't figure out how to either link it to a program using sound manager... or how to access the sample on the instrument and create a new (and playable) program on the instrument. Any links to video tutorials and/or sections of the user manual that address this would be kindly appreciated.Thanks!!!Mark

title: RE: How to create new program based on sample in sample library?
post_content: MyKeysToMusic must have videos that answers your question.Assuming the sample is named "MarkSample" and is in sample slot #55.Create an empty program, say in B:03:2.Turn the Synth Engine On and turn the volume knob to the max (master volume up too).Turn the selection knob to Sample (selection 6 down right) and with the other knob, select 55.Play !Fred

title: RE: How to create new program based on sample in sample library?
post_content: cookie wrote:MyKeysToMusic must have videos that answers your question.Assuming the sample is named "MarkSample" and is in sample slot #55.Create an empty program, say in B:03:2.Turn the Synth Engine On and turn the volume knob to the max (master volume up too).Turn the selection knob to Sample (selection 6 down right) and with the other knob, select 55.Play !FredI would add a step after creating the Empty Program: do a Synth Init (to initialize the program to be based on Synth section, so also effects are pre-assigned to it, even if switched off, but you may want to add them) and/or a Sound Init on the Synth section.To the OP: even if there are good video tutorials, I recommend you to study the NS2 manual (all of it, end to end, is not a big one compared to other keyboards) and then focus on Synth Section in particular; it explains all you need to know about your NS2, including definition of what Programs and Samples are in NS2 architecture and how to Init the Synth and use the Samples as Osc waveforms (which is only the beginning, in most cases you may then want to alter them with filter, envelopes, effects.... that's why you need to know all of your NS2).

title: RE: Toto's "Africa" SynthBrass Sound
post_content: I have just read this :Here's the definitive scoop from Oct 82 issue of Keyboard mag Toto interview.Keyboard Editor:What else is going on in "Africa"?David Paich:The kalimba is all done with the GS1. It's six tracks of GS1 playing different rhythms. There's a high organ sound that's GS1, and I wrote the song on CS-80, so that plays the main part of the entire tune.GS1 is here, in Nord's Library :http://www.nordkeyboards.com/main.asp?t ... slib=SynthFM is part of the synth section on the NS2 (3 osc).CS-80 , analog 1 oscilliator per voice, 8 voices ...

title: Nord Stage 2/2EX Programs for Beatles songs
post_content: I played for many years in a Beatles tribute band, so I have a number of programs that may be useful to the community. I will share them in this topic, one for each post.Recommendations:1- these sounds were programmed on a NS2 88 HA: if you're using a 76 HP or 73 SW, you will sometimes run out of space for the splits, and/or you will have to adapt them.2- most (maybe all) of the non-piano sounds make extensive use of morphs, always for volume and sometimes for several parameters. Make sure you have a control pedal connected!3- we played 1 semitone lower to give the singers some breath. If you want to play in the original key, don't forget to turn off the Transpose button!4- these sounds were programmed to be played in a full tribute band (we learned the parts note from note from the Sacred White Book with all Beatles' songs), with 2 guitars covering the original guitar parts and sometimes a second keyboard player for the most complex songs. So, no shortcuts! If you need a "generic" beatles patch that will allow you to go through a song without a full band, you will not find it here, sorry!5- All the files are in .ns2p format, you will see the necessary pianos and samples once loaded in the Nord Sound Manager or even better, using the great program viewer app created by our fellow forum member florence (nord-stage-forum-f3/ns3-program-viewer-t19939.html). Anyway, if there is some obscure sample that you cannot find, just ask!I'm not uploading mp3 demos because all pianos and samples are standard ones found in the main Clavia website or here in the forum/nordusersounds.I only used this one file of sound effects I made myself (Jet plane for Back in the USSR, bubbles for Octopus' Garden, and various claps and cowbells), to be used in a split configuration on the bottom part of the keyboard. There are sounds only on some white keys, the others (and all blacks) only have silence, to minimize the risk of hitting the wrong sound. C1-D1-E1= 3 different claps (sound best when played all together, to give the sense of a clapping group). G1-A1= 2 cowbells, one brighter and one deeper (these have a higher volume than the other samples, careful!). C2=bubbles for Octopus's Garden. E2=jet plane for Back in the USSR (when used with the Hold function, it will loop endlessly).These claps and bells can be loud, always mind the volume pedal!

title: Nord Stage 2/2EX Programs for Beatles songs
post_content: I want to hold your hand.A simple program with just piano and claps on the bottom octave. Also usable for Eight days a week, I saw her standing there and all the early rock'n'roll songs which usually had just piano (or not even that) and lots of claps, cowbells, etc. For Back in the USSR, use the jet plane on key E2 in combination with the Hold function: it will repeat ad libitum (if playing at the correct tempo, it shold be more or less in time with the song...not that it's really important)

title: Nord Stage 2/2EX Programs for Beatles songs
post_content: Hey Jude.Although it's a simple 3-zone split (strings on the left, horns center, piano right) this was a tricky one: there are simply not enough keys (and fingers!) to play correctly all the parts. Also, during the big final crescendo with full piano, strings and trumpet chords, polyphony is severely put to the test and voices dropping out are noticeable. title: Nord Stage 2/2EX Programs for Beatles songs
post_content: Two programs for Let it Be.The first is relatively straightforward, and I used it when we had a second keyboardis playing the horns. So it's basically just piano and organ, with the attention of pressing down the control pedal on the middle and ending breaks, to bring in the distorted Rhodes. Oh, and switch between Organ Presets I and II for the soft chords during the first chorus, as opposed to the distorted riff in the mid break.This second one is probably the most complex sound I used: not so much from a programming standpoint, but rather because it was quite an act of gymnastics to play it correctly in a performance! In order:- acoustic piano on the upper split for the whole song (avoid to play octaves in the bass, to avoid running out of keys).- 1st chorus: enter the organ in the middle keyboard zone, on Preset I- 2nd chorus: the organ is replaced by the horns in the left section.- Interlude: this is where things get interesting. Use the mod wheel to bring in the Rhodes on top of the acoustic piano. Play the rhodes section of the break, then press Organ Preset II to switch to a fuller organ sound. Play the organ break, bring down the mod wheel to go back to acoustic piano and revert to Organ preset I. Now you have all the guitar solo to breathe again.- Now things are easier all the way to the end, just remember the mod wheel for the closing Rhodes riff!

title: Nord Stage 2/2EX Programs for Beatles songs

title: Nord Stage 2/2EX Programs for Beatles songs
post_content: Strawberry Fields Forever.Another tricky one, with two sections of the song using totally different sounds, which I always found quite difficult to blend well in the mix with other live instruments, possibly because it was post-produced so much on tape that the final sounds bear little resemblance to real instruments (and of course the famous "flutes" were not real flutes but Mellotron tapes, etc etc etc).Anyway, I ended up with two versions of this song. The first one tries to do everything with a single program, using a great sample I found on this forum, "Strawberry Orchestra", with strings, trumpets and sitar all together in different parts of the keybed.For whatever reason, I was never fully satisfied with this version. Either the intro and first verse sounded great, but not the second part, or vice versa. I struggled for months with equalization and never found the perfect solution. And so...see next post.

title: Nord Stage 2/2EX Programs for Beatles songs
post_content: Another version of Strawberry Fields. I found I could tailor the sounds much better using two separate programs, one for the intro-1st chorus-verse and the other for the rest of the song, with the trumpets and the sitar breaks. I put them one after the other on the set list, and learned to be quick in switching programs mid-song. Of course the NS2 doesn't have seamless transitions, so sound will be cut for a split second when doing the switch. I found that in live performance this was basically unnoticeable by the band (and even less by the audience), but it remained the one situation where I longed for the seamless transitions of the E6/NS3!

title: Nord Stage 2/2EX Programs for Beatles songs
post_content: Tomorrow Never Knows.The Beatles song that changed everything for me. When I first listened to it I was simply shocked. Was I listening to Radiohead or Aphex Twin? To Chemical Brothers or Brian Eno? How could that thing possibly be from nineteen-SIXTY-SIX ?!? Since then, whenever somebody says Beatles only did silly outdated pop songs, I make them listen to this and make them guess who's the author and when it was recorded. By the time they recover their jaw from the ground, they've usually changed their mind about the Fab FourAs for the program, I used the arpeggiator and Hold function together with a lot of delay to recreate the sitar drone. Press C3 to start the song and don't touch it again, and don't play any other sitar note, to aoid messing things up. Just remember to turn off the arpeggiator at the end of the song to stop the drone.The other split zones contain the violin and organ sounds. The reversed guitar solos was played by our guitarist, so I didn't recreate it.

title: RE: Queen
post_content: Hi - i've been busy with work so long delay...I was interested in seeing if the arpeggiator  voice in Radio Ga Ga could be reproduced on the NS2... I had my doubts, but thought i'd give it a go.The results are more "Radio BooHoo" than "Radio GaGa"! But as always, you can get something usable with the NS2.First off - no samples. That's cheating!I tried to reverse engineer the sound and decided to use a square LFO to modulate the cutoff frequency on a staccato synth with the arpeggiator latched on.It works surprisingly well, but I discovered a big drawback with the NS2 synth - you can't reset the LFO when you press a key - it just runs.(EDIT: I added an item to the NS2 wishlist if you want more detail on this.nord-stage-forum-f3/ns2-wish-list-somet ... tml#p52622)Anyway, with both the arp and the LFO synced to the master clock running around 104BPM it's ok.If you Tweak the Frequency knob up to 12 oclock, and the Freq 1 (LFO mod) down a bit and Freq 2 (Mod env) betwen 12 and 3pm, you can mess with the arp and see how the LFO does its thing. (you can hear the results of some of this in the MP3) To any synthnoobsbeginners out there, i am willing to go into more detail on this kind of thing, but in another postI put this in Slot A and mapped it to the Lower part of the keyboard (Try F1 - i think the song is in Fmajor), and then tweaked a kindof generic pad I made for something else in Slot B, and added a Piano slot for a bit of attack (I used the Yamaha Studio Grand i think), I don't like the results myself, but I thought i'd post it anyway.Personally I would probably use another synth to handle the arpeggio and go for a fatter, fuller sound on the NS2 using both synth slots.As usual the disclaimer: this is not a demo of great playing, nor is it meant to be a fully authentic patch. Just an education in tweaking the synth.Radio_BooHoo.mp3EDIT:DO NOT GET THE PATCH FROM THIS POST!- it was just a quick first attempt. Get the better version on the next page of this thread, which sounds like this:Radio_GaGa.mp3

title: RE: Queen
post_content: This patch works a little better - it uses the Yamaha Studio Grand piano and the sample Full Strings, both from the Nord library.There's a little amp on the piano to make it sound brighter, but it's not possible to add the FM bell sound without another slot... (so use an external midi synth).The arpeggio is on Slot A. I'm not messing with the volume to make it cut-out, that's the square wave LFO.To get the effect, start with the filter (Freq knob) at it's far left position, and the LFO (Freq Mod 1 knob) at about 7. Then sweep up the filter slowly to about 2 O'clock, you might want to simultaneously bring the LFO knob anti-clockwise a little if you are feeling dexterous! If it was an encoder instead of a pot, you could do both with a morph, but there we are. You could still map the filter to the Mod Wheel though, if you prefer.Edit: ideally you wouldn't want to start with the bottom F piano note. If I was performing, I might start the arpeggio with the volume down, then bring it up.Due to the fact that the arp does not key sync, it might be hard to get it in time with the drum beat, but it doesn't seem to matter too much if it's a little off.Radio GaGa - better.mp3It's still only good enough for a pub gig
