title: Pink Floyd - Shine On You Crazy Diamond
post_content: Here's my gift of the week to the good people of this forum.I've searched around for a good patch for Shine On You Crazy Diamond, and found mixed results. Some people made some good patches with samples, but that doesn't cut the mustard for me - firstly because they immediately give themselves away as samples when you play at anything other than the root pitch, and secondly because I avoid samples where possible out of sheer old-school prejudice!There are some great patches for the NS2 for the multi-layered chords, but they use both slots, so no good for the lead if you only have one board.So i used the B3 organ to supplement a detuned saw with chorus, LFO instead of phaser and the results are pretty OK IMHO.That left slot A free for my nice Moog synth lead.Anyway, there's my justification for revisiting old ground out of the way, and here's the patch.Performance tips:- The Mod Wheel is set up as a morph to control the levels of Synth B and Organ together, so you can do the fade-in at the beginning of part 1- The Preset II button in the organ section switches to a slightly different organ - you can add adjust 8th drawbaw while playing, to add that high G which is hard to reach- Sustain pedal will sustain the chords but not the lead, so you can change chords more seamlessly- Lead Moog synth has aftertouch vibrato, (although Richard Wright probably used mod wheel for that originally).- Recommend tweaking the main FREQ knob and the amp drive on the lead synth (slot A) to get the brightness to your liking.Shine_On_2.mp3

title: Baba O' Riley
post_content: Hello,below my very first attempt to build a patch for playing Baba O'Riley on NS2.Here's how it works- when you load the patch you find yourself on Slot B, which is dedicated to the main Arpeggio. Play a F3-C4-F4 then Latch the Arpeggiator (with the Hold Button or using a Latch pedal)- now activate Slot A and on the upper section you have the organ ready for playng the additional notes of the intro (play C6->D6->E6->F6, then on with the other phrases) and on lower manual you have a Bosie piano ready for the piano power chordsIt is just my first try and I focused on the Arpeggiator and tremolo, so the organ sound can be improved to better match the original, if you like and do it please post your resultsNote: you can control the legato/staccato style of notes played by synth-organ section(s) by changing their AMP ENV release timePS: the MP3 demo is intended only to show the sound, I improvised it based on my memory of teh song but probably it isn't 100% right.Baba O-Riley.ns2pBaba O'Riley patch for NS2 (no samples required)(547 Bytes) Downloaded 1554 timesBaba O' Riley NS2 short demo.mp3Enjoy and comments welcome!

title: RE: Baba O' Riley
post_content: This is really a well designed and executed patch. Just the right combination and amount of effects makes the arp reproduce the exact notes on the recording.  Small changes can completely negate the excellent programming you did here.I made a couple of adjustments to it and hope to post it this weekend.1. Adjusted the main arp sound to try to get it closer to the original "marimba repeat" sound done on the Lowrey organ. The original has a percussive and metallic quality that I have found difficult to reproduce. Still more work on this.  I used Organ wave 6 instead of 7 here.2. I moved the Main Arpeggio to an upper split so I can have the piano available for both slots, because the arp changes and I didn't want to miss too much by having to change it and switch back to slot A to play the piano chords.3. I set up the Arp for slot A as well, because some of those figures continue along with the main arpeggio. After the first part of the song, when the piano chords come in, I turn on the ARP and Hold, hit keys C-F, and the resulting figure sounds fairly good and goes with the main arp with either the F or C chord.  The figures can be changed between the phrases played on the piano for variety like the original.-dj

title: RE: Baba O' Riley
post_content: Hi Whimsical,There are three different sounds going on here and Electros are mono-timbral.  Also, there is no sample involved in this NS2 program.  It would technically be possible to physically sample those sounds and create a composite .nsmp file containing each sound element, but that would be quite a lot of work and would yield a result which wasn't useable anyway.  The sustain pedal needed to latch the arpeggio would mess up the organ and piano parts.Some ideas are simply not practical, even if/when they might technically be possible or very nearly so.  Ultimately, it's just not going to be possible to trick your Electro 4 into pretending that it's a Stage 2.  If you have a dual keyboard setup, you might be able to figure out a way to attack this by assigning some portion(s) to one kbd and have the other cover the remainder.Easiest solution would be to get an NS2 though.Bless,Pablo

title: RE: Baba O' Riley
post_content: My band plays this every night, so I did some additional work on this.I programmed the main arp on my Virus, which was able to get a lot closer to the original sound.  I made the Baba.nsmp from this sound and loaded into Sample slot 139.Clock setting is 119bpmPatch opens in slot B, just hit C5 one time and the arp will start.  The Arpeggiator Hold will keep it going.Then, switch to slot A and you play the C_D_E_F parts with the fluttery organ sound.  Then, hit F and C, and lock in those with with Arp On and Arp Hold buttons.Piano power chords ready to play in the lower split (I used the Fazioli with some EQ for this)Enjoy!-djBABA O RILEY2.ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 660 timesBaba.nsmp(405.23 KiB) Downloaded 856 times

title: RE: Baba O' Riley
post_content: I found that trying to emulate the Lowrey on the Stage 3 without a sample just wasn't worth the time I had already put into it, so I turned to sampling after viewing a video posted by ajstanMy Stage 3 post is atnord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 16090.html. I no longer have a Stage 2 to put together a program, but below are the samples created. The original keyboard part was a bit sharp, so I took the Intro and dropped the pitch to be in tune to the piano for the first sample. The sample with the 32nd notes was created by cutting off the last half of each 16th note (C, D, F, G) and cut-n-pasting the first half again. I don't know the song yet but I play through a few notes on the MP3 so you get an idea of what you have. For the program, the bottom split would have "WhoBabaORileyFGW" with the intro pattern on the F key and a pattern on the G key for when the song changes to a C chord. The middle split would have the desired piano (I used pianos an octave apart to play with one hand so other was free for adding 32nd notes in places). The top split would have the second sample "WhoBabaORiley32W" with the 32nd notes. Take careMP3 - Who Baba ORiley.mp3Keywords: Who Baba O'Riley O'Reily Teenage Wasteland Lowrey

title: Boulevard of Broken Dreams Green Day
post_content: Hi All.Anyone has a program for the stage 2? The gimmick/synth at the beginning with a tremolo....?Just let me knowThanksSincerely

title: RE: Boulevard of Broken Dreams Green Day
post_content: It's most likely guitar put through a tremelo effect as suggested in these videos:I got a reasonable imitation by using a fully distorted Hammond through the Tremelo effect as follows:Use something like the bottom four drawbars full on. Add Leslie and full distortion/overdrive. Use the Tremelo effect with the Amount to maximum, speed to taste obviously. I then added a lot of treble and quite a bit of middle to get the sound to "cut through" a lot more. If you've got a sweepable mid (I think you do on the Stage 2), set the middle frequency to approximate the distinctive middle of a guitar, probably around 800hz to 1Khz.Basically you need to play around with the chord shapes and EQ section to get the right "flavor" to the sound - just think like a rhythm guitarist in terms of chord shapes, so try using chords with no thirds, just root and fifth, or root fifth and octave for example. [Edit: I ended up adding the 5th 6th and 9th drawbars pulled out about halfway to increase the brightness. If you use too much of the drawbars to increase the brightness, it starts sounding a little too "organy".]You're basically just cycling through the chords - Fm Ab Eb Bb. I played octaves in the left hand as it needed some quite low notes to get the right amount of "growl" and depth to the sound.

title: RE: Boulevard of Broken Dreams Green Day
post_content: Super, thanks a lot...

title: RE: Boulevard of Broken Dreams Green Day
post_content: I also found out it works slightly better with the Clav B as the source - slightly more attack and brightness, feels a bit more "guitary", plus you can play around with the Clav EQ settings as well. I reduced the EQ quite a lot - by about half, and I set the Clav's Dynamics to 3 (maximum) to make sure that there was enough level and distortion even if you don't play very hard.

title: RE: Boulevard of Broken Dreams Green Day

title: RE: help extracting sample from bundle
post_content: I wonder why you think your 'Archive Utility' (whatever that is) might be corrupted - directly after reporting that it worked like a charm to open a ZIP file as a folder.It seems that ZIP file handling is fully integrated into your computer. Whereas of course ns2pb file handling isn't. 1) ns2pb files aren't as widely spread as ZIP files, and your computer won't know that this is a special sort of ZIP file; 2) ns2pb files aren't meant to be opened as a container for different parts. They can be, but they aren't really meant to be opened by anybody.So, it will never work with simple clicking - you will always have to know the trick. And the trick is to rename the ending of the file name: change *.ns2pb into *.zip to be able to extract things. And remember having renamed it - as you will always have to re-rename it in order to use it as a Nord sound bundle with the Sound Manager software.The ns2pb isn't the only file format that's a zip container which can be opened while renaming it. The epub format (for ebooks) is the same thing. The LibreOffice file format, too. There are some examples. But you will alway need to use that trick. And if you extract something out of that ZIP file, always use the copy feature, not move parts out: Those special formats always consist of a certain number of specifically named files. And will be needed to work together as meant.

title: RE: help extracting sample from bundle
post_content: With the top box checked, you should now be able to rename the bundle files to have a .zip extension using Finder.  You will get a confirmation pop-up - make sure you click on "Use .zip".  You should then be able to unzip the files using the Finder.  I can post some screenshots if you need to see the steps.When you are using the Terminal to expand the files, the unzip command puts the files/folders into the current working directory (folder).  From your screenshots, it appears to be unzipping in your Home folder, which is normally in the Finder Favorites list as your user name.  If you look there, you should see 3 sub-folders: Piano, Program, and "Samp Lib".  The files you are looking for are in folders under those folders.

title: RE: help extracting sample from bundle
post_content: Hi Mel,I have started up my old MacBook (mid 2021 with macOS Catalina) just now (was posting the .zip file in my previous post from my Windows computer) and tried to unpack the bundle there, ran into similar problems at first after renaming the bundle to CakeByTheOcean.zip and trying a double-click on it from Finder - it actually says that the file format is not supported so there seems to be an issue with the integrated unzip capability of FinderI then tried "WinRAR" which is available at the Mac app store and was able to open the .zip file with this app and export all files into a folder at the desktop. I suggest you try this app for future use...Unzip from Terminal does work as well, but the files will be extracted into your home directory which you can access from Finder by the "Go To" option in the menu bar and then click on "user folder" (or something similar, I am on a german version of macOS and don't know the correct english menu item names). However, just using the  unzip command from Terminal does not collect the extracted files into a specific directory so you are losing the structure and it's difficult to identify everything which belongs to the bundle. You better use the following command in Terminal which creates a new directory (called CakeExtracted in this example) on your desktop and extracts the whole content of the bundle directly into this directory:unzip /Users/maryellenleonard/Desktop/Cake.zip -d /Users/maryellenleonard/Desktop/CakeExtractedHope it helps a bit ... best regardsSchorsch

title: RE: Abacab - Genesis
post_content: elto66 wrote:Hi Keego19.I'm not a smart user of my keyboards, so please forgive me if my questions are stupid.How can I create the sound on my Nord Wave (1)?I uploaded your sample of the abacab synth, and then I tried to put in one slot (A) on OSC2 with the mix totally on OSC2, so it means that slot B is off and OSC1 on slot B is silent. I suppose I have to create the right envelope, filter, LFO etc to have the right sound. But I don't know how you obtained that complete sound.I use an organ on my electro6 (lower keyboard, left hand) but I would like to have the synth on the Wave (upper keyboard, right hand).Can you help me?With the Wave, you should be able to recreate a nice sound using a sawtooth wave for OSC1 and a sawtooth wave set 7 semitones above for OSC2. I don't have a Wave but would suggest starting with the following parameters for the AMP and FILTER: Attack 0, Decay 10, Sustain 10, Release 0 (might be the default for an initialized program). You might want to reach out to folks in the Wave Forum as well. If you want to work from a sample, I just posted one I put together from a Stage 3 program I use that has the synth organ on the left and synth 5ths on the right. The MP3 has the intro drum loop with the first note played and then I come in with the sample. Just reverb is needed but a little echo effect works well with it too. Good luck!Sample posted at-->nord-user-samples-nsmp-samples-f14/gene ... 21386.html

post_content: [quote="WannitBBBad"]With the Wave, you should be able to recreate a nice sound using a sawtooth wave for OSC1 and a sawtooth wave set 7 semitones above for OSC2. I don't have a Wave but would suggest starting with the following parameters for the AMP and FILTER: Attack 0, Decay 10, Sustain 10, Release 0 (might be the default for an initialized program). If you want to work from a sample, I just posted one I put together from a Stage 3 program I use that has the synth organ on the left and synth 5ths on the right. The MP3 has the intro drum loop with the first note played and then I come in with the sample. Just reverb is needed but a little echo effect works well with it too. Good luck!Thanks WannitBBBad.It works. The best way seems to operate with 2 detuned OSC per each lot, and you can play a perfect 5th with one finger. It's perfect at the beginning of the song. I had to reduce the volume of the detunet OSC going on because Tony doesn't play with one finger but he always plays in a 5th way and sometimes in a 4th way, so the single note can't really operate with a strong 5th, but a light 5th is ok and makes the sound very similar. No samples used. I used a normal B3 for the organ on Electro 6 splitting the keyboard with the same sound for the left and right hand.

title: RE: All Night Long - Lionel Richie
post_content: Hey jazzbydave,here's my take on it. On the left split there is the DX Full Tines Piano, to the right you find synth brass / soft synth trombone-like brass. title: RE: Cindi Lauper - Girls Just Want to Have Fun
post_content: I got pretty close with a transistor organ patch on my non-Nord (easier to do the slide intro on non-weighted keys) and a single-shot delay.  Shouldn't be too hard to create if no-one has one, just got to get the timing on the delay right and hope the drummer doesn't start it way too fast or slow.

title: RE: Cindi Lauper - Girls Just Want to Have Fun
post_content: OK, here is a patch for this song.The main transistor organ is on the left side of the split.  It is set to the tempo of the record, but you must play staccato on the upbeat of every other beat to make is sound right.  If you hold the keys down too long, the delay won't be tight.The right hand side of the split is the "popcorn" solo.  To get the flutter effect later in the solo, just turn the Arpeggiator on. No samples used at all.Hope this helps you get through the wedding!-djGIRLS HAVE FUN#1.ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 875 times

post_content: It will take some DIY work yourself, but there's a video on YouTube on a guy who nailed the sound by layering 3 DX patches on the DEXED VST - in the description he lists the patches by name and where to find them. title: Sostenuto latch kbgate
post_content: In the following patch I use the sostenuto-functionality for the piano slot A and both sostenuto and kbgate-function for the synth-sound slot B.That means this synth-sound sustains with no more playing while the other elements keep on playing with no sustain.I use the Trpiple Pedal but this should also work with an extra latch pedal.Slot-B-synth-section uses Clavia's sample FullOrchestra_ste SRv4 on location No. 25.Comfortably numb.mp3Comfortably numb.ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 1803 times______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________Here is just another pad, probably the 10billionth:Tjoh-pad.mp3Tjoh.ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 882 times______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________The following Rhodes has got some ampsim an EQing which I found cuts quite well through a mix.First part is without, second with chorus.Nothing special but to my needs the best I can get out of the currently available epiano library.Genuine Rhodes.mp3Genuine Rhodes.ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 1590 times______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

title: RE: Sostenuto latch kbgate
post_content: I have learnt from your patches Patschi, thank you for sharing.First program with example using the latch function on the forum.I like the balance between the twin cabinet, the eq settings, the compressor, and the pan for your Rhodes programm, the -1 oct shift, the organ section goes well with it too.  I'll keep the name "Genuine Rhodes" for me tooAnd I always like synth pads too.

title: You'll Use This - My Stage 2 "Utility" Program
post_content: My go-to "utility" program is a good starting point for other programs. This has piano, strings, bass, and B3 organ with drawbars on the mod wheel. Slot A has all but the bass; Slot B has left handed bass and piano/B3 on the right. The memory locations in my Nord Stage 2 EX for the samples used in the program are:Slot A - 204 - "WarmPad1__CL stereo 2.0"Slot B - 97 - "FndJazzPlectr_Preamp_ST mono 2.0"Utility Program W.mp3Utility        W.ns2pUtility program with piano, bass, strings, and B3 with drawbars on the mod wheel by WannitBBBad(547 Bytes) Downloaded 589 timesWarmPad1__CL stereo 2.0.nsmpWarmPad1 sample for Stage 2(876.64 KiB) Downloaded 727 timesNote that it doesn't matter which sample memory locations you store new samples in your Nord Stage 2, just make sure that after you load a program, that you point the Slot A and/or Slot B Synth to the correct sample in your system. For example, if you load "WarmPad1__CL stereo 2.0" into your sample location 140 (204 in mine) for the program below, then you just need to point Slot A to 140 rather than 204. I'll revise this post as needed based on questions, so feel free to comment.Take care.LINK "Stage 2 - For Those New To Programming" -->nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 16863.html

title: RE: You'll Use This - My Stage 2 "Utility" Program
post_content: This is terrific info.However I cannot figure out how to input the sounds on the MP3 into my stage 3. Would love to get your basic Utility and other programs you've posted in this group. Thank you

title: RE: You'll Use This - My Stage 2 "Utility" Program
post_content: Hi,you cannot import a MP3 into the Nord Stage, you have to download the .nsmp files. These can be loaded into the Nord by using Nord Sound Manager. But you also cannot load the Nord Stage 2 program file (.ns2p) into the Stage 3, you must rebuild your own program.However, I think Wannitbbbad has also created his utility program for the Stage 3, you can find it here:nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15745.htmlJust download the file Utility_W.ns3f and transfer it to your Stage 3

title: RE: You'll Use This - My Stage 2 "Utility" Program

title: RE: Ohne Dich Münchner Freiheit
post_content: Stinger wrote:Hello, I need the file synonymous as .ns3f is there a converter?Hello,no, it’s not possible to convert NS2 programs to the NS3, you can just transfer the samples. You have to create new programs for the NS3 but these can be based on the same samples which are used on the NS2, the reason is because the NS3 technology is different from the NS2, especially the synth, and therefore not compatible with regards to programs.

title: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: Won't get fooled.mp3First attempt at creating and uploading.  Band is trying to pull this one off.I can't figure out how to get rid of the pulse.Wont get fooled .ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 1298 times

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: Nice!  Sounds like the tremolo effect needs a little attack dialed out. How are you creating the tremolo?edit: "Tremelo" is in Belgium

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: No trem.  It's all done with the wave (#6 organ) and the square LFO.  Phase2 is the only effect.

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: Ok, so tremolo is made by a square wave LFO affecting the frequency on a filter, dialed to the extremes (on/off)? Make sure resonance is at 0, I don't think Attack in the Mod Env section will affect anything with that tremolo effect.  Difficult to armchair for me, I need my board in front of me, but maybe someone else can chime in in the meantime.

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: Hi Jason, very nice patch! Have been working on it myself for the last days, but your patch sounds reall great. Only there is indeed a short attack in the "Quasi"-Tremolo via the LFO routed on the Cutoff, or maybe it is due to the lowest value of 0.5ms? A LFO routed to the AEG while not available on the NS would be a tad more suitable but I think it comes very close!I finally ended up using the Vox Organ and the tremolo, and agree about the Phaser 2 being a pretty good emulation of the original sound.Just to compare I uploaded my patch here, but not much new: IMHO, the Wavetable Organ works pretty well!Won´t get fooled again JE.mp3

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: Nice Johannes ...  Didn't think about it that way.  The trem sounds good.My concern with the pulse in my patch, is it's going to sound awful in a band context.  Bad techno Who.

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: Two ones I just made, one based on your original with the tremolo replacing the LFO, and the second using the B3 sim through the same effects.  Dunno if they're any closer..

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: Johannes - your patch sounds great!  I'm trying to speed it up just a little to the original tempo of the song, but can't figure out a way to do it without ruining the effect.  I'm fairly new to the Nord world, so I may be missing it.

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: Hi James,in the version I uploaded, all speeds are synced via Masterclock. You can easily change the speed by either tapping the desired tempo on the MasterClk Button in the main section or adjusting it manually by holding the MasterClk button and adjusting the speed using the Value Dial.

post_content: Thanks so much, Johannes.  I'll give that a try - I knew I was missing something pretty easy!

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: What I could imagine is that you have the ns2p-file looked at in this viewer, which has been made and provided by the forum user florence if I‘m right:https://ns3-program-viewer.herokuapp.com/Then you only need to rebuild the programme in your Stage 3.Cheers from Germany

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: everygrain wrote:Hi everyone. Is there a way I can use these (fabulous!) samples on my nord stage 3? I've been trying to upload each of them using Nord Sound Manager but I keep getting a message saying the files aren't compatible with my instrument. Is that so? Many thanks.Johannes made a version above using the Vox organ and tremolo effect that can easily be recreated on the Stage 3. Here's a link to a version I put together for the Stage 3 a while back using the two synth panels and a WAH effect morphed to the Control Pedal -->nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 16615.htmlWhoWntGetFldAgnW.mp3For those of you who want to try something similar for the Stage 2, here is what I did with the Stage 3: For the Slot A synth I used Wave 8 ("Wave Organ #1") and for the Slot B synth I used a triangle wave to fatten up the sound a little. For both synths the LFOs are set with the square wave and synced to the clock, the control pedal covers the Wah effect, and EQ is used to pull out some of the midrange. Try it out with your keyboard set up across the range of the control pedal and adjust the midrange EQ as needed to make sure there isn't a frequency range coming through too strong compared to the rest. Take care.I have over 70 programs for the Stage 3 available at -->nord-stage-3-programs-ns3p-ns3pb-files- ... 15748.htmlGood luck to you.

title: RE: Won't Get Fooled Again
post_content: Thanks a lot Tasten-Bert and WannitBBBad!! Great tips -- problem solved!!

title: Use Song Intro on the Nord Stage 2
post_content: Hi all,I'm new on the forum and the Nord.Question I have is how you can use an existing song-intro (few seconds of strange sounds) for the Nord Stage 2?Is it better tot use a FLAC or MP3? Most simple seems to play it with Music on your iPhone.But I prefer to have it somewhere on the Nord Stage 2. How do i make a Nord-file of that (MP3 or FLAC)?TNX so far.Happy New Year and Stay Save!

title: RE: Use Song Intro on the Nord Stage 2
post_content: Hi and welcome to this great Nord community!One way to since this is to create a .wav file of the sequence you want to have played, and then use Nord Sample Editor to create a sample which is using one key only to play the audio when you press that key. I did this a few times and used either the highest or lowest key of the keyboard for it (the keys which are used much less than all others).The flip side is that you have to “waste” one of the synth slots for this, but you can also combine the intro sound on a specific key with another or couple of another sounds for the other keyboard areas when using different wave files combined into one sample with sample editor. It’s not very complicated once you understand how the sample editor works

title: RE: Use Song Intro on the Nord Stage 2
post_content: As schorsch said, the only way is to create a nsmp file. You can not load mp3s directly on your nord. I've done the same, with the diference that I use a multisample consisting from various wav. files assigned on different keys. I can play variations of the intro each time and decide how long the intro will last.

title: Sound wanted: Joan Jett
post_content: Hi,does anyone have any hints how to recreate the synth-organ sound on those Joan Jett recordings (links with timestamps)Is this just a held power (7th) chord with a very refined sound or do the fingers move really quickly / trills? Does anybody know the instrument? Some early FM synth or organ?I think it's done by Kenny Laguna but didn't find anything obvious on the web.Any input is appreciated...

title: RE: Sound wanted: Joan Jett
post_content: To me it seems that it is a synthesizer that mimics the organ sound. In these days It wasn't easy to carry around a piece of furniture!By the way, I really find no reason to try to simulate the simulation of a real organ, since I have an instrument that can mimic the real thing better than those early synthsesizers. I bet that if they had a nord back then, they would use a pure B3 sound! However, if I wanted to gve that 80's color to the sound, I would layer an organ with an 80's polysynth sample, an OB6 or polymoog. I would also add some LFO to modulate the sample in order to give this tremolo effect (they probably did the same to simulate the lesslie effect).

title: RE: Sound wanted: Joan Jett
post_content: They used Prophets and things for those organ sounds partly because they needed an organ sound and had one around, but mostly, the used them to have something that played and worked like a Hammond butwasn’ta Hammond and didn’t sound like one.Every professional production studio had a Hammond sitting around; if they’d wanted the sound, they would have used one.

title: RE: Sound wanted: Joan Jett
post_content: You mean that a real hammond sounded a bit old and coservative to them and they wanted something modern and fresh but to work in a similar way? maybe you got in point on that, in that era synths were developing rapidly and started taking over classical instruments, at least in mainstream music. In any case, regarding the particular songs, those synth lines are fillers, they don't play major role in the song's structure. So I still can't find a reason to emulate it exactly, except maybe of sound design challenge!

title: RE: A sky full of stars
post_content: Note that just because the piano section may not be active in any given program, there will necessarily still be an assigned piano hidden away in that darkened piano section.  You can go into that program, momentarily turn on the piano section (for both slots A and B), reassign the missing piano to one that exists, turn the piano section off again, and STORE your new program.  The missing message will no longer appear.Bless,PabloPS -- Nanawel, thanks for the contributions to the forum, but they will be better received and spark more interest if you include brief mp3 demos with them.

title: Spacehog - In The Meantime
post_content: In The Meantime has always been one of my favorite rock songs from the 90s.  This summer I got a chance to cover it at a live venue with my shiny, relatively new Stage 2.I had read somewhere that Spacehog got the intro telephone sample from Penguin Cafe Orchestra's "Telephone and a Rubber Band" so I did the same.  It was a good excuse to finally sit down and learn the ins and outs of the Nord Sample Editor.Make sure you listen to the audio on a decent pair of headphones or speakers so you can hear the signature bass line from this song.  I hope some other people can get some use out of this patch or make some improvements!Emeris - In The Meantime.mp3

title: RE: Spacehog - In The Meantime
post_content: nice!

title: RE: Spacehog - In The Meantime
post_content: This is great, thank you!I have a stage 3 and am a new user.I was able to load the sample files (they were up converted) but not the program.  The sound manager indicated the extension (ns2p) is not supported by this instrument.Does anyone know how to do this?  I have created my own program with a split and dial tone on the low and the other sample up higher.  Perhaps this is the simple fix and there is nothing else to the program so I don't really need it?I am also trying to vary the Power Synths Mighty sample to add some drama during the song.  I think Spacehog messed around with oscillators or something during the song.  I am not certain how to do this.Thanks either way!

title: RE: Spacehog - In The Meantime
post_content: Programs of different Nord Stage generations (also true for Electro for example) are not compatible to each other due to different hardware. All you can do is re-create a program to get as close as possible to the original.You can use Florence’s program viewer to load the Stage 2 program and get the information of all parameters used in this program, and then create a new program on the Stage 3.The program viewer can be found here:https://ns3-program-viewer.herokuapp.com/This is the thread about it:nord-stage-forum-f3/ns3-program-viewer-t19939-20.html

title: RE: NS2 EX sound "Come Together" (Beatles)
post_content: Probably a Wurlitzer, I cant hear any vibrato and I dont think it has chorus as it was not around at that time.But im sure you can replicate close with either your fav wuli or rhodes piano samples.There is also a sugestion that they may have been useing a hofner pianet around that time, i dont think it sound like it to me.

title: RE: NS2 EX sound "Come Together" (Beatles)
post_content: Please do not post copyrighted material in the forum.

title: RE: NS2 EX sound "Come Together" (Beatles)
post_content: I have listened again to the original Beatles LP and think, that it‘s rather a Rhodes than a Wurlitzer. It sounds a bit distorted, so maybe they had it recorded „amped“ via one of their VOX guitar amps. And deep in my mind I seem to remember that I‘ve read some years ago in another forum from a guy whose friend worked with the Beatles during the late period and that they had two Rhodeses but no Wurli. Paul was supposed to have played it on Come together.A good reference for the typical Rhodes sound in my opinion is Bob Mayo on „Frampton comes alive“ from mid 70ies. If I‘m not wrong it was his solo at „Do you feel, feel like I do“ which has got me! And the typical Wurlitzer sound is Supertramp.I play Come together in my rockband with the sound as in the foto, here the details (disregard the poti positions in the foto):Sample is EP 7 Amped Tines XL 6.0EQ: Bass -3,0, Freq 5,6 Hz, Gain +6,4, Treble +11,2Eff 2: 3,6 HzDelay: 0,2Reverb 0,5If this is of good help for you, then have fun with it! If not - I‘m open for other thoughts. Stay healthy everybody and best regards from Germany.

title: RE: NS2 EX sound "Come Together" (Beatles)
post_content: It was definitely a Fender Rhodes EP on the original.I have watched a video on youtube (I can no longer find it).I still have an mp3 recording I made of just the audio. Some person introduces the main speaker on the video as "Steve", who has a British accent, but no last name was mentioned.This Steve person explained that he was given access by EMI and "Sir Paul McCartney" to not just the final 8 track recording on which the studio recording was finished, but also the original 4 track recording on which the song had been started."Steve" says the song as using a Fender Rhodes, which he described as being a relatively new instrument at that time.I have used the Nord Nefertiti EP sound when our band has covered this song.Someone at Abbey Road studios really knew how to record a drum kit in 1969. Pity they did not also record the kit for Who's Next.

title: RE: NS2 EX sound "Come Together" (Beatles)
post_content: It does look that it was a Rhodes, I’ve just listened to the 4 track multitrack stems. They appear to be the original 4 tracks. It sounds like a Rhodes. It even has the track listed as Guitars and Fender Rhodes. So for me it’s an early Rhodes.

title: RE: NS2 EX sound "Come Together" (Beatles)
post_content: Normski wrote:So for me it’s an early Rhodes.It's a suitcase Mk 1. These became available in 1965, four years before "Come Together" was recorded.There's a rather amusing story about how the Beatles acquired theirs (the record company on both sides of the Atlantic going through enormous lengths and jumping through hoops to buy one and fly it over, avoiding all red tape, only to be shrugged off by Paul with the realisation that "oh, I guess I meant a Wurlitzer then."

title: RE: NS2 EX sound "Come Together" (Beatles)
post_content: Someone recently posted a video "Deconstructing Come Together" which allows one to listen to isolated tracks. The EP starts at at bout 10:45, although it seems mixed lower relative to the guitar in the partly isolated track than in does is the actual studio recording:Maybe this is what Normski was referring to?As an aside, it's an amazing capture of the kit. If I didn't know the song and someone asked me when it was recorded just based on the kit, I would guess about 10 years later.

title: RE: Bundle for Worship
post_content: milossd wrote:I need help, I download this and I dont know how to put on my nordHi milossd,This is a bundle package, so it has all programs and necessary samples. Here are the steps:1 - First of all, you have to download and install Nord sound Manager.2 - Make a backup (backup button) of your NORD STAGE 2. It´s a very important step.3 - Use the button "Bundle Down" to put the sounds on you NS2. You can use "add to a bank" option (NS2 should have some progam locations free) or "Replace the content in bank" option (replace your programs).PS.: Sample Partition and Piano Partition has to have some free memory to put this package on your keyboard.

post_content: Hey there, I LOVE the sound of these files, but I'm struggling with making them work on an E3. Is there a way to make a program with these two sounds split? I've tried to use the sound editor, but I'm overwhelmed. Definitely kicking myself for not springing the extra cash for a Stage, since the vast of majority of files do not work for me. My band wants to play this next month, and I would love to get it spot-on. Any help or advice would be appreciated.

title: RE: Never tear us apart - INXS
post_content: The electro 3 cannot play two different samples at the same time.It is also not possible to reëngineer the original samples from an .nsmp file. You will need to either get access to the original sample editor projects or the original samples. Then you could combine them into a single Nord Sample file with two sounds split across the keyboard.

title: RE: Never tear us apart - INXS
post_content: Thanks. Sorry that I'm brand new to Nord. How can I load this into my Stage 3? Need to convert it?

title: RE: Never tear us apart - INXS
post_content: rpossemo wrote:Thanks. Sorry that I'm brand new to Nord. How can I load this into my Stage 3? Need to convert it?In Nord Sound Manager you may need to remove a few samples you don't use to make room for the two samples ("nsmp" files) listed at the beginning of this post, then you'll need to make a program to use each.  A few tips for Sound Manager:- View your current samples in organize mode to show open memory locations.- Sort samples from largest to smallest and delete the ones you don't need starting with the largest so you're freeing up the most space without losing as many samples.- Save all new samples to memory locations 250 and above so you always know what you added versus what came stock with the Stage 3.I hope this helps - take care.

title: RE: Muse "Uprising" Synth sound
post_content: Hi Fabrice and welcome!Unless some other NS2 plays this exact song and has a patch and is eager to share, it will be difficult to get such a quick reply, plus very nice by the guy, so you might need some patience.To start with, it always helps to try to get the instruments used in the studio recording which in your particular case of Uprising would probably (IIRC of the Muse gear) a Juno 60 and a Moog Voyager. So I would guess, with one of the Moog Samples from, the Nord library for the Solo Lead you chould be able to get this typical Muse Solo sound (Be sure to try all of them out plus some additional filtering etc.!!!). Pretty sure you get the Muse sound from there!!For the rest, the VA of the NS2 using Sawtooth waveform should give you a way to replicate the rest of it. Good luck!!I'm sorry that  cannot give you a more detailed proposition, but I don't have the NS2 ;-(

title: RE: Liquido - Narcotic
post_content: Thank you all!Lord Nord, or Hanon, do you know how to obtain a sound closer to the original, "more wet" like you said? I saw on another topic (D 70 samples) that the sample "Mondopoly" seems to be the one used by liquido for this song, has someone a personal patch wich use this one?

title: RE: Liquido - Narcotic
post_content: Fabinlive wrote:Hanon, do you know how to obtain a sound closer to the original, "more wet" like you said? I saw on another topic (D 70 samples) that the sample "Mondopoly" seems to be the one used by liquido for this song, has someone a personal patch wich use this one?Hello Fabin,I believe that Liquido used an actualRoland D-70for this sound.I watched a couple live videos, and Wolfgang is seen playing one.I did asampleof this sound, but the sample just doesn't quite capture the magic.I have a D-70 in the studio, and will attempt to break down the sound.The D-70 is an odd synth/ ROMpler which seems to me to sound somewhat in between the U-20, 220 and the JV-1080.It's architecture is up to 4 tones per Patch, and up to 4 Patches per Performance program.Roland_D70DSCN1480.jpg (1.96 MiB) Viewed 19784 timesThe Mondo Poly Performance program (I:47) is a layer of 4 PatchesPatch 1= a87 Lite Bell1Patch 2= a88 Polysyn (a brassy Jump type sound)Patch 3= a88 Polysyn (detuned for analogish chorusing)Patch 4= a88 Polysyn (up an octave from Patches 2 and 3) volume reduced by 12%Overall, the Performance program has Hall 2 reverb.Velocity controls the filter cutoff frequency.AfterTouch controls the filter cutoff frequency, and vibrato amount.The attached mp3 attempts to give a listen to the individual elements, as well as what the AT controls.0:00 to 00:08Performance with all Patches0:08 to 0:17Patch 1 only0:18 to 0:21Patch 2 only0:22Patches 2, and 3 only0:25Patch 4 only0:30Patches 2, 3 , and 40:33All Patches again0:35 to 0:42Demonstration of AT's action0:43Ham-fisted attempt at the hook lineD70_MondoPoly_Narc.mp3Roland_D70_Lite_Bell1.nsmpPatch 1 D70 Lite Bell1(574.15 KiB) Downloaded 1709 timesI hope this sheds some light on the sound.Cheers, Hanon

title: Sample Library Failure
post_content: I just got back from a rehearsal, where my unit was still functioning fine, but now at the start-up process, I got the error saying some of my samples in my sample library were corrupted. The error is shown in the video you can find here:It says 'SampLib Failure: [insert name of sample]', and then alternates between samples that are corrupted. When I connect the instrument to the Nord Sound Manager (V6.86), those samples are shown in red, with the error message 'Broken - Invalid checksum'. The number under 'Version' is then very high and unrealistic, and of course incorrect. The other samples look fine. In the Sample Manager I am then asked to delete those samples, and then restart the keyboard. If I do so, I get the error message that another load of samples is then corrupted, and this is an endless loop, at the end of which I am left with no samples at all.Please note that I am running the latest operating system on my Stage 2, and that I am using the latest version of the Sound Manager.I have tried under 'File' in the Sound Manager the 'Format' several times, and after re-downloading all samples from Clavia's site, and re-downloading them to the instrument, the same thing happens. I've tried 'Clean Deleted Space' as well.I need my Nord badly this Saturday. Is there any way to fix this, or to at least get a replacement somehow?

title: RE: Sample Library Failure
post_content: Try cross posting this in the general NS forum, rather than the 'Programs' section. You're more likely to get a response there. Good luck!

title: RE: Sample Library Failure
post_content: No crossposting, please. This is the right forum.

title: RE: Sample Library Failure
post_content: Sorry, didn't realize about the cross posting rule.OP's issue seemed much more technical about a software issue and less about actual programs...

title: RE: Sample Library Failure
post_content: Did someone solve this issue??? I have a friend who’s having this issue again with the Nord Stage 3 88

title: RE: Sample Library Failure
post_content: PhonPhon91 wrote:Did someone solve this issue??? I have a friend who’s having this issue again with the Nord Stage 3 88Ensure your friend has the latest OS on NS3 and the latest version of Nord Sound Manager + try on different computer(s) if possible

title: RE: Sample Library Failure
post_content: Try restoring from one of his backups or the factory restore file on the Nord website.  If it works, then the issue was likely an anomaly (like a power surge or extremely rare software bug) that corrupted the data that was loaded.  If there's still a problem after restoring a known good file, then it's more likely to be a hardware issue that requires diagnosis and repair.

title: Recommendations for new 80s keyboard sounds
post_content: Hi everyoneI currently have a Nord Stage 2 as my main keyboard but would like to add a new additional keyboard specifically to recreate 1980s band sounds i.e. Duran Duran, Simple Minds, Depeche Mode, Human League, Soft Cell, and all those big 1980s sounds including the ones which include guitar..... says our guitarist!!!  (So looking at material other than Kraftwerk!!)Thinking I need another keyboard with good arpeggiator and looping capability, (which might include drum as bonus only),  while I play synth on the Nord, with maybe presets for the 80s synth and piano sounds.  Needing something to work with the Nord maybe layering on top of what Nord primarily is playing, Nord always being the main keyboard with secondary keyboard backing up what I can't play at the same time on Nord with its 2 slots per programme.My local music store PMT in Bristol, UK,  showed me the ROLAND VR09 before lockdown on a casual visit, and it was about £700 then, its now available for about £570.  Awesome price when I consider the price of a Nord.  This Roland VR09 is 61 keys, not weighted,  which is fine as I have my beloved Nord with 88 fully weighted keys for my main stuff.  Looking at videos the Roland VR09 seems to cover a variety of  decades, not particularly 1980s.What do you 1980s guys and girls  think.  Agree, disagree, can you offer alternatives up to approx  £1000 UK sterling pounds.   (I am a classical trained pianist now mostly playing In a David Bowie tribute band which is currently exploring a side line of 1980s music.  Things like modules and tech stuff are therefore a bit alien to me, not necessarily beyond me,  but thinking that is something I might need to get into reluctantly.  Any comments and recommendation welcome).Happy lockdown creativity, and love to you all.   Looking forward to hearing from you.   Boom Boom Boom.Sally

title: RE: Recommendations for new 80s keyboard sounds
post_content: Hi Sally, I would recommend to have an eye on the korg kross 2-61 which is at the same price level as the roland vr09 but has much better arpeggio features and as far as I know much better 80s synth sounds. The roland vr09 seems to be let me call it a low price plastic nord. Roland launched this model after they didn‘t get neither the vr760 nor the vr700 established in the market segment which was opened by nord. I think you‘ll love the korg. Sunny regards from Germany.

title: Hammond with Leslie/Tremolo on Mod Wheel, DX7, Bass
post_content: This is my new "utility" program with bass on bottom split and Hammond, Rhodes or Rhodes/DX7 on top split (of course a breeze to get to any other Piano as well).  For the Hammond, the program uses the MW to control the Leslie all the way from stopped to its fast rotation (like a Leslie 22R).  The MW is also morph-assigned to the Effect 1 Rate/Tempo for the tremolo to accent the Leslie rotating effect.  The mp3 starts out with me nudging the MW slightly on-off, "rotating" the Leslie to different stopped positions, then moving the MW to slightly-on for the slow Leslie/tremolo, and then all the way up for the fast Leslie/tremolo.  While in fast mode, I turn the tremolo effect on and off so you can hear the effect of just the Leslie and the Leslie/tremolo combination - it's off when the organ sounds louder, but also not as "pulsing" as with the tremolo. With the tremolo on again, I then back the MW off to slow down the rotation.The Leslie will follow whatever function last controlled it. If you move the MW, the Leslie will follow that; if you hit the Leslie slow or fast button, the Leslie will follow that including pedal-controlled slow/fast - which leads to the next effect.  On the mp3 I speed up the Leslie/tremolo again with the MW, and then with the MW in the fast mode, I hit the Slow/Fast button on the Leslie to slow it down while the tremolo stays in the fast mode based on the MW setting. The result (to me) is an accented Hammond chorus with slow Leslie that I really like.  I then play a couple bars using that setting with the bass in the lower split.  Turning on the Rhodes and synth at the end, I have the DX7 Rhodes with the Hammond (if you're interested in the DX7 Rhodes sample, more information is provided in my prior post athttp://www.norduserforum.com/nord-stage ... t7676.html<-link).Below are two versions of HammondWheelDX, the second uses an amp with the Hammond - hope you like them. Take care.HammondWheelDX W.mp3HammondWheelDX W.ns2pHammond with Leslie/Tremolo on the wheel and DX7 Rhodes patch.(547 Bytes) Downloaded 1020 timesHammondWheelDX2W.ns2pHammond with Leslie/Tremolo on the wheel, DX7 Rhodes patch, and amp settings.(547 Bytes) Downloaded 967 timesLINK "Stage 2 - For Those New To Programming" -->nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 16863.html

title: RE: Hammond with Leslie/Tremolo on Mod Wheel, DX7, Bass
post_content: Thanks for this! I'm going to load it up this evening!

title: RE: Hammond with Leslie/Tremolo on Mod Wheel, DX7, Bass
post_content: Something to note: it's cool that the Leslie will follow whatever function last controlled it (morph to wheel or buttons for STOP/SLOW/FAST) with this program, however, if you place the Leslie in the "stop" mode with the wheel and then change programs to another using the Leslie, the Leslie will continue to be in the stop mode (but no STOP button light on) until the STOP MODE button is hit twice or the SLOW/FAST button is hit. I'd consider that to be a "bug" as the orientation of the Leslie in one program shouldn't affect where it's set with another, however I hope that if Nord decides to fix that, that they don't break the feature I like most of having the multiple options of controlling the Leslie.

title: RE: Hammond with Leslie/Tremolo on Mod Wheel, DX7, Bass
post_content: WannitBBBad wrote:Something to note: it's cool that the Leslie will follow whatever function last controlled it (morph to wheel or buttons for STOP/SLOW/FAST) with this program, however,if you place the Leslie in the "stop" mode with the wheel and then change programs to another using the Leslie, the Leslie will continue to be in the stop mode (but no STOP button light on) until the STOP MODE button is hit twice or the SLOW/FAST button is hit. I'd consider that to be a "bug" as the orientation of the Leslie in one program shouldn't affect where it's set with another, however I hope that if Nord decides to fix that, that they don't break the feature I like most of having the multiple options of controlling the Leslie.This is a really old post, but... Actually I don't think morphs, once assigned to the wheel, AT or CtrlPedal are "meant" to be operated from the button/knob that originally controlled them, hence I'm hesitant to call what you describe a "bug".By the way what you describe actually happens also within the same Program. Try this:Assign the rotor to the wheel. Now increase the rotor speed with the wheel, still within the "green LED" range but fairly "fast-ish". Hit stop mode to completely stop the rotor. It does stop indeed. Now hit it again to resume: surely enough it starts spinning again, but you'll note it's NOT at the same speed you left it with the wheel; rather, it's at its "default" low speed. You touch the wheel again, the rotor will quickly catch up to whatever speed matches the actual position of the wheel.Another example: try now increase the speed with the wheel but go to full speed. Now try press the button slow/fast: it won't do anything. Viceversa, had you pressed it with the wheel still on the green LED zone, it would have switched to fast.These kind of quirks in my opinions aren't bug strictly speaking, but a natural consequence of having two physical controls conflicting over the same parameters. By the way an example of what I described can be seen at the end of this video:Note how they try to act on rotor speed both from the wheel and from the button.

title: RE: Hammond with Leslie/Tremolo on Mod Wheel, DX7, Bass
post_content: Hlaalu wrote:This is a really old post, but... Actually I don't think morphs, once assigned to the wheel, AT or CtrlPedal are "meant" to be operated from the button/knob that originally controlled them, hence I'm hesitant to call what you describe a "bug"....Hello Hlaalu, welcome to the Forum! Unfortunately I don't have my Stage 2 EX any longer, however the "bug" was that if I left the Leslie in the stopped mode using the Mod Wheel and then went to another program, the Leslie would stay in the stopped mode (but no STOP button light on) until the STOP MODE button was hit twice or the SLOW/FAST button was hit.  The Leslie should have gone to whatever I had set for the program I switched to but somehow the morphed "Stop" wasn't getting reset.  The function on the Stage 3 works just fine as you mention, I really like the flexibility it adds to the Leslie. Take care.

Unfortunately I don't have my Stage 2 EX any longer, however the "bug" was that if I left the Leslie in the stopped mode using the Mod Wheel and then went to another program, the Leslie would stay in the stopped mode (but no STOP button light on) until the STOP MODE button was hit twice or the SLOW/FAST button was hit.  The Leslie should have gone to whatever I had set for the program I switched to but somehow the morphed "Stop" wasn't getting reset.  The function on the Stage 3 works just fine as you mention, I really like the flexibility it adds to the Leslie. Take care.Ha I see, I must have misunderstood the problem exactly, but I think I see what you mean now.I actually haven't tried doing what you describe with the Stage 3, but from your lines I piece together that the bug has been fixed eventually.By the way with the Stage 3, personally once I set the rotor to be morphed by the wheel, I don't touch the button again -- as I said the rotor responds oddily if I do so. I also do the same for any morph for the matter.

title: RE: Hot Stuff - Lead sound
post_content: I had been using the factory "Orvar Polynord" setting on my Stage 2, but it didn't sound quite right.  It occurred to me that the original seemed to have a flute sound overlaid with it.  So I looked up layering in the user manual, which was new to me, and tried layering Orvar Polynord with "Organ Flute 2" that I found by rotating the selector wheel through the available samples.  The layered sound supplied the missing element and gave what I felt to be a decent approximation to the original.

title: NS2 KB Layout:Feels Like the First Time
post_content: For anyone playing this tune in a cover band:Here is a complete patch that will cover all the sounds in this tune. Done for the original key of G. The middle part of the split contains the piano used in the intro and the later choruses. Only two notes are played, D and G in a fast repetition. The lower part of the patch is the organ tone for the first part of the verses.  The mod wheel brings in more drawbars for the second half of the verse and the choruses (I have to reach over with my right hand), add fast leslie sim to taste.  The upper part contains the synth patch for the bridge, which is repeated three times, you can just hit the octave switch for the last time and you are good to go.I am not sure how the splits will translate to an 88 Key unit, though.  This was done on my NS2 SW73Enjoy--dj

title: RE: Steam Organ Calliope sound
post_content: I also don't use it often.If my draft is the sound you're looking for and is good enough, you'll need to map automaticcaly starting a C2 with 1 semi tone, then remap manually each sliced waveform in the NSE to the relevant note (I spotted : c2 d f g a c3 d e f f# g g# a a# b c4 c# d# e f f# g g# a a# b c5 d) unloop all and generate the nsmp.Fred

title: Man I feel like a woman!
post_content: Hi folkslooking for some help and advice regarding the brass lick for the intro and sounds for Man I feel like a woman. Does anyone have a patch or samples they use for this. New to creating my own sounds and learning as I go.

title: RE: Man I feel like a woman!
post_content: I was about to say, by heck I'm getting worried about you lolin regards the recording, this takes me back to my college / university years as a musician and sound programmer, I'd often be asked to analyse and sound design where possible to the original spec. the secret is a sax and brass section with a touch of distortion added, bear in mind that at the same time as the brass, you're adding an electric guitar with a good amount of distortion and a touch of compression, so when that's blended as a stereo mix, it has that funk and brightness to it.back in my college years, I was the only keyboards guy / pianist / organist, so I always had to turn up with my own hardware, even when the college had their gear, it was rather crap and not worth my time, so I used to bring a stage controller (well before nord), rack bag containing korg racks (trinity rack, wavestation SR, Triton rack, M1REX or would change it to an 01R, Roland D550) this was strapped on my back while pulling the stage controller, usually one of a few I'd choose from at the time, white cane in the right hand, stage case in the left pulling it, on and off trains, long hikes to locations and the college. thank god I don't have. to do any of that ever again. Uni was easier luckily, the had a fair stock of the tools I needed.lew

title: RE: Worship sound on Nord Stage 2
post_content: natmusic wrote:Thanks very much. How can I install this only in the Program Bank D for example ?The posted link contains .nsmp samples for the Synth, with NS3 but not NS2 not Programs (and the two are incompatible); use the Nord Sound Manager to load the samples in the Sample Memory then create your own Synth sounds (just do a Sound Init on the synth, put the Osc in Sample mode and load the sample you want) and save as Programs in bank D.For Organizing your programs use NSM with the Organize function active (and you may also want to activate the Dual View, if you find it easier to drag drop between two lists rather than one only).

title: RE: Worship sound on Nord Stage 2
post_content: natmusic wrote:OK, thanks very muchAs I saw in Nord Sound Manager that we could put up to 999 sample lib, I thought I could have up to 999 different sounds ...That's correct, but only in theory since number of slots and available size are two different things. Samples vary a lot in terms of size, you can get samples wit a few KB of size and others with a couple of MB - therefore 999 samples is theoverall limit of storage slotsfor samples, these can be used as long as thetotal size of all samplesdoes not exceed the available memory capacity of the sample lib

title: RE: Pink (p!nk) try
post_content: Here is the Patch for try.It comes up in Slot B.  ON the upper split is the pianet type sound for the intro and the pre-verses. The patch uses the Electric Piano sample MKII Shallow.  The delay should match the tempo of the song pretty closely. The lower split is a basic pad for some of the fluff during the verses.  The mod wheel will change the oscillator shape so you can alter the sound.For the Chorus, switch to slot B for the big pad.  Play the G chord in the octave below the split for fatness. I made this with Farfisa and Synth.Enjoy--djTRY          .ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 676 times

title: Old CP70/80 effect... help
post_content: Hi to allI'd like to obtain the sound of the yamaha CP used in this video, in the first few seconds, when the leader takes four.I tried with the NS2ex, I managed to do something, but I think you can do better to get as close as possible. In your opinion, how was it achieved?

title: RE: Old CP70/80 effect... help
post_content: I can hear a lot of Flanger and/or Phaser in that sound + you need to work on the EQ

title: RE: Old CP70/80 effect... help
post_content: That was processed using 3 effects in series. Chorus, Phaser and Flanger, the problem here is that in order to do this, the Stage cannot run multiple effects in the same chain per panel on effect 2 unit.  so, the only way around this is to layer 2 CP80 or the Electric Grand which sounds better than the CP80 sample. Panel A would use chorus at 50% mix but I'd slow it down just a touch, Panel B using Phaser at 75% mix and play with the speed. I'd add a touch of EQ on this and also just a touch of stage reverb to sweeten it a touch. you could with both panels enabled put a touch of piano detune  which might give just that bit of edge.  the original principle would have relied on a CP80 with the Roland Chorus unit connected as well as parallel phaser anda touch of flanger..This is where the stage's effect handling could be improved.

title: USB 3.0
post_content: Hi everyone, I'm just wondering if the Nord Stage 2, or any Nord supports USB 3.0 for quicker transfer speeds?  Or if good old USB 2.0 is fine and it won't make a difference either way.I'm always testing the different piano sounds (XL) and need to hear how they sound through my amp and on gigs, and the process of moving these large samples is slow.

title: RE: USB 3.0
post_content: See:nord-stage-forum-f3/restoring-old-backu ... tml#p95082

title: RE: USB 3.0
post_content: Thanks, looks like the Nord Stage 2 and probably 3 are both USB 1.1 so a standard USB 2.0 cable will do.

title: RE: USB 3.0
post_content: JohnCorda wrote:Thanks, looks like the Nord Stage 2 and probably 3 are both USB 1.1 so a standard USB 2.0 cable will do.Absolutely not 1.1. It would take days to transfer files.Both the stage 2 and 3 should be USB 2.xWould have been nice if the Stage 3 were 3.x, but don't believe that to be the case.

title: RE: USB 3.0
post_content: 1.1 is what lsusb says... unless there is a different mode to send MIDI and data at the same time.12Mbps is about 1.5MB/sec, no?in one minute that would be about 90MB transferred.in 30 mins that is about 2.6GBHow long does it take to backup the NS2?

title: RE: USB 3.0
post_content: I don't think USB 3.0 will much improve time for backup and restore.  As I understand  the weakest link is the time it take to read and write from the memorychips.

title: RE: USB 3.0
post_content: I did a little more digging on this and I believe your correct. The Nord Stage interfaces seem to be based on the full-speed USB 1.1 spec at 12mbps or 1.5MB/sec.USB 2.0 would be a big improvement in RAW transfer speed, but as pointed out the Memory write speed is likely the limiting factor as it probably wouldn't be able to keep up with the data transfer rate.

title: People Gotta Move chords/patch
post_content: [BBvideo=425,350][/BBvideo]Hi there! Is there anyone that plays People Gotta Move (Gino Vanelli, I know, guilty pleasure...).I can't get my hands to play the riffs and there's nothing online it seems. Any help is appreciated. I would love to play this with the band.Thx!

title: RE: People Gotta Move chords/patch
post_content: Great song! I have played it before, let me get back to you with some chords.

title: RE: People Gotta Move chords/patch
post_content: Intro:||: F#m7 | B7/F# : ||Verse:||: F#m7 | bm7 | g#m7(b5)add6 C#7#9 | F#m7 : ||A#+5/C | A#+5/CChorus:||: Bm7 | Bm7 | F#m7 | F#m7 : || 3xg#m7(b5)add6 C#7#9 | F#m7The A#+5 (A#, D, F#) is, as far as I can tell, functionally an F#7+5 as dominant chord leading to the Bm7 in the chorus, with the bass moving to the C as a tritone substitute. Tricky, but cool.Then the whole thing repeats except up a half-tone.Horn break is just  cm7 and gm7.Transition to piano solo is something like dm7 and C#7b5key solo is Cm7 and gm7 again, ending in Am7b5 and that weird run andshift the next chorus another half-note up into C#m7 and G#m7, ending in A#m7b5 and that weird run andanother half-note up.

title: RE: People Gotta Move chords/patch
post_content: Tricky but cool - indeed!I gotta try those chords tonight!

title: RE: People Gotta Move chords/patch
post_content: That's from a quick take — there might be errors in there. But structurally, it's a pretty basic minor progression with a II-V-I minor cadence.Those smileys are, of course, part of the second repeat sign.

title: RE: People Gotta Move chords/patch
post_content: Yep, it seems to be quite right. The A#+5/C is equivalent to a C9#11 (tritone substitute for F#7).When it comes to the sound, I think it's a wurlizer with phaser. On my NE4 I get pretty good results with the amped wurly sample, dyn=3, phase 2 rate 3, and some eq./Anders

title: RE: People Gotta Move chords/patch
post_content: elektromin wrote:Yep, it seems to be quite right. The A#+5/C is equivalent to a C9#11 (tritone substitute for F#7).Ah, thanks! Yes — that's a more elegant way of putting it.

title: RE: People Gotta Move chords/patch
post_content: Hi guys,I have trouble inderstanding the notation of this part: 'g#m7(b5)add6 C#7#9'I do read musical notes but the chords stuff is quite new to me. Could anyone tell me what the between brackets '(b5)'  means?And is the 'C#7#9' a seperate new chord? why then is there no "|" between the two?

title: RE: People Gotta Move chords/patch
post_content: b5 means flat 5, cos the b's as close to the flat symbol as you can get with a normal typeset.The first chord is G#m7, with a flattened 5th instead of the 5th (ie D natural instead of D#), and add to that the 6th (F natural). So something like G# B D F F#The second chord is C#7 (C# E# G# B), then you add the sharpened 9th at the top which is E natural(E#=Fnat)

title: When you’re gone (Bryan adams) - organ sound
post_content: Hi,I’m looking for the organ settings of “When you’re gone” from Bryan Adams/Mel C, which seems to be a tonewheel organ with some specific attack sound (?), can be heard best in the into and the verseDoes anyone have this or could let me know how to create it on an NS2 or NS3?

title: RE: When you’re gone (Bryan adams) - organ sound
post_content: No one having an idea on how to create that sound on a NS2 or NS3?

title: RE: When you’re gone (Bryan adams) - organ sound
post_content: Listening to the whole song I was thinking it was a synth for the percussive organ and at the very end you hear it sustained out with a chorus effect. I'm a few hundred miles from my Nord right now but would set up the background B3 first - left of the split if you have a pedal for Leslie slow/fast or right of split if you have a half moon or hit the slow/fast button. For the percussive sound I would set up a synth and start with the organ waveforms with chorus set up like you hear it at the end of the song and reverb. If I couldn't get it right with just reverb, I would play around with medium reverb and set delay for a tighter slap back. Using OSC2 you also blend in a wave an octave higher or lower if the organ wave doesn't quite get it on its own. This approach leaves slot B open if you want to add an additional synth to the sound with the same effect settings. Hope this helps, take care.

title: RE: When you’re gone (Bryan adams) - organ sound
post_content: Schorsch wrote:You may be right, I saw some videos from Bryan’s live performances where the keyboard player was playing a grand piano with his left hand and the Hammond with his right hand on the intro. I tried to rebuild this on my two Nord stages but am still not getting it right, will continue to try and make it (I am lousy in creating sounds)Live performances are always a good starting point when you try to recreate a sound.For this song:When you try a basic 'rock organ' 888800000 with leslie volume turned up until it sounds just a little bit distorted when you play a chord. No chorus, percussion 3d, soft, fast. Start playing with the leslie slow and just before the singing starts, switch to fast.For the piano sound: Use an electric grand with a slow phaser effect. You don't even need two keyboards, you can do it with a split.

post_content: Well, there are several accordion samples on the Nord web site which I use quite regularly.  You may want to spend some time shaping them: attack, release, effects, etc.I am happy with the results.  I use accordion on maybe 6-8 tunes across different bands.That being said, I'd suggest you use them sparingly.  The bellow effects of a REAL accordion are quite unique, and the Nord can't approach those.As far as instructions to download them into the keyboard, please review the standard Nord documentation.  It's not hard at all.

title: RE: Good accordion sounds
post_content: One suggestion.....to add more "fullness", I assign an accordian sample to both slot A and B, set one an octave higher, and mod wheel morph the volume on one of them to customize the sound I want for the song.

title: RE: Good accordion sounds
post_content: As an accordionist, I would just add that the most realistic way to play the accordion sounds would be to have no velocity sensitivity, and just use the wheel/pedal to control overall volume (a bit like an organ sound). That would be how the accordion would work. Good fun though!

title: RE: Good accordion sounds
post_content: ACCORDIONMAN wrote:As an accordionist, I would just add that the most realistic way to play the accordion sounds would be to have no velocity sensitivity, and just use the wheel/pedal to control overall volume (a bit like an organ sound). That would be how the accordion would work. Good fun though!I use aftertouch on some patches to add the dynamics.

title: for worship musicians, anyone know how to duplicate
post_content: the repeating (oscillating) synth sound on Elevation Worship (do it again)? I have a rod stage 2thanks

title: RE: for worship musicians, anyone know how to duplicate
post_content: The synth pulse is pretty straightforward to recreate. Start with a warm pad sound, set the LFO to a square wave synced to the master tempo at 1/8th notes, turn up the filter LFO knob until you’re getting the pulsing effect. You might also need to turn the freq control down a bit.

title: RE: for worship musicians, anyone know how to duplicate
post_content: Jazzdoc52 wrote:the repeating (oscillating) synth sound on Elevation Worship (do it again)? I have a rod stage 2thanksI have this patch, but for Stage 3

title: RE: for worship musicians, anyone know how to duplicate
post_content: This one is tricky actually. For me, my band plays to a click and while I can set the LFO frequency to a BPM, there's no way to set the LFO to start on keypress. Inevitably, I play the pad with the LFO and it starts on some arbitrary beat that doesn't align with the click. There's no way to fix this, except to have the whole band try to play along to the LFO frequency, which is a dicey proposition. So, while the Nord can technically do this sound, for me it's not actually possible to accomplish it live. That said, the song doesn't suffer much from only having a pad without the LFO movement in my opinion.

title: RE: for worship musicians, anyone know how to duplicate
post_content: JazzDoc52,We play "Do It Again" occasionally, and I just use straight pads with a bit of blueSky shimmer cross-faded in.  Sometimes the extra hassle of making something sound the same just isn't worth the bother - especially when other than the band, no-one notices.Besides, Michael W Smith's version doesn't use the pulsing pad, and I actually prefer that arrangement to the original.

title: RE: for worship musicians, anyone know how to duplicate
post_content: redisred wrote:This one is tricky actually. For me, my band plays to a click and while I can set the LFO frequency to a BPM, there's no way to set the LFO to start on keypress. Inevitably, I play the pad with the LFO and it starts on some arbitrary beat that doesn't align with the click. There's no way to fix this, except to have the whole band try to play along to the LFO frequency, which is a dicey proposition. So, while the Nord can technically do this sound, for me it's not actually possible to accomplish it live. That said, the song doesn't suffer much from only having a pad without the LFO movement in my opinion.I’ve only played this on NS3, so not sure if it’s possible on NS2, however it is possible on NS3: You need the master clock keyboard sync (KBS) set to “On”, so that the pulse LFO starts in sync when you play. The rest of the band is on the drummer’s click which is the same BPM. The keyboard sync on NS3 takes care of any minor timing differences with the rest of the band provided the BPM is the same.***Edit:  Just took a quick look at the NS2 manual, an it looks like it doesn't have a keyboard sync feature for the master clock, so on NS2 you would be stuck with a fixed LFO frequency.One of my big frustrations with the Nord Stage is that you can’t (easily) send a click out to the drummer so that timed effects, arps etc. work well. The keyboard sync makes up for some of that frustration.

title: RE: for worship musicians, anyone know how to duplicate
post_content: redisred wrote:Ah! Master Clock Keyboard sync, that's what I need! Grrrrr, dang you NS3 and your many appealing features that I can't afford.But the Nord can receive a MIDI click, from say a drummer with a trigger, cant it?

title: RE: for worship musicians, anyone know how to duplicate
post_content: Yes it can receive Midi clock, but Midi clock doesn't contain any information about beats (like when they start or stop) - just the tempo. So it would still require you to hit the keys accurately on the downbeat. For that you need a protocol that layers on top of Midi - like Rewire.

title: RE: for worship musicians, anyone know how to duplicate

It contains all the information you described. Maybe not the downbeat but that isn't necessary. The stage 2 isn't perfect but all the Nords I've had so far locked perfectly into the Midi clock I've received from say Ableton or similar. No need to play in time anymore.PM me if you need anything

title: RE: your favourite e-piano and organ programs as *.ns2...
post_content: You might find something helpful at this link.  My "Utility" program includes a B3 with drawbars mapped to the Mod Wheel - crank up the overdrive for more of the "rock organ" sounds, use the "stop" mode on the Leslie to get the Deep Purple "Lazy" sound. The Rhodes/DX7 was put together when a sample for the DX7 was needed, however the sample is still provides a nice accent to the DX7 now available in the piano section.nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 16863.html- Good luck

title: RE: your favourite e-piano and organ programs as *.ns2...
post_content: Thank you for this good ideas... I test especially the "utility program" and the "hammond" program. If I understand it right, in the other programs you did use a DX7 Rhodes, so a "Synthi"-Rhodes.I would like to get some good sounding e-piano-section-programs, so with the build in e-pinaos EP1-8 and Wurlitzer and Clavinets. With your EQ-ing and effects. How do you program these pianos to get a nearly original sound of the e-pianos. I know, this depends a lot on the used speakers/PA, but nevertheless it would be interesting for me to see, what you are doing with EQ, chorus and so on...

title: RE: your favourite e-piano and organ programs as *.ns2...
post_content: The Piano Library at the Nord website (https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... no-library) is a good starting point for information on the pianos available.  For a Rhodes, I use EP1 the most, followed by EP7 and EP5. EP1-EP8 are all Rhodes pianos and very authentic, each with their own tonal characteristics based on vintage, amplification (or not), and "voicing" of the tines. On a Rhodes, the tine for each key can be adjusted in relationship to its pickup to get the tone desired. Regarding effects, it depends on what you're going after: the phase shifter was popular in the early-to-mid 70s and the chorus took off quickly after it was introduced in the mid 70s. The Flanger was popular with the Clavinet. The tremolo effect was popular with the Wurlitzer, and some artists tried the Rhodes and Wurlitzers through the Leslie. The best thing you can do for sound is play your Nord through a good full-range PA speaker.  I play my Stage 3 through a QSC K10 that need little in terms of EQ, but for the Rhodes I'll sometimes add the Twin amp simulator with EQ. I hope this helps, take care.

title: RE: your favourite e-piano and organ programs as *.ns2...
post_content: Dear WannitBBBad... thanks for your infos... I use two RCF Ecox 8 as PA and for home-training or monitoring dbTechnologies Flexsys FM 12. The Nordstage grandpianos sound fantastic with it, but I have problems to get a origin good sound with the e-pianos with my own equipment...I know this nordkeyboards-soundlib-site. There the example-recordings really sound absolute great. But I never get it like this in true. Thats the reason for searching for sound-program-settings on the Nordstage itself, using the EQ- and effect-section, to get a mostly original Rhodes, Wurlitzer an Clavinet sound out of my PA. Perhaps I also have to change settings on the mixer also (Allen&Heath QU 16). But it ist difficult to change mixers EQ, beacause the keyboard-stereo-channel of the mixer includes the whole Nordstage, so organ, e-pianos, grandpianos an synthies. Changing the mixer EQ for e-pianos can sound good, but is not good for synthie or organ or grandpiano for example. So I would like to do as little as possible changes on the mixer EQ. Or should I seperate pianos and organ/synth to different channels? The same problem exists with the B3 sounds, to get it as close as much to a origin Hammond B3. The typical Jimmy Smith 8-8-8-0-0-0-0-0-0 sounds so flat for me, that I don't know how to get more brilliant, like the real B3.So I am open up for setting-ideas concerning EQ, compressor, dynamics, drive, amp-simulation an effects with nordstage-on-board-possibilities for the Rhodes, Wurlitzer and Clavinets... That means complete programs or complete written parameters of this features...
