title: RE: Synth
post_content: The synth is pretty easy to do, but the sound you are hearing is the side chaining of the entire track to the compression of the kick drum.  This is done in the mix and may be very tough to duplicate in the patch itself-I will take a look--dj

title: RE: Synth
post_content: perhaps with a control pedal mapped to — inversely — morph the volume? So that when you tap down on the beat, the volume goes down, and as you pull back on the offbeat, the volume goes back up?

title: RE: Synth
post_content: Yeah, I can tell you that works, but keeping it up for a whole track -even on something slower- proved quite tiring!The new Yamaha Montage has a side chain function on the compressor (obviously it has the necessary audio input too) and a promo video I watched gave exactly this example.I suppose if you were doing a lot of music needing this effect you could use an external compressor in your signal flow just taking a feed from the live kick, then bypassing the compressor when not needed. Personally, I resorted to putting the synth pad into a click track.

title: RE: Synth
post_content: Kayj_prod wrote:Yeah, I can tell you that works, but keeping it up for a whole track -even on something slower- proved quite tiring!I imagine.I wonder though: I have a Yamaha FC-7 expression pedal, and that has a spring with adjustable "bounce back" point. That might make it easier, if the band setup isn't wired for click tracks.I mean, there's always that "one piece" you hope won't be in the set, because it's hell on the keyboard player, right?

post_content: You can also do the "pumping" with aftertouch, at least with sustained chords.

title: RE: Rammstein - Ramm4
post_content: hmmm...1) it is very difficult to hear those sounds clearly in that cellphone video (too bad all those other people around you were making so much noise while you were recording -- you should have asked them all to be quiet), and2) if it is not very difficult to create them, then you should have no problems to do this yourself...?I'm not trying to be a jerk here (though perhaps I am succeeding), but the only thing that's really easy here is asking someone else to do this for you.  If you try to do it yourself you may learn some things about programming your instrument in the process.  Better to teach a hungry person to fish on their own (and feed themselves for a lifetime) than to give a hungry person a fish (and they'll be hungry again in four hours).Bless, Pablo

title: RE: Sexy Back - Justin Timberlake
post_content: Having mp3 files is good practice generally, but not required.  In the instance of simple programs (essentially sysex data) this becomes much less important.  When someone posts a 5MB sample file, it's rather a hassle to go through download, possibly have to clear space in the instrument to accommodate it, set up a program which uses it, making demo audio files more important.  Simple program files are, however, little teeny tiny affairs, take up almost no space, take virtually no time to download from internet to computer or from computer to instrument, and on NS2/NS2EX where factory load banks A and D are identical, it is easy to find an innocuous place to put it on your instrument for testing purposes.SajaPro, the question "do you have a sample mp3..." was intended for the person, Andreas Bek, not for you.

title: Ns2p on NORD STAGE 2ex
post_content: Hello, I want information, I have a former Nord Stage 2EX and when unloading the program from this site with ns2p size, the keyboard does not find me sounds.it's normal? how can you solve?

title: RE: Ns2p on NORD STAGE 2ex
post_content: It is difficult to understand your question, but...An .ns2p file will contain reference information as to what piano instruments are selected for Slots A&B, and possibly also contain reference info as to what samples are selected for Slots A&B (IF the OSC Type selected is Sample).  If your instrument does not contain these files, that will cause a problem.That's what BUNDLES are for.  With a BUNDLE, the program file comes with pianos and samples included.Bless,Pablo

title: Realistic Church organ sounds...
post_content: Dear all,I work in a school and we have recently purchased a Stage 2 and to say were impressed is an understatement.. However ! We use the Organ in our chapel services and from the default patches I'm struggling to find a full range church organ "sounding" patch.Most of the patches either sound like were at a baseball game or at the fair... Does anyone have or can point me to a genuine sounding church organ patch...Many thanks in advance!Matt

title: RE: Realistic Church organ sounds...
post_content: Two questions:1. are you referring to the included programs that use the Organ section of the instrument, or the organs that are included in the samples within the Synth section? There are a few impressive pipe organ samples in the Synth section, but they're bombastic all-stops type sounds.2. what types of organ are you trying to emulate? if you're going for a pipe organ with the ability to control stops or are you looking for more Gospel sounding electromechanical organ sounds? Fully-articulated pipe organ is going to be difficult, but not impossible, to accomplish on this since you'll need to utilize the sample functionality and probably delve into the world of making samples.  However, the latter will work perfectly if what you want to do is emulate a classic B-3 Gospel sound.

title: RE: Realistic Church organ sounds...
post_content: Hi Bods...thanks for your in depth reply. I'm sort of referreing to both, basically we p[urchased the keyboard for its ability to act as both an organ (emuklating a pipe organ) and as a stage piano. We have been using some of the built in organ sounds but theyre just ont quite close enough to a pipe organ and i was wondring if anyone has created some organ programmes?I downloaded the samples from the link below but am pretty new to the stage 2 and havent quite worked out how to create programmes from samples yet and kid of figured someone else would have done so ?http://www.norduserforum.com/post7223.html?hilit=churchorgan#p7223Is it fairly straight forward to creat programmes from samples as they manual is a little cryptic...Many thanksMatt aka Lutonbod

title: RE: Realistic Church organ sounds...
post_content: It's very simple to make programs with samples in them - what you want to do is turn off the organ and piano sections and enable just the synth section.  Then hold the shift key and tap "Sound Init" in the synth section.  Then, tap the oscillator selection button until the arrow is lit next to SAMP.  Then, use the knob in the oscillator section to find the sample you want to play.  That's it.  Then, you can save the program by tapping the red save button twice (assuming memory protection is turned off), or if you don't want to overwrite the spot you're in, hit shift-save, potentially change the name, then save again to choose a place to put it (and therefore overwrite the program you choose) and hit save again.  Alternately you can use one of the live spots to save it dynamically, no save buttons needed.This is all a bit from memory, so hopefully it doesn't vary much, if at all, from reality.  So to clarify what the Stage 2 does, it is really built to model the Hammond B-3 (and other transistor organs, but they're not what you're after) rather than a pipe organ.  The Hammond, of course, was originally built to emulate a pipe organ, but anyone who has played a pipe organ will know that's not really what they accomplished.  The Hammond has its own sound that is a cornerstone of jazz, rock and blues, and to a certain extent worship, but realistically the Hammond in a worship context is there to sound like the Hammonds of yesterday sounded where they were used to take the place of pipe organs.  I can't speak to Hammond in this context because I have virtually no experience with it, but if you search youtube for videos of people playing Hammond in a gospel context it may become a bit more clear what I'm talking about.The only board I know of that takes a stab at proper pipe organ is the C1/C2/C2D, which have a pipe organ model, but I'm not sure even how much closer this will get you to what you're looking for.

title: RE: Realistic Church organ sounds...
post_content: I really love my Nord, but there is one thing they missed by a mile on, and that's the pipe organ sounds.  I have the Electro 5D which has a dedicated pipe organ setting for the drawbars, but comparing it to a real pipe organ is like comparing Tang to orange juice.  It's like a gross parody that only bears a faint stereotyped resemblance to the real thing.The samples available also don't sound very good to my ears, and anyway being samples they aren't very flexible.I was however very surprised to discover how strikingly realistic the modeled pipe organ is on the Hammond SK-1.  I would not have thought it was possible to model so realistically (because I've never heard it done so accurately anywhere else), but that thing is fully modeled, meaning you can mix and match via the drawbars just like pulling stops on a real organ.  And the sound... I do a double-take every time!Nord does such a great job with so many other sounds, for example Nord's harpsichords are clearly better than their Hammond counterparts, and Nord's EPs (Rhodes, Wurli) are unsurpassed to my ears.  But the pipe organ just plain stinks on my Electro 5D, which I assume is similar to the Stage (I have not tried anything in the C2 line, so can't comment there).  I very much hope Nord will study the Hammond modeling, learn from it, and distribute a software patch one day!

post_content: Just wanted to bump this as I figured someone is probably covering this and has a sweet program.Any chance you would share?

title: RE: Dancing Queen - Abba
post_content: Which part(s) of the arrangement do you need? The main part is just - a piano. Any old piano with a bit of chorus should do the job fine, just add a bit of treble to brighten it up and you're good to go. Other than that, there is a full string section arrangement, but you're not likely to be able to play all that at the same time, you'll probably have to settle for layering an orchestral string sample or two over the top and using a foot pedal to bring it in and out while playing some of the most important lines when necessary.

title: RE: Jupiter 80 sound
post_content: Hi,You connect the nord via USB to a computer and use the "Nord Sound Manager" software, that is available as a download on Nord's webiste.Then you upload the program, using that software, from your keyboard to the computer.You'll get a file, named after your program's name, and ending with the "ns2p" extension.This file you upload here on the forum, using the "Full Editor" button that is next to the "Submit" button when you post a message, it gives you access to file upload.Let's face it ... NS2 vs Jupiter80 :NS21 program has 2 synth sectioneach synth section has 1 oscillator, unison modes (multi is nice) and knobs on the panel.Jupiter 801 Program (is called a LiveSet) can have 4 sounds (including percussion, called "Tones"), a synth tone has 3 oscillators (called partials).Effects have to be considered as well.The "fight"is more balanced than specs may suggest 'coz of Nord's ability to summurize things.Jupiter 80 can selection PCM (samples) waveforms for each oscillator.NS2, we can use samples (form Nord Sample Library), an layer organ / piano (with effects and "uncommon" settings).You're right, this sound is sweet.Also Cory Henry is a great board player imho.Cheers,F.

title: The Killers "somebody told me" synth
post_content: Hi everyone, does anyone know how I could create the lead synth that we hear in the intro of this song and at the end of the 1st chorus "1min18"? I have a gig this saturday and it will be so dope if I could have the good sounds for that. I really appreciate your help. Thanks guys.

title: RE: The Killers "somebody told me" synth
post_content: The original sound is a preset on the Microkorg (I forget which one). The Microkorg has a very distinctive bright hard metallic sound which can be difficult to reproduce.Set up up a two oscillator sawtooth (unison pitch) patch with a little detune and use the Unison function to thicken the sound up.Set the amp envelope to the fastest attack and add just a touch of release.Close the filter down somewhat and then use the filter envelope with a fast attack and slower decay to get the filter sweep.Next you'll need to set the voice mode to Mono or Legato (whichever works best) and then add a little glide.Depending on how that all works out, you might need to add a little upper mid or treble to the sound if it's not quite bright or hard enough.

title: Snapping Fingers Sound
post_content: Does a program exist for "snapping fingers" for use on NS2 - ?  If no, has anyone successfully created one using the synth section?I looked through the Nord Sample Collection, but could not find one.  Our band is playing "Fever", so this sound/patch/program would be valuable.  My hands hurt after snapping for 5 - 6 measures.

title: RE: Snapping Fingers Sound
post_content: You can create one yourself, find a .wav of finger snapping (or record your own! Or the original one from the record...) then use the Nord Sound Manager (correction Editor!) to create a .nsmp using that sample (remember to set the sample Play Mode =  Unpitched, as explained in the Nord Sound Editor manua)

title: RE: Snapping Fingers Sound
post_content: maxpiano wrote:You can create one yourself, find a .wav of finger snapping (or record your own! Or the original one from the record...) then use the Nord Sound Manager to create a .nsmp using that sample (remember to set the sample Play Mode =  Unpitched, as explained in the Nord Sound Editor manua)Absolutely,  Put a mic on a stand press record, and snap your fingers.  You might do several and then mix them together with slightly different start points to get the feel of having the whole band doing that at once.One slight correction, though...Nord Sample Editor is used to create the .nsmp,, not Nord Sound Manager.Bless,Pablo

title: RE: Snapping Fingers Sound
post_content: Well, using Sample Editor, I recorded one finger snap, and somehow Forrest Gumped my way to making a very usable sample.  I must say, if you open Sample Editor for the first time and have just two hours before rehearsal to create one, it can blow one's mind!  However, the user manual got me started, but it sure is a techy read.The final product ended up multi-timbral, and chromatic - a different tone for each of the 73 pressed keys.  Kind of cool, actually!  Not quite sure how I did it, but voilà.  And, very economical at only 392kb.Will post the sound tomorrow night when I get home from another rehearsal.  One good thing about being a keyboard player, you're always in demand.  There's a zillion good guitarists and drummers out there.  Then, there are the bass players...

title: Cars: Let's Go, Just What I Needed
post_content: Here are a couple more patches which can be used for the Cars tunes.Let's Go has the "talking" synth on the lower split and the string part for the verse on the upper.Just What I Needed (Cars Synth) is a split also.  The distorted sound can be used when playing with another guitar for the stabs, it blends pretty well.  The upper split is the synth riff sound.  The first synth sound is played with the mod wheel closed. Open it up halfway, and the sound will hollow out for the second synth sound used in the rest of the song.Starting points as always, improvements welcomed!-dj

title: RE: Cars: Let's Go, Just What I Needed
post_content: OK, thanks, this is due to the Mod Envelope affecting the filter. I don't think I set the LFO to do anything, but it was a while ago.It is subtle and I like that effect, but if you don't, just turn off the Mod to 0 in the filter section:Mod.jpg (87.82 KiB) Viewed 5216 times

title: RE: Cars: Let's Go, Just What I Needed
post_content: DJ - LFO is set to 0 and it still does it.  at 0:09 in the mp3 you hear it switch from the more muted sound to the more attacky sound.  this is the change in sound I am talking about.  Sorry for all the trouble - just can't seem to figure this one out.

title: RE: Cars: Let's Go, Just What I Needed
post_content: Not the LFO, the MOD in Freq Mod 2 (highlighted in red above).  Make sure that control is at 0, then adjust the filter for the sound you want.I will have to look into it at home on my machine.  May take a couple of days for me to get to it though.I will let you know what I find out.

title: RE: Cars: Let's Go, Just What I Needed
post_content: Sorry - that's what I meant - that knob is at 0.

title: RE: Cars: Let's Go, Just What I Needed
post_content: OK, I will check it out.  Get back to you later on this.-dj

title: RE: Cars: Let's Go, Just What I Needed
post_content: I just had a chance to investigate this.  It turns out there was a very slow LFO modulation of the Filter Cutoff, so it took a long time, but you could hear it abruptly lose high end. You have to look at the values in the display to make sure they are set to 0, as just looking at the position of the knob was not sufficient. I programmed this patch pretty quickly.I changed this and saved a new patch.Try it out and let me know it works.

title: RE: Synth solo sound
post_content: I found an interview with Tim Carmon -SS: What's your current stage set-up like? And how exactly do you get that synth sound on your "Old Love" solo?TC: My current stage set-up is Organ, Rhodes, Yamaha Motif 6 and Nord Lead. The synth sound is made by 2 sounds programmed by Dave Delhomme (on the Crossroads DVD) through a wah-wah pedal. Eric mentioned the reason for doing the song was because he wanted to hear the synth solo.- Ted

post_content: Arpeggio types are fixed on NS2 (up, down, up-down, random), any other type can only be accomplished using an external MIDI arpeggiator device (HW or PC with SW)

title: RE: help lead synth
post_content: Buongiorno,For me it's a saw waveform, a low pass 24 db/oct filter between 50-90 Hz, some unison (1+multi quite often).I'd have to try for other settings, to shape the sound attack with modulation envelope, and chose the mono/legato mode properly.Frantz.

title: RE: "Relax" Frankie goes to Hollywood
post_content: That song was built by Trevor Horn mostly on a Fairlight. The drums are LinnDrum, and the pads and brass are probably a Roland Jupiter 8.The "BOW BOW BOW" bass is quite possibly a PPG Waveterm.There's probably a number of custom samples, but much of what you need, you should be able to find in here:Fairlight:http://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-libr ... ht-historyJupiter 8:http://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-libr ... -jupiter-8PPG Wave:http://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-libr ... s/ppg-waveNo idea what sample is called that could be used for the BOW BOW BOW bass, but the second one in the demo (from 0:09) sounds like it could be a dead ringer if taken down two or three octaves.

title: Set list maker and NS2
post_content: Hello everyone!I 've used this app in the past to send program change messages to ny NE3, my NW, my Roland RD-300sx and everything was OK.I can't get to do the same on my NS2.Everything seems to be set OK but it won't work.On the NS2:OS latest v 2.10MIDI Global is set to "USB1"Midi Program Change is set to "receive"There is a USB cable connecting the keyboard to the iPad through the camera connection adaptor.On the iPad:Latest iOS9 and latest Set List Maker updateIn the MIDI Device menu NS2 is added and "All Ports", "Channel 1" and "Active" are setIn the Automation menu "Send MIDI" is enabledMy set list is ready and the MIDI presets are set by the rules (MSB blank, LSB 0-3 for banks A-D and program 0-99)The MIDI presets are connected to the songs.The result: NEGATIVE!Is anyone able to help me?I didn't sleep last night trying to fix it...

title: RE: Set list maker and NS2
post_content: You have to update to iOS Version 4.2.1SLM iOS Version 4.2 has a problem with "MIDI presets that caused program changes to be sent on the wrong channel". Details seehttp://www.arlomedia.com/apps/setlistma ... notes.html

title: RE: Set list maker and NS2
post_content: U N B E L I E V A B L E ! ! ! ! ! !Thanks man!!!!There is a bug that will be fixed in the next few days.By mistake, the SLM is transmitting the program change message to the next channel of what is set in the keyboard.Eg. if you set the iPad to send to channel 1, you have to set the keyboard to channel 2 and it is working!!!!!I can't believe I 've lost so many hours on that.I should have read Arlo's forum earlier.Thanks for the tip Merlimau!

title: RE: Set list maker and NS2

title: RE: Set list maker and NS2
post_content: Hello Keith Bowie,I 've used this app with the following rigsNE3+NWNE3+RD300SXNS2 (my current live board)In the RD300SX manual (you own a different RD300 version, but it is possible that it's the same over there) there is a chapter titled "selecting sounds from an external midi device".In my version of the board, you have to set the 32 "setups" (this is the word that is used by Roland instead of "program") and then set the midi presets in the app like this: MSB=85, LSB=0, Program=1-32 (depending on the setup you wish to recall).Look into your Roland manual and it's gonna be there.

title: RE: Set list maker and NS2
post_content: I've been using SLM for a couple of years now and would be lost without it. We're a covers band and very few songs use the same preset so D bank is now full and I'm happily chewing into C bank. If I had to whizz through that little lot to find the next song my band mates would rapidly get very annoyed. One tap and I'm good to go. Better still, I've rigged up an Airturn footswitch which connects to SLM via Bluetooth (bit temperamental sometimes and often needs talking to sweetly or firmly, depending on stress levels, to get it to work) and that allows for very rapid and secure programme changes, even within a song. The Nord buttons aren't that big and tend to shrink in the heat of gig battle, so a large chunky footswitch is a far safer option.A breeze to copy the setlist to the next show and edit as required, very customisable, and syncs effortlessly between devices. Wouldn't recommend syncing with other band members, however, as that customisation is different from player to player and I managed to wipe all the singer's lyrics once, which made me very popular.In short: couldn't live without SLM and can't recommend it highly enough.

title: nspg vs ns2p
post_content: Can I use nspg samples on my ns2 piano ?

title: RE: nspg vs ns2p
post_content: .nspg are not samples, they are NordStageProGrams (for Nord Stage Classic/EX).You can find the explanation of all Nord Sound Manager file extensions in its manual.

title: RE: nspg vs ns2p
post_content: I have discovered the following :-How can I transfer my programs for the Nord Stage Classic or EX to my new Nord Stage 2?Unfortunately, there is no way of converting your programs, and never will be. While for organ and piano based sounds, it seems pretty straightforward to creadte your nes programs for the NS2, it might be more difficult for Synth patches.One way of converting it is getting all the values in particular of the Synth section and than reprogramming it from scratch on the NS2. To get all values, you can use  the Nord Stage CTRLR Editor software to see it on your computer (downloads.php?cat=7). Start the software, load the patch you want to recreate on your NS Classic/EX, and do a dump (explained in this post:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-stage ... html#p8381) Then you can set the NS2 to those values and should get very close to the original sound.To share or take notes of patch (in particular, Synth) settings, you can also use this patch sheet:  nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files-f15/reo-ridin-the-storm-out-t2389.html#p13499

title: RE: nspg vs ns2p
post_content: Exactly

title: samples nsmp on Nord site, need .ns2p*
post_content: quick question i hope - probably dumb one..have NS2 O/S 2.10 and trying to download some new program samples from Nord site.  I select the compatible ones for ns2 but upon downloading them - they come in as nsmp and won't go in to my sound manager.i'm just having a brain you-kno-what, right? please help.  thanks.

title: RE: samples nsmp on Nord site, need .ns2p*
post_content: "program samples" is a contradiction in terms, either they are programs or samples.  The Nord site does not contain programs except as internal component parts of backup files.  It is SAMPLES you are downloading.  NS2 programs use file extension .ns2p.  Samples use file extension .nsmp.  Programs are loaded to PROGRAM tab.  Samples are loaded to SAMPLE tab.  If you first select SAMPLE tab your samples will load.bless,pablo

title: RE: samples nsmp on Nord site, need .ns2p*
post_content: Note that you then need to create an empty program on the Nord stage that uses that sample for the synth.

title: RE: samples nsmp on Nord site, need .ns2p*
post_content: yes...this is a 2-step process:1) install sample on instrument2) create program which uses (selects) the sample which you've just loadedpablo

title: RE: Song medley with genius keyboard sounds
post_content: Most of the warm, thick sounding leads you have posted are just variations of the same type of plain minimoog-style sawtooth waves, with a 24dB filter with slow attack and low resonance, and some portamento. I'd assign pitch modulation to aftertouch or use the stick.The hollow-sounding leads are square waves.The organs... well yecch. I dunno. You could probably use one of the organ samples from an M1 or so if you really want that warbly plastic sound. It'll be difficult using the nord organ engine, as that actually sounds like a Hammond and 80s jazz-rock/fusion decidedly did not.

post_content: The "Garden Party" one does, yes."Sizzle" sounds like standard sawtooth with a 12 dB or 18 dB filter on it.So does "Waves" — though that might be a regular 24 dB filter.

title: RE: Song medley with genius keyboard sounds
post_content: Hello!Here's a program that I use for the synth in Stuck on you by Lionel Richie.I know it's not perfect but it does the job for me, if you have any suggestions on how to improve it, please let me knowwhat I did was use  Sine FM (1-OP), with a LP12 1.5kHz frequency and Osc shape at around 3.7.I made the mode legato with a glide somewhere between 1-2, and set the vibrato on wheel.I thought I have the release at around 3-4, and attack around 2, with full decay. And finished it with a bit of reverb.Hope that helps!Greetings,NilsStuck on you.mp3

title: RE: Format
post_content: You are confusing Programs (.ns2p) with Bundles (.ns2pb), ensure you select the Program tab and Program Upload in the Nord Sound Manager (for any doubt, please check the NSM manual about the difference between Programs and Bundles)

title: Memphis Horns
post_content: I've been gigging with my NS2  about three years now, playing in a covers band (60s, 70s, 80s etc) using many different sounds.But now the pressure is on. Just starting a new venture playing mainly Stax soul (a la Commitments). But I have to provide an authentic brass/horn section on my own - we can't afford the real thing (too many mouths to feed).I'm aware of the limitations of trying to emulate these instruments on a keyboard, but just wondering if anyone has any suggestions.Can it be done? Is the NS2 the best place to start (in which case, grateful for any particular suggestions - other than 'try Nord Sample Library') - or should I be looking at another keyboard altogether?Many thanks if you are able to offer any advice.

title: RE: Memphis Horns
post_content: I use Kontakt horns and Sampletank3 horns in sections mapped over different parts of the keyboard - works ok. Threw in some of the horn sections from the Nord Library as well.I find the trick is not so much what sounds you use as it is what you are playing. Sometimes hard to think like a horn section from the keyboard. The beauty of a tight, well arranged horn section is how they blend and move together - the parts are always in motion.For example back in the day I spent a lot of time on Spinning Wheels, getting the parts as close as I could. Pulled off a reasonable facismile with just a D50 and an M1. I had a bari sax mapped on just the bottom octave to give it some bite.It's worth spending most of your effort in picking out the harmonies and lines each instrument is playing.Just my $0.02 CDN.DH

title: RE: Memphis Horns
post_content: Thanks for the info and suggestions.Could explain where the Kontakt horns and Sampletank 3 horns come from - i.e. where can I find them?Cheers

title: RE: Memphis Horns
post_content: have you tried googling KONTAKT and/or SAMPLETANK?

title: RE: Memphis Horns
post_content: Try the NS2 samples/programs for Bari/Horns or in general Brass sounds first, despite not being the top as far as realism is concerned (particularly of compared to VSTi instruments) they may be suprisingly effective in the music context you are going to playOf course you need not just to take the Nord Samples "as is" but work with EQ and other effects to make them the way you like; check also the NS2 Programs section of this forum for some nice Brass programs.

title: RE: Memphis Horns
post_content: Would I be correct in saying KONTAKT and SAMPLETANK are only useful if you're hooked up to a PC/laptop?I was looking for sounds I can use at a live gig, with just the NS2.Thanks for the help.

title: RE: Memphis Horns
post_content: I think Hanon's brass spike (think that's what it's called), which is floating around on here somewhere, does a decent job. I recommend using both patch A and B and doubling the horns up, one patch an octave below the other.

title: RE: Memphis Horns
post_content: http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-user- ... t2250.htmlBoth patch A and B, one patch an octave below. Works for me anyway!

title: RE: Memphis Horns
post_content: Thanks for all the advice.Could I go one step further and ask if anyone has anything that comes close to the hard 'raspy' solo sax sound such as used for solos in Treat Her Right (George Thorogood) or Land of 1000 Dances (Wilson Picket)?A bit like the sax solos in the old Duane Eddy numbers (if anyone goes back as far as me!)I've tried downloading quite a few from the sample library (and deleted them again just as quickly), so just hoping someone might have some suggestions. Very grateful.

title: RE: Memphis Horns
post_content: Reading again your first post and then the lst one, I think that if you are after good and realistic emulation of acoustic sounds, with all the nuances and articulations, the NS2 is not the best keyboard at that simply because its Synth is not designed for handling multilayer samples and applying complex modulations to them (which is what you need to emulate acoustic sounds)I would suggest you add another keyboard (or module) to your setup (such as a Motif, for example) or use a PC with good sample libraries (in case of PC or module you will control and play it via the Extern section of the NS2)

title: RE: Memphis Horns
post_content: I found my 20 year old Roland SC-88 midi module in the garage.  Those old Roland midi brass sounds are very, very good, as are many other wind instruments and guitar sounds.  I'm going to figure out how to hook it up today and see if it will provide the brass tones you are describing.

title: RE: Memphis Horns
post_content: Hi,+1 on old stuff. When I was taking harmony courses 30 years ago, we were using the brass sounds of the first Emu Proteus 1 to see how it could sound in real.....that's why I bought a Proteus 2000 loaded with 4 extra Rom and with the XV5080 Roland and the Stage 2, I never complain about realism for Brass band section in a live setting...We play Sledgehammer/Peter Gabriel and Run for Vover, Marcus Miller/David Sandborn and it works very well.my only complain is when you have very jazzy trumpet or sax solo....you really need to work on the wheel, aftertouch and pitchbend at the same time and then, you cannot comp with chords on organ or piano at the same time....other than that, there a lot of good stuff in the old 80s/90s expanders....and they are very cheap....

title: Very small Church (Pipe) Organ
post_content: I adapted a little bit the very simple Organ Flute program (factory program C 15:5 with factory sample 22) and added a 4 feet flute sample which I converted from a small public available organ of the Hauptwerk-Church Organ system. This new sample calledMiniorgan4fussis loaded into slot B with sample # 16 and the volume of B  is controlled via the control pedal. I use it to study at home some songs which I then play on a real pipe organ in our church. To use it on Your NS 2 load the sample to any location and the program to any location, change the sample #16 to the position where You loaded the new sample, store the program and give it a try. I made a MP3 sample which begins with the (high) 4 foot sample, changes to the factory organ sample an then plays both together. I can imagine better sounding samples - both are not masterpieces especially for longer hold notes. For that I need some more training with the sample editor. The german word Doppelorgel means Double Organ and 4Fuss means 4foot. title: Maroon 5 - Sugar, MKTO - Classic, Ariana Grande - Break Free
post_content: Hey!I'm looking for patches for the following songs. Alternatively, I would be also thankful for any tips on how to create these sounds.Maroon 5 - Sugar (subdued type of synthorgan? sound)MKTO - Classic (intro: plucking synth, verse/chorus: pad/mellotron? + synth lead)Ariana Grande - Break Free (pad/mellotron? + power synth?)Appreciating your help!

title: RE: Maroon 5 - Sugar, MKTO - Classic, Ariana Grande - Break Free
post_content: For the Maroon 5 organ, I would use the synth section, rather than the organ. Why? you have the benefit of the filter (LPF), which you are going to need.Try setting the synth type to WAVE and choose one of the first few waveforms in the list which are organs. Then set the Filter Type to LP12 and turn the Frequency knob down to 10'oclock. That's your starting point - you should be able to nail it if you play around form there.

title: RE: Maroon 5 - Sugar, MKTO - Classic, Ariana Grande - Break Free

title: Twenty One Pilots - 'Holding On To You' sound
post_content: Heya folks!This is my first post on this forum, so I really have no idea what I'm doing - but from what I've seen, this looks like a really helpful place.I just got my Nord Stage 2 four days ago, and I'm in love with it!Anywho, thought I would share this program with ya'll that I made for Twenty One Pilot's song "Holding On to You."Recommended way to play:Slot A:- Play right hand chord on counts 1 and 3, letting the delay fill in the hits on 2 and 4.  Play the left hand bass note once.- Move Mod Wheel up for "La la la la la la" part to introduce synth and light organ.Slot B:- Select Slot B at the bridge to introduce upright piano.- Select both Slots for build [with Mod Wheel down]I hope you guys enjoy!  Please feel free to give feedback; I'm new to this whole thing(Also if someone would like to enlighten me on how to add the "MP3 Preview" to these posts, it'd be much appreciated.

Download the Zip-file, unzip it and You can download the samples with the newest version of the Nord Sample manager to Your Keyboard.Wolfgang

title: RE: Looking for a nice Jazz skat roland like sound
post_content: Hi search the forum. Somebody posted dooh and the dah samples in the past. You can import them as single layer nsmp files  (I think the dah one is just the wav file, so you need to construct the nsmp). Unfortunately the NS2 cannot switch/morph samples with velocity but perhaps single layer does the trick for you.

title: RE: Looking for a nice Jazz skat roland like sound
post_content: See here:http://www.norduserforum.com/post47922.html

title: RE: Looking for a nice Jazz skat roland like sound
post_content: Velocity layer support is not something that can be added to the current architecture via a future software update.It will have to wait until the Nord Stage 3 (and really, it needs to come — it's the one major aspect nord is really, really lacking).

title: Problem with ns2p file!!
post_content: Goodmorning everyone! And sorry for my bad english... I can not upload files .ns2p  in Nord Stage 2..only .nsmp...why..?!? How can I do..??

title: RE: Problem with ns2p file!!
post_content: Welcome to the forum (and do not worry your English is fine).Perhaps you need to delete some program before giving space to the new ones? Bank A and D are duplicated so you could delete, let's say, bank D and put new sounds in there.

title: RE: Problem with ns2p file!!
post_content: Thank You..!! I try..!!

title: RE: Problem with ns2p file!!
post_content: Ah..! Where they loaded this type of file? what is the section??

title: RE: Problem with ns2p file!!
post_content: Damiano wrote:Ah..! Where they loaded this type of file? what is the section??.ns2p is a program. You need to make a note of which bank (A,B,C,D) and which program number it is saved in when you copy it onto the NS2 using Sound Manager..nsmp are samples and accessed via the Synth > Sample.A program can include samples. The way to think of it is a program (.ns2p file) contains the sounds, all effects, settings - everything ready to perform. The sample ( .nsmp) is just the raw ingredient sampled sound that you use in a program.Oh, and welcome!!

title: RE: Problem with ns2p file!!
post_content: Thank you!!so...if you want to insert, for example,  a sound of thriller synth  downloaded from the forum format .ns2p .. what should I do ? can you tell me an example..?

title: RE: Problem with ns2p file!!
post_content: This will tell you everything you need to know :http://www.nordkeyboards.com/sites/defa ... on%20A.pdf

title: RE: Problem with ns2p file!!
post_content: Hi Damiano,And welcome!First, turn OFF Memory Protect in System Menu.  Connect instrument via USB to computer running Nord Sound Manager.  Pick a program which you do not like and DELETE it.  It will disappear from the list without leaving a trace of the empty space.  Enable ORGANIZE icon and you will see the empty space.  Drag and drop the downloaded program to that spot.  Done dealBless,Pablo

title: Filter piano on The Beatles "Birthday"
post_content: Can anyone show me how to whip up a patch for the filtered piano on 'Birthday' by the Beatles? Probably have to use the synth side and load a piano sample, then you can apply the filter. But I can't match the sound on the record.

title: RE: Filter piano on The Beatles "Birthday"
post_content: Probably do-able with just FX processing - try using the HonkeyTonk upright from the Nord piano library, then use some FX: Flange, also probably Delay. Turn on the Amp Sim and turn the treble down on the EQ, and some Reverb for good measure. Any good?

title: RE: Filter piano on The Beatles "Birthday"
post_content: I use Honky tonk piano with a bit of flanger and eq (don't remember the settings right now).Sounds quite close to the record, and it's easy to do.(and don't forget the organ part for the chorus!!!)

title: RE: Filter piano on The Beatles "Birthday"
post_content: I did some Googling to find out how the Beatles made the original recording. Apparently they ran a mic'd up piano through a Vox Conqueror or Vox Defiant. Both models have a 3-position midrange booster knob -- this is the magic. The knob was moved between the 3 positions to get that sound.  Here's a guy who recreates Beatles songs with the original gear (or close to it):You'll see the amp & hear the sound at 1:26. I'm still not getting close to this exact sound...

title: RE: Filter piano on The Beatles "Birthday"
post_content: keyman27 wrote:...Apparently they ran a mic'd up piano through a Vox Conqueror or Vox Defiant. Both models have a 3-position midrange booster knob -- this is the magic...interesting bit of music history - thanks for the link

title: RE: Filter piano on The Beatles "Birthday"

Both models have a 3-position midrange booster knob -- this is the magic. The knob was moved between the 3 positions to get that sound.  Here's a guy who recreates Beatles songs with the original gear (or close to it):You'll see the amp & hear the sound at 1:26. I'm still not getting close to this exact sound...That's pretty awesome, and almost impossible to duplicate.Hm. Amp simulator, yep. A bit of wah, controlled by a pedal, perhaps?

title: RE: Filter piano on The Beatles "Birthday"
post_content: Yes, I think wah on the expression pedal is the best bet. It comes close!

title: Sad Lisa (Cat Stevens) - Piano Sound

title: RE: Sad Lisa (Cat Stevens) - Piano Sound
post_content: Once you've got the basic piano sound, duplicate that into the second slot.On that second slot, add the rotary (Leslie) speaker effect to the piano.Use morph via pedal or wheel to fade the clean signal a bit, while adding the Leslie piano.Add quite a bit of compressor.

title: RE: Sad Lisa (Cat Stevens) - Piano Sound

title: RE: Sad Lisa (Cat Stevens) - Piano Sound
post_content: You could try doing exactly what I wrote above, but using a pretty strong chorus (and fairly fast - maybe 5-10 Hz or so). It won't be *exactly* that, but it could probably get fairly close.

post_content: Klangwerk wrote:Hi Spike,sorry, but I really don´t know how to do it.How can I upload it in Mp3 format?I´m sorry, maybe I´m the only one who doesn´t know it.HelmuthUploading MP3s is as easy as uploading the sample itself. Just record a short sequence using your NS2 and save it as MP3. Then upload it and click on the "Place Inline" button and voilá! It is a bit of work since you have to record your NS2 etc.. If you think it is too complicated, a second best solution would be to just take the WAVE file you were using and then convert it into MP3 and then upload this single note. Let me know if you have any further questions.

title: RE: syndrum sound
post_content: That kind of sound can be made by setting the resonance of the LPF to a maximum (where it oscillates) and then using the modulation EG to drive the closing of the filter.

title: RE: syndrum sound
post_content: There you have an example of what I meant. You control the pitch decay with a combination of the "Decay" (in the  "Mod. Env." section)   and the "Mod. Env." (in the "Filter" section).By activating "Kb-Track" you have a different pitch in each key.Syndrum.ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 410 times

title: Britney Spears - Toxic
post_content: I really need your help on this one, guys!I'll be performing "Toxic" with my band next weekend, but I can't wrap my head around, how to create a descent patch.Do you have any suggestions, advice, experiences?? All help will be appreciated

title: RE: Britney Spears - Toxic
post_content: I think the original song is mostly done with samples, so I think your best option is to do the same and use the song as a source.As for the synth sounds:* the fat bass that kicks in with the verse "Baby can't you see - i'm calling..."  I think trying to make a bass like this on the NS2 would be disappointing... (maybe it was originally done on a BassStation?)* The Synth that comes in at the break (around 0:55 - thanks for making me watch the video btwshould be possible with a SAW OSC, HPF and maybe amp drive.* The 'Prodigy*' style sound around 2:37 is probably beyond the NS2... you mention other brands in your profile - do you have a MiniBrute by chance?there's a lot of sounds in this song, so covering them all with a NS2 in a live performance may be a challenge! Maybe better off just using some strings on slot A and create a multi-sample for slot B with some 1-shot samples, triggered in a range of the keyboard you don't need for the main strings... might work.In short, I don't think the NS2 is the best tool for this job! (Before I get flamed - I love the NS2, but it does have its limits!)* I mean 'The Prodigy' as in the band, not the Moog with the same name - a very different sound indeed

title: Drum loops to have basic rhythms to play along on the NS2
post_content: FINALLY!  After multiple attempts at trying to be too ambitious, I have simplified my strategy -- sorry, but I'm new at this upload posting thing.Here are three samples of loopy drum things together with three associated programs for their use.Please understand that these are intended only as crude examples of what is possible.  The live drum samples were lifted from gig recordings and are not production quality for technical reasons, mostly monitor bleed into drum mics.Comments gratefully appreciated...old 1DrpSteppers.ns2pon my SW73, the high Eb triggers root note one drop sample.  high Ab (below the Eb) that triggers root note of steppers sample.  Mod wheel crossfades bass and organ in middle zone.  control pedal drives delay amount on both pianos.(547 Bytes) Downloaded 489 timesstep one drop.nsmp(4.24 MiB) Downloaded 791 timesclean 1 drop.mp3clean step.mp3Fat Mix B 1 Drop.ns2phigh Ab triggers root note of one drop sample.  high Eb (above the Ab) triggers root note of "riddimwise" version of same one drop sample (no kick).(547 Bytes) Downloaded 462 timesdamn.nsmpconsidering how long this loop is, doesn't really take up too much space -- roughly same as average Mellotron sample(5.67 MiB) Downloaded 770 timesdirty drop.mp3dirty riddimwise.mp3Deadweight.ns2phigh Eb triggers root note of sampled loop.  loop written as G1 sequence, then recorded live with some PW modulation of square LFO on filter in bars 9-12 of 12-bar pattern -- keeps things a little less boring when working in 16-bar song structure(547 Bytes) Downloaded 449 timesdead loop.nsmp(525.04 KiB) Downloaded 742 timesdeadweight.mp3

title: RE: Drum loops to have basic rhythms to play along on the NS2
post_content: Great samples and programs! Excellent loop points, very intuitive to play and jam along the great beat loops!I have still the idea to create a large set of drum loops, say, 12 different styles, each assigned to a key of an octave, and then have it at different speeds in 10bpm steps over the full range of the keybed. This way, you would basically obtain a full set of rythm accompagniements like on any workstation, availably easily via one slot in one sample file.Only problem is where to get the beats from - while using a VSTi such as GrooveAgent would be very easy, it would not allow to share it due to license restrictions, and I did not yet find freely available high quality samples to create this sample, but I reckon it could be useful to many, just to have a simple way of playing along some standard beats without external hard- or software. Maybe Nord want to release something like this one day?Anyways, kudos Pablo for these inspiring patches!!Maybe something like thishttp://www.vst4free.com/index.php?plug-ins=Drumkitscould also be used...

post_content: There's a song I haven't heard in a whileFor what it's worth: I found a live clip and I see a Moog Prodigy and what looks like two Prophet 5's. title: Elenor Rigby Strings
post_content: Hey!Do you possibly have a NS2-program for a good allround and fat string sound, suited for Elenor Rigby (Beatles)?Thanks!

title: RE: Elenor Rigby Strings
post_content: There's a lot of complex strings in that song - solo Violin, solo Cello, quartet/ensemble not to mention different expression: stacatto, legato, even pizzicato maybe.So it may be a challenge to find one patch that will cover all this with only two synth slots, although you could probably go a fair way with clever use of multisampling (e.g. cello at low end, violin at high and quartet in the middle, and different velocities for stacatto vs legato bowing).Having said all that, the Beatles were using the Mellotron around the time this was recorded AFAIK, so you may find exactly the samples you need on the Nord site...

title: RE: Elenor Rigby Strings
post_content: I'm pretty sure that there's a real string quartet on Eleanor Rigby and not a mellotron.But to answer the op, I think the string samples in the sound library are really good and playable, especially the OrchStrings SustVib sample. You can download it here:http://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-libr ... ic-stringsGood luck!

title: RE: Elenor Rigby Strings
post_content: I'm pretty sure that there's a real string quartet on Eleanor Rigby and not a mellotron.Yep - I totally agree - I hadn't actually listened to it recently when I replied to the OP, I was replaying it in my head- my bad.After a quick google I found a funny piece of trivia though: the original cellist on Eleanor Rigby was Reginald Kirby, and it was him (and his cello) that were recorded for the cello sounds in the Mellotron (400), so it turns out the sounds on the mellotron practically came from that song, not the other way around

title: 'organ / lead'-sound from Faith Evans Mesmerized
post_content: Hi there, anyone who could help me on this punch organ like sound which is heard all trough this song (The double F-note you hear in second 1, second 5 etc.)?Many thanks!Steven

title: RE: 'organ / lead'-sound from Faith Evans Mesmerized
post_content: Sorry, just realised it is a simple sawtooth...I didn't get that spacey effect on it, but it will work in the mix.There is a sequence at 13 seconds, sort of Arpegg going up. I don't think this is possible with the Stage 2 (except for sampling/playback). If anyone has an idea on this, most welcome!Thx.,Steven

title: RE: 'organ / lead'-sound from Faith Evans Mesmerized
post_content: Those 2 notes are a just a square wave.That scale up sounds more like a saw wave and seems to be Eb F Bb C repeated over 4 octaves.You can create the sequence by holding those 4 notes and set the arpeggiator up with a range of 4 (both leds on).But it might be tricky to do live unless you synchronise to a click track.Edit: actually if you set the Master Clock On to 1/16 and keep tapping the tempo live just until the sequence (about 126 bpm or so), then press that 4 note chord and that might be it.you might have to hit the chord carefully to make sure the sequence is played in the correct order.Really, the NS2 would benefit from a connector to enable tapping the tempo with a foot pedal/switch and free one hand.

title: RE: 'organ / lead'-sound from Faith Evans Mesmerized
post_content: Hi Mr. G.That is exactly what it is, but You're right, playing that Arpegg is almost impossible live. I solved it by sampling that loop. See files attached. I have the sequence starting when playing the lower d#, controlled by a controller pedal. That way it starts at the right time, but you can control when you here it or not. The square wave is on F0, allowing to sort of play everything without switching.Mesmerized.ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 309 timesmesmerized.mp3Sorry for the crappy recording, have to get some gear to record with my Macbookmesmerized.nwiproj(17.22 KiB) Downloaded 182 timesMesmerized.ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 309 times

title: RE: "who are you" intro sound
post_content: Nobody can help me??

title: RE: "who are you" intro sound
post_content: Sounds like stacked sawtooth waves to me (unison in Stage 2's synth section) with opening lowpass filter with some resonance (choose LP12 or LP24, twiddle resonance to your liking, probably around 4-7, experiment with Freq, Freq mod 2 to mod env and Mod envelopes attack and decay). Hope this helpsPs. If you want to get more deeply into synthesis, check these articles out:http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/allsynthsecrets.htm

title: RE: "who are you" intro sound
post_content: Thank you MrSitcom. Do you think i have to use some delay?

title: RE: "who are you" intro sound
post_content: No, in the record there's two takes, one panned fully right playing on beat and one panned fully left playing on beat. Either you can do a split and pan slot A to right with A-pan rate at 0 and amount at 10 and slot B at amount 0 and play them alternately, or just use A-pan with one synth slot and slave it to MST CLK and either tap the tempo or put it to 160ish.

title: Some Rhodes patches for those interested.
post_content: Chick Rhodes - has probably too much overdrive for many but I was going for his early 70s sound with this one… uses the Close Ideal Rhodes.Galper Rhodes - This one uses the Leslie effect as Hal Galper used it a lot on his early 70s fusion records.  Nice with pitch bend… try some arpegs and pitch bend now and again for a dreamy effect. Uses Close Ideal sample.Herbie Rhodes - Classic mid 70s sound… not quite there in the top end but still nice sounding for comping Uses the Low Deep Rhodes sampleDukey Rhodes - Based on his 1971 LP "Inner Source"… nice old Rhodes sound… maybe I should have put wah on it for more authenticity.  Uses Vintage 67 Rhodes sample.Enjoy.

title: Jaw Harp - Juice Harp
post_content: Well, I started putting together this program for a post looking for a jawbone, then found videos of one being used - it sure wasn't this!  Jaw Harp uses the Synth and WA-WA effect with the RATE/TEMPO morphed to the Control Pedal and AMOUNT turned all the way down. The square wave OSC Shape is turned all the way up at 10.0 (9.9 adds a little more tone if desired). The EQ is used to roll off all the bass. If you load just the Synth patch, you'll need to add the WA-WA effect and EQ. If you load the program, the Jaw Harp is at the high end of a 3-part split, and I just have Bass and Piano/Organ available on the lower two splits for other playing. The MP3 is simply hitting/releasing the "E" note repeatedly and controlling the WA-WA.Take care.Jaw Harp W.mp3Jaw Harp       W.ns2pJaw Harp Program by WannitBBBad - third split(547 Bytes) Downloaded 624 timesJaw Harp W.ns2sJaw Harp Synth Patch by WannitBBBad - WA-WA effect and EQ needed.(60 Bytes) Downloaded 535 timesLINK "Stage 2 - For Those New To Programming" -->nord-stage-2-programs-ns2p-ns2pb-files- ... 16863.html

title: Selected Backup
post_content: I suspect that, like many NS2 owners, I keep all my current and custom programs in Bank D.From time to time, I back up my Bank D (to a DVD - RW disk, as it happens).Two questions -It seems to take the same amount of time (33 minute it states) to backup Bank D as it does to back up everything ("All"). Is this correct?I would like to backup individual programs, rather than the whole of Bank D. It seems that the only way I can restore programs is to re-load the whole of Bank D from my backup disk, thus overwriting everything in Bank D since my last backup. Is there any way I can backup and restore individual programs?Hope this makes sense!Many thanks.

title: RE: Selected Backup
post_content: Hi Killer,A backup will always necessarily include the ENTIRE contents of the instrument.  Restoring a backup file to the instrument will always overwrite the entire contents of the instrument.  If you wish to create a file which does not go "whole hog" on you, you will want to use the BUNDLES feature.  Creating a bundle of your Bank D will yield a file which contains all Bank D program along with all piano samples and sample samples needed to perform those programs.  Depending upon the size of the samples/pianos you use for your Bank D programs, and the number/size of pianos/samples resident on the instrument which are NOT used by your Bank D programs, this Bundle operation may or may not save you a significant amount of time when writing it to your computer.Using the Bundle operation will always save you much time when re-writing it back to the instrument because whereas the Restore process overwrites everything, Nord Sound Manager, when loading a bundle, will scan the contents of the piano/sample memory on the NS2 for copies of pianos/samples called for in the bundle, and if it sees that the needed pianos and samples already exist in the instrument's memory, it will skip those writing operations.  This will save a HUGE amount of time in your case.It is always possible to simply upload programs to your computer's hard drive.  These are teeny tiny little files because they do not contain and sample data.  Transfer will be superfast, blink of an eye style.  As a practical matter, how many files are we talking about here?  Most folks, I think, might not routinely use more than 20-30 programs in a performance; not the full hundred of an entire bank.  Use the SOUND UP icon to upload these to computer.Bless,Pablo

title: RE: Selected Backup
post_content: Thanks for VERY quick response, and for your suggestion, which I will follow up - hopefully tomorrow.I actually have about 60 progs stored in my D bank (although I don't use them all on one gig!).Typically they are stored on D 1/1 to D 12/1 (that's how I list them on my set lists, anyway. I guess everyone has their own way of referencing them).I would like to save a single prog to disk (say D 5/4), try something different in it's place for a while, but be able to restore the original back to D 5/4 if the new prog doesn't work out.Will see if your suggestion does the trick.Thanks again.

title: RE: Solsbury Hill - Peter Gabriel
post_content: There are no real specific keyboard parts in Solsbury Hill other than general backing chords. Piano chords layered with a soft string or pad sound is all that's needed. Probably the best thing to do would be to play the flute riff as well, and a sampled flute sound would be perfect. The Nord sample library should provide a suitable flute, try the flutes in the Wind/Brass download. The Chamberlin/Mellotron flutes might not work as they speak quite slowly and don't really have the right vibe for this song, but they might be worth a shot.

title: RE: Dual Doubler
post_content: I'm afraid there isn't, the different Stage's are not compatible. You'll just have to do it by hand. Shouldn't be too difficult as you already seem to know basically how its done.

title: RE: Dual Doubler
post_content: Uh oh. Do you know then if there is any way of creating that Haas effect - delaying one channel ever so slightly?

title: RE: Dual Doubler
post_content: Maybe you can make the Haas effect in a stereo sample and use that in the synth section.

title: RE: Dual Doubler
post_content: That's no problem -- if you want to load the MkII into one slot and the Mk V into the other, then use a very short delay on one set to 100% wett.Pablo

title: Convert Electro3 programs into Stage2?
post_content: Hello!I've just found an awesome patch for a Electro 3, that I want to use on my Stage2. Is it possible to convert a electro3-program into a Stage2-program?Thanks!

title: RE: Convert Electro3 programs into Stage2?
post_content: The Nords do not seem to bet patch compatible across models, unfortunately. You can share samples, but that is it.

title: RE: Convert Electro3 programs into Stage2?
post_content: A note here on program compatibility: different instruments with different available functions and features, different architecture and different software cannot possibly have programs which are compatible cross-platform.  It is not reasonable to expect that they would...That said, I don't think that there's anything that the NE3 can do that an NS2 can't, so it should be possible to "translate" one to the other manually.Pablo

title: Nord Stage 2 / Mainstage
post_content: Is it possible to take a sample created with the ES2 synthesizer in Logic Pro X and load it onto the nord as a sample? I just got a nord yesterday and am curious to know if such a thing is possible. Thank you!

title: RE: Nord Stage 2 / Mainstage
post_content: Create wav files of some notes and use the sample editor to produce a nsmp file. Relatively easy to do.

title: RE: Nord Stage 2 / Mainstage
post_content: How do I do this?...

title: RE: Nord Stage 2 / Mainstage
post_content: 1. You play amd record a couple of individual notes on the ES2 track in Logic-2. You bounce that track to an audio file.3. You import that audio file into the Nord Sample Editor.4. You chop that audio file apart for the individual notes and assign them to the appropriate keys, with the Editor interpolating in between.5. You load the resulting .nsmp sound into the Stage using the Nord Sound Manager.If any of those steps should prove confusing, please consult the manuals for the software. There are YouTube guides to using the Sample Editor, as well.Folks here can help you out if you're really stuck, too, of course.

title: RE: Cosmic Girl - once again ...
post_content: Hi there,I believe the intro sound is a Rhodes with a lot of phaser effect, though the original song has a (not-shallow) MkII Rhodes which is not available in the current Nord Library, and this particular Phaser effect is probably also not on your Stage 2. Myself, I use a real Rhodes for this song in particular.The strings in the intro: I just play them halfway through the intro with a Nord Wave. You can use any of the tremolo strings: I assigned an expression pedal to the volume. Perhaps use a delay pedal, oscillate the sound and slowly increase volume and decrease delay. This is possible on a Stage 2, which I do not own, but you can probably assign Strings volume and effects to an expression pedal as well.I play this song a lot in my band, it's a real classic one!

title: RE: Cosmic Girl - once again ...
post_content: You're true about the Rhodes, it's not in the library. Thing is, the only Rhodes MkII sampled in the Nord library is a shallow one. A 'normal' Rhodes MkII sounds different, sounds less shallow (figures, right?).I bought a real MkII few weeks ago and got a Small Stone Phaser effect pedal this christmas. Combined, they sound awesome and are spot on for this song.The synth lead just after the chorus you mean? On my Nord Wave, I use a basic saw tooth (I think..), Mono Mode on mono with glide set to about 20-30%, add the Chorus 1 and I assigned the Morph weel to the frequency, for which I use the vocal type setting, finishing with a vibrato on the after touch.This lead sound is also perfect for any song by Jamiroquai. His keyboardist also uses it in Little L and plays with the frequency a bit. That way your lead synth sounds like it's 'talking' like it's a WAH sound , or something like that. Hard to describe, haha.If you want, I can send you my lead sound as a Nord Wave program, I guess. That should be at the end of this week, you can send me a PM if you'd like. Or I could e-mail you a demo if I have the time.cheers!

post_content: Hi everybody! New to the boards there so excuse me if there's a better place to ask this question.I seem to have a problem downloading sound files for my Stage 2. Anybody familiar with this issue or is there something I'm doing wrong?Thanks for any help you guys can provide!

title: RE: Problem with 1kb files
post_content: Hi,Do you left-clic and select "save-as" ?What's the downloaded file's extension ?A ".ns2p" file should be 547 bytes long.F.

title: RE: Problem with 1kb files
post_content: frantzkb wrote:Hi,Do you left-clic and select "save-as" ?What's the downloaded file's extension ?A ".ns2p" file should be 547 bytes long.F.Yes, I am doing all of that. title: RE: Problem with 1kb files
post_content: Have you tried another browser ?What's the file extension, after download ?Are you on osX or Win ?

title: RE: Problem with 1kb files
post_content: frantzkb wrote:Have you tried another browser ?What's the file extension, after download ?Are you on osX or Win ?Using Chrome, but also tried it on IE. Both result in the same 1kb file.After downloading, the file extension is still .ns2p.Using Windows 8.While it's downloading, it says .../547kb, but as soon as the download is done, the file changes to 1kb.

title: RE: Problem with 1kb files
post_content: Hi Dubbs,I think perhaps you are mistaken -- while downloading it says 547bytes, not kilobytes.  Programs are not memory intensive things, requiring only minimal info to designate panel knob and button settings.  This is perfectly normal.  The 547bytes figure is rounded off to 1kb for some display purposes.The things which consume significant amounts of memory on the NS2 are pianos and samples, .npno and .nsmp files respectively.Bless,Pablo

title: RE: Problem with 1kb files
post_content: pablomastodon wrote:Hi Dubbs,I think perhaps you are mistaken -- while downloading it says 547bytes, not kilobytes.  Programs are not memory intensive things, requiring only minimal info to designate panel knob and button settings.  This is perfectly normal.  The 547bytes figure is rounded off to 1kb for some display purposes.The things which consume significant amounts of memory on the NS2 are pianos and samples, .npno and .nsmp files respectively.Bless,PabloRight and (Dubbs) remember that .ns2p are "Programs" so in the Nord Sound Manager you must be in the Programs tab to load them, not in the Piano or Sample or Synth ones.

title: Amped Electric Grand
post_content: Spent some quality time with the new(ish) amped Electric Grand, this patch and MP3 is the result. The new EG is really rich and IMHO responds quite nicely to effects. The sample is in three parts, the first part has the plain sample with just a little EQ and reverb, middle part adds slow Leslie with overdrive, and the last part adds chorus and auto-wah on top of that. The attached patch has those effects configured as they appear in the sample, but inactivated initially. No compression or DAW effects other than some crossfade between takes, the sound is as it comes out of the board.I have the amped EG sample in slot 5 of the grands, so you may have to adjust the patch accordingly if you have it somewhere else.Edgy Electric Grand.mp3EdgyEG.ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 372 times

title: DrummerBot
post_content: Hi,I've just been playing a bit with the NS2 section arpeggiator using the white noise sample and master clock synched together with the delay and filter.I realised that it is possible to create some interesting rhythmic patters and since never heard anything similar in the built-in sounds or samples of the NS2, I thought I would share this.DrummerBot.mp3Here is the nsp2DrummerBot.ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 461 timesAnother interesting thing is to use the synchronised LFO to modulate the filter so the sound changes within the loop (in some beats like a tom, and others like a snare).The Delay Amount and Feedback can be used to introduce some variations to the patterns too.Enjoy!

title: RE: DrummerBot
post_content: I like your implementation here.  I did a similar thing, zoning the synth section to the very top zone and leaving hold on, but mapping my control pedal to synth section volume.  This allowed me to start a song with a little electro style beat, leaving my hands free, then fading the beat out once the drummer joined in.  Worked well.

title: RE: Rise Up Parachute Club
post_content: Hi,Nsmp files can be dropped into the sample tab in NordSoundManager, on a free slot number. The Nord kb is connected via USB. The sample is loaded into the kb.Then you can access the sample in the synth section of the kb. Press s***-InitSound, select 'samp', set the sample number, watch the sample name displayed on the screen.You have to tweak the synth section buttons and knobs, try different envelope and filter setting to your taste.Of course, you can also start from an existing program ( ns2p file ) that makes use of a similar sample, and just select the sample number.Cheers,F.

title: My split EP2 program
post_content: When Clavia released their new Rhodes sample, I thought there was no longer a reason to upload the Rhodes program I've been using for a while. But, although I like that new sample a lot, I've frequently found myself switching back to my "Universal Rhodes" program, mostly because it seems to cut through much better. So here it is, finally (with a lot of new optimizations, actually).It is a bit difficult to demo because I wouldn't usually play it as a solo instrument. But since a demo is pretty much a requirement, here you go (sorry about the somewhat sloppy playing and low fidelity):Universal Rhodes Demo.mp3So, what did I do?The most annoying issue in the Suitcase sample is (IMHO) its weakness in the second octave above middle C. In its original form, I've often had the problem that it would totally disappear during a solo. I fixed this (or at least reduced it somewhat) by creating a split at B5/C5 with two different EQ/Drive settings below and above. After a lot of experimentation, I think I've found some settings that make the split point hardly noticeable (unless I've just gotten used to it).There is also another aspect to the different EQ settings: The program contains a rather strong upper-mid boost. By choosing a slightly different center frequency for the boost, the negative effects on the sound can be reduced somewhat.Another problem, which can be worked around easily but frequently caught me by surprise, is that the dynamics somewhere around an octave below middle C are really strong. In particular, notes that are played too lightly turn out to be barely audible. The synth section of slot A is used to make the fundamental of these notes a little stronger. The filter is intended to restrict this effect to the notes that need it.The synth section of slot B is used to add more overtones to the notes below F2, which otherwise tend to get lost in a mix. This is very optional, of course, so if you need on synth section for another purpose, use the one in slot B. This also removes the need for the E2/F2 split point.Hope this is useful to someone. Happy tweaking.

title: RE: My split EP2 program
post_content: Thanks! Very interesting the boosting with the synth. For some reason the Rhodes has been a difficult instrument to please everybody.As you say, most Rhodes samples in the Nord feel somewhat thin in the upper octaves. Maybe they have less layers in that section? I wonder if that could be fixed by adjusting the dynamics of the layers.Whichever is the case, Clavia has listened to comments, so let's hope that newer samples will be offered.

title: RE: My split EP2 program
post_content: Lovely sound! You did a great job!

title: RE: U2 With or without you
RE: U2 With or without you
post_content: Hi,Here's some alternate tip (or receipe) for this song, that should avoid an arp/sequence use, specially if you play with a human drummer:Use the synth section, select "Sin" in FM categoryUse 900ms as release time, use a medium-short attack time.Adjust HF filter to make it more "mellow".Then play the following notes in a loop, one hand alternating to the other :[:D6 (right hand, piano), D5 (left hand, pianissimo), A5(lright hand, piano), F#5 (left hand, pianissimo):]Then Adjust middle eq to avoid invading frequencies.Then relax, sit back, enjoy and call friends to play the other parts

title: RE: Help me please !
post_content: Hi Daniele,Why I thought Austria I have no idea - have you changed flags recently or was I simply seeing things?Very tricky finding that program -- it was 5:3 on my machine!  I know, you were simply making it a little more challenging.Okay, so here is my version of the DIGILOG DUAL PAD.  I'm not 100% happy with Slot B, but frankly it will be VERY difficult to get it exact so after an hour of playing around with it, I decided I was close enough and you can tweak the rest of the way to taste.Part of the difficulty lies in the fact that the digital waveforms available in the NS/NSEX Synth's Osc Section are not necessarily contained in the Wave section of the NS2's Synth Section.  It may be impossible to get exact.  Also, there are plenty of envelope things going on there, with the Mod Env set to repeat, a setting which is not available on the NS2.So here's the program in NS2 format:NS2 DIGILOG DUAL.ns2pfirst attempt at converting NS/NSEX factory program DIGILOG DUAL PAD to NS2 platform(547 Bytes) Downloaded 319 timesComments/suggestions/corrections happily accepted, and apologies for absence of mp3 file, but not set up for that at moment.Bless,Pablo

title: RE: Shake your rump synth sound request
post_content: The Beastie Boys sampled it from the song 6 O'Clock DJ by Rose Royce.Rose Royce did it with an analog mono synth,  probably the mini moog or micromoog from 1075. That's the sound you are talking about right?

title: RE: Shake your rump synth sound request
post_content: Get the synth section on. Initialise it. get a saw or square wave and transpose down the octave shift.Play a low note (actually the phrase seems to be a sequence of 5 consecutive semitones). Open and close the filter Freq set as LPF24 with level 4 or so of resonance. Not exactly the same, but close.

title: RE: Fury in the slaughterhouse - Time to wonder
post_content: I always default to a Hammond for that kind of function.Clean sound, no chorus, something like an 808000003 or so. Some reverb.Not loud - just enough to make it obvious that something's missing when you stop playing.Play with Leslie speed to add dynamics, maybe pull one or two of the other drawbars towards the end, depending on how crazy your band goes over dynamics.

title: Supersaw - Trance Hook
post_content: Hello everybody!Sorry if it has already been discussed, but I could not find in the topics.I am looking for a typical supersaw "trance" sound, commonly used in today EDM.I am new to the Nord Stage 2 and could not yet manage to make one that I like.Do any of you play this kind of music or has something to share?Thank you very much.Paulo.

title: RE: Supersaw - Trance Hook
post_content: Initialise the synth section, choose saw wave, then you can thicken it with the Unison switch. You can also use the hidden oscillator to set it one octave down (dtn mode) plus a small amount to frequency modulation via the SHAPE MOD (set towards the LFO side).

title: Program Editing Question
post_content: Hi guys - fairly new to making my own programs and just need a quick bit of help . If I have my NS2 split with pianos at the bottom and my synths up top....there is the "effects" section on the top right where I can select the source and add EQ/drive, etc.  But when I do that to pianos and then switch to synths I lose the changes I made to pianos and vice versa.  Is there any way to have these effects active for both pianos and synths on the same program??

title: RE: Program Editing Question
post_content: What do you mean with switch? Are you actually switching programs? If you change a program but do not save, you lose your changes when you switch programs.I'm not completely sure about this, but I think the effects only affect the primary two outputs; anything you send out the primary outputs will be affected by the effects. If you send a sound out the outputs 3 and 4 (possible as a stereo signal), they will not have the effects applied.At least that is how I think it works, but I don't have an NS2 anymore nor did I consult the manual, so I might just be wrong

title: RE: Program Editing Question
post_content: when I say "switch" I just mean switch the source selection in the effects menu.  Once I take the source off piano after editing, the changes I made are not active.  I want to change the effects for both sources in the same program and have them both stay - is this possible?

title: RE: Program Editing Question
post_content: Maybe you can get what you want by putting your piano in slot A and your synth in slot B. This way you can have two independent effects sections.

title: RE: Program Editing Question
post_content: Misunderstood what you were trying to accomplish.-dj

title: RE: Program Editing Question
post_content: Sorry DJ, but as I read the OP the answer is NO.  It is not possible to, for example, use the delay on piano and synth at the same time.  Each individual effect in the f/x section can only be assigned to one instrument section at a time, so choices must be made.As Juholaatu stated, segregating things to different slots is the strategy for fine-tuning what you what.  If you absolutely must have EQ for both synth and piano, put them on different slots and layer the two slots together.Bless,Pablo

title: RE: Program Editing Question
post_content: Hi, Pablo-Thanks. I misunderstood the OP. I did not realize he was trying to have the effects on two different instrument types in the same slot.-dj

title: Muse - Big freeze.
post_content: Hello.This weekend I will try to DIG IN and create the patch for this song. The arpegiator is the big problem as it needs to follow a specific sequence to sound right. And I noticed that the arpegiator from the NS2 is very dependant on the way you press the keys. I mean, the arpegiator needs to start from the root, EVERY TIME, and EVERY TIME - needs to follow (for example from Eb ) - Eb G Bb Eb G Eb Bb G (this is a Eb chord, in a 4/4 time, as eighteens). So, for every chord change, it needs to follow this sequence. 1 3 5 8 13 8 5 3. I noticed that (maybe because of my pressing the keys) - sometimes the arpegiator starts on the 3rd, or 5th and it is not ok for the song. More than that, I cannot use my both hands to make the sequence as I need to play the synth's pad on the right. And I cannot hold and change fast a 5 note LARGE chord for the arpegiator (and more - press it PERFECTLY so the arpegiator with kick on the right note).If anyone has hints - on what I am missing, what I shoud follow on,  please let me know.Thanx.
