title: synth patches on the NS2
post_content: I've recently bought a Stage 2, and while in almost every respect it's a real improvement on my Stage Classic, I have to say I really miss not having presets in the synth module. I do intend to get my synth chops together a bit more so I can make my own sounds, but it was really handy having presets on the classic, especially for getting patches together in rehearsal situations etc. Am I missing something here? I've gratefully downloaded some of the excellent patches forum users have posted, but is there a bank of more generic all-purpose patches available for download anywhere? I'd be grateful to anyone who can enlighten me!

title: RE: synth patches on the NS2
post_content: The synth sectiondoeshave its own presets. You can have 1024 programs (where a program contains the settings for all sections in both slots) but you can also have 300 presets just for the synth section.What was very confusing for me is that the names of the first 115 presets (or something like that) are the same as the standards samples on the Stage 2. You can change that of course and if you keep going, at some point you'll see that the synth presets will have different names (and probably don't use samples, but I never verified that).Page 32 of the manual briefly describes how to choose a synth preset - read theLoad Soundsection, especially the 2nd paragraph.I never found these synth presets that useful and frankly somewhat confusing. I suppose they're best in a live situation, or when creating new synth sounds since you could build up a library of good starting points.Edit:I'm wondering if I'm confusing the situation on the Wave with that on the Stage 2. I have neither anymore, so I can't check. Maybe it was the Wave where the first 115 were the same as the samples. On the other hand, I seem to remember the Wave could only have 99 samples. Age is catching up with me...

title: RE: synth patches on the NS2
post_content: Hi Shan/MJ,I often marvel at how involved you get in responses relating to keyboards you no longer own, but your brain has cross-pollenated some things here, as you suggested.  The Wave has 8 banks of 128 programs each; the Stage 2 has 4 banks of 100 programs each.  You were correct about the Synth Section "subprograms" though; they are still implemented on the Stage 2, but organized slightly differently.  The older Stage/Stage EX splits those synth subprograms into three categories: Leads, Basses and Pads.  On the NS2 there is no superimposed organization -- you simply get access to 300 locations to use as you see fit.Pablo

title: RE: HELP creating patches ???
post_content: a program ? A nord .ns2p file ? a patch ? whatever you may call it...matt

title: RE: HELP creating patches ???
post_content: Dear Matt,The sample editor you mentioned earlier is complete seperated from creating a patch, or a program. The sample editor, to my humble knowledge, can only be use when you want to create a sound for using within the 'synth' section only.As for creating a patch, basically you have, per patch, 2 slots - A and B. within each slot you have 1 organ, 1 piano, and 1 synth. You can mix and match as you like and save it to the location you wish for it to be. So in total, providing you use 2 slots simultaneously, you will get 2 organs (although those 2 organ settings can only be build on the same model, ie. B3, farfisa or vox), 2 sounds from piano section and 2 synth sounds from its section.I hope that should give you the idea to start!Tat P.

title: Soulfull Rhodes
post_content: Is it possible to program the kind of Rhodes used in this tune on a Stage 2?

title: RE: Soulfull Rhodes
post_content: I don't think you can reproduce it exactly using the currently available EPs, but IMHO you can get sufficiently close to be happy with it. It's mostly a matter of tweaking, and a lot of it comes down to personal taste. As a starting point, you could try:the MK V sample -- This might be surprising, but I've found it to work best because of its "clean" sound (not sure whether this is the right word to describe it; I'm definitely no expert).the "Small" amp simsome treble boost (though this probably depends a lot on the song and arrangement)a high dynamics setting -- I think it's important to be able to lay down chords very softly and play strong accents occasionally. (I can't do that very well on my SW73, but it tends to work much better using a weighted controller keyboard.)a bit of chorus, slow and subtle enough that you don't hear it as an effect of its ownoptionally some tremolo or panningrelatively little reverbYour playing style can also make quite a difference, especially because the different velocity layers and sample transitions are very noticable. Some groups of keys have a slight bell characteristic, even in the MK V sample, but only at certain velocities. It probably makes sense to memorize which keys have a noticeable sound, and maybe to use the sweepable mid EQ to make them stand out some more.But in the end, I think the "right" EP sample is just not there (yet, hopefully). Something like JaZzMaN251's MK II sample could work, but only with velocity layers, of course. This experiment I made with that sample might also help if you are prepared to do even more tweaking:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-user- ... t3993.html

(Sorry, I can't redo it now because the neighbors tend to hear the sound of the keys being pressed down. Oh, and I didn't have enough time to figure out the correct chords, either.)I sort of can't help it.mp3You can hear the "enhancement" in some of the higher notes that I played. I think it's a step in the right direction, but definitely not the final answer. And I have no idea what it would sound like in a band context.

title: How would dissect this song?
post_content: Hi all,Just starting to get to the point where I feel comfortable with all my gear after a 20+ year layoff.  I want to move on to the next level of figuring out how to dissect keyboard parts within a song and how to go about doing that.   I'm pretty decent about figuring out the older school stuff with basic synth parts or piano/organ type of stuff but some of the newer stuff with multiple parts has be puzzled as to where to start.  I'm not just looking for the "sounds" that are used but how do you pull it apart to figure it out.This is a song by P!nk that has a bunch of different stuff going on.How would you go about figuring out the parts on it?-Dave

title: RE: How would dissect this song?
post_content: Are you familiar with how a digital audio workstation (DAW) roughly works? I think this song was carefully crafted in a DAW, with her voice as maybe one of the few elements that was left relatively untouched (as far as I know, she steers clear of auto-tune like it is the plague).I would probably load the song in a DAW (Ableton Live in my case) and do the following:Determine BPM and time signature (probably 4/4)See if I can chop the song up in measures (bars)Determine the songs elements (verse, chorus, etc.)Per measure, figure out what's actually in itI'm pretty sure I'd have my hands full with this and this probably isn't the best way to approach it, but this is how I'd approach it.I would expect a live version to sound quite a bit different (simpler, less polished).Btw. I must the video surprises me a bit. She must've had some bruises (it seems to be a mixture of modern dance and rugby) and I'm sure she could totally kick my rear-end.

title: RE: How would dissect this song?
post_content: Well, you picked a great song for sure!  Pink is at the top of her game and the top of the charts.With modern Top 40. there are a lot going on, so the best place to start is to figure out what is being played by keyboards.  There is a piano in the intro, then the first verse is guitar, bass, and drums. At the end of the first verse there is a synth/string swell and the piano from the beginning comes in over that.Just listen to each verse, chorus, bridge, and isolate the keyboard sounds.  It is likely that one person will not be able to cover all the sounds in a single song, so pick the ones that are the most important, the signature sounds, and program patches to cover those.Have fun--dj

post_content: Is it possible the names of the programs have something like an underscore (_) or maybe '%20' (without the quotes) in them? If so, try replacing the underscore with a minus sign (hyphen) and replacing the %20 with a single space (or another minus).

title: RE: Program would not show in Sound Manager
post_content: Yes, I've been experiencing the same thing for a few weeks. It took me a while to realise that the programs are actually loading into the bank location (well, nearly always).So, when I select the saved location, they are there. To get them to show in Sound Manager, I changed something in the name (maybe just a letter) and re-saved.You can always change the name back once its appeared in Sound Manager.Hope this helps. It worked for me in most cases. But maybe someone has a better work around - and a proper technical solution.

title: RE: Program would not show in Sound Manager
post_content: Solved!!Just found out that programs can not include underscore (_) in the file name. (Why use them in the first place??)Thanks to thekiller01 and ebladinieres for responding.Cheers

title: The Ultimate Grand.
post_content: Ok, so am I the only one here thinking 512Mb of piano memory is far too much and we need to go to great extent in order to cram it up to the max ???Just kidding. There's not enough piano memory. And this program won't solve the problem - on the contrary.I like the YaS4 Bright Grand because it is so bright, yet rather mellow, and with the right reverb, it sound so beautifully wide and aerial...But its bass are not very clear nor defined.I like the bass of the Bosendorf better. It has a kind of macho sharpness which is just what I need - unfortunately its medium and hi-pitched notes are too thin to my taste.NO PROBLEM : let's just split the keyboard, use the Bosendorf for the first two octaves, and the Yamaha for the rest !In XL quality (I wouldn't go for less), that's about 400Mb for just one program, but hey, this is just the best piano sound to my taste ever. (I had to do away with the Italian Grand to make room, not without regrets though. I also had to get rid of all the upright pianos, which is too bad because I like the honky-tonk and saloon ones.Life is the art of compromise, which may be why it so often sucks.Or maybe Clavia should just put more memory in their keyboards.)So, here it is. The Bosendorf should be in grand piano model #1, as from factory, and the Yamaha S4 in grand piano model #2. The split point is in 2nd split position. You can move it to 1st split position: that sounds good too. Any other place would defeat the whole point (and be noticeable), so better keep the split to either one of the first two positions.

title: My collection of FAT funky EPs...
post_content: Ever since I bought my NS2 (about 8 months ago), I've been aiming at the ultimate EP sound... I like my EPs fat, and I like them funky.Here they are. They're work in progress of course, since every time I use them, I tweak them a little bit further.There's no mp3 demo because my new cheap-and-crappy laptop doesn't have a line input and I haven't addressed that yet. But they're all electric pianos all right.Things you should know :- They all contain the main EP in Slot A, and an octave-down 2nd layer in Slot B, to fatten the sound. Sometimes, the B SLot is enabled by default (and you can disable it), sometimes it is not (and you can enable it).- Effects 1 and 2 are always programmed, for both slots. They're not always all enabled at the same time, however. It's up to you to enable/disable effects at will.- All programs use the Mod. Wheel and Control Pedal, as two independent controls, though you may need to enable effects to hear them work. (Don't forget there are effects waiting for you on B Slot too!). Most of the time, they control tremolo rate and amount, but there are other, accasional surprises...These programs are using (about?) all EP sounds, in their original factory locations.Enjoy !

And I've tried a few different ways, and failed.I would ideally like one preset to have rotary speakers SLOW and with some Drive, and the other preset FAST, no Drive. title: RE: Organ Presets I and II
post_content: Hi Killer,For a single slot (either one), set your organ to desired settings, then hit Preset II button and set your other desired settings.  Store program.  Preset II button will toggle between the two.Pablo

title: RE: Looking for Ac Piano (like RD 700SX) and Rhodes (like Sv-1)
post_content: Hi I love the Bosendorfer XL on the NS2.  However, I've always had Yamaha P series (P80, P90) and a CP33, which sound the same and are fantastic pianos.  Nord piano sounds straight out of the box sound a bit thin and weird in the EQ to my ears especially after years of Yamaha.  So I set up my CP33 and my NS2, found the sound closest to my Yamaha sound, which is the Bosendorfer and then set about EQ-ing it to sound and behave in roughly the same way.  I am actually very very happy with this sound.  I have the Dynamics set to number 1 and my EQ setting are as follows: Bass +7.9, Mid Freq 263hz Mid boost +3.6, Treble +7.6.  The reverb is set to stage 1 and the knob turned to 3.0 or more if you like more reverb.  Give it a try and see if you like it!  If you are a Roland piano sound fan it may be a little too Yamaha for you!!

title: RE: Looking for Ac Piano (like RD 700SX) and Rhodes (like Sv-1)
post_content: Hi,I start from Nicko's settings to work on Nord 's piano Eq.I'm happy with these :Dyn : 0- Bosen : Bass 4,6, mid 263Hz :+3 High +1,5- C4 : Bass 5,3, mid 5k : -3, High : -3- Italian : Bass 5,1, mid 263Hz : + 3,2, high +1,3Any opinion?

title: RE: Looking for Ac Piano (like RD 700SX) and Rhodes (like Sv-1)
post_content: As a general rule with EQs, it is always better to cut rather than boost. I have also found that the character of the NS2 pianos change a lot depending on the listening system type (headphones, studio monitors, PA system, stagemonitors, etc..) and across the same system depending on brand/model used.Personally, when I use headphones (Sony MDR7560) I sometimes cut the mid-freq around 550-650HZ about -6dB; when home I use an old (but good enough, I have to play at low volumes so..) 2.1 PC speakers system (Cambridge soundworks) and usually I apply no EQ as the system itself shapes the sound quite OK.So, all in all, I don't think there is a single and definitive EQ setting for all tastes, everyone has to find his/her own and may need more than 1 8for home/headset, studio, rehearsal room...)

title: Different pianos?
post_content: As far as playing in a live band is concerned, are there any real difference between the various grands that cannot be achieved by a little EQ adjustment?  I've listened intently to all the samples on Clavia's download page (and the comparison between the Bose and Faz by PianoManChuck on YouTube) - and the differences, even playing through decent PC speakers, are very subtle. I cannot believe they can't all be achieved just by taking a particular piano and tweaking with a bit of EQ to obtain all the others. Is this not a bit like The Emperor's new clothes?I also wonder if the sound samples on the Clavia website are from the actual original pianos, and not from the Nord instrument. I can never get my Nord to sound the same as their examples - even using the same speakers. Would love to know what 'effects' they have applied, because it always sound much richer and more 'piano-like' when I listen to their examples.As an aside, I recently replaced the Bose with the Faz in Piano Bank 1 on my NS2, but must have done something wrong when 'linking', because I had to go through all my saved programs to link them to the new piano (I was just getting a - sign in the model window whenever I chose a program that had previously used the Bose). Painful!If you've come across any of my other postings, you might think I do nothing but complain about the NS2. That's not the case - there are many things about the Nord I think are great (including this forum). I guess we just tend to raise things we're not happy with, rather than the things we are.Comments and obs welcomed, as ever.

title: RE: Chameleon - help me improve this sound!
post_content: When I recorded my "chameleon" loop, I recorded the Nord into 1 audio track while it was playing, trigerred by midi tracks (see picture above).  This inserts a 50ms delay into the audio. When I play back the audio and the remaining midi tracks for drums, they are not synchronized, the 50ms is hearable. My resulting mp3 mix was sounding fuzzy.While chasing the "fuzzy" impression I had, I made a cleaner (more classical) clav riff.I updated my mp3 (kamaleon2) in my first post, and here is a better midi clav riff.clav2.mid.txt(1.04 KiB) Downloaded 277 timesJust wanted to share this trial & error experienceHave fun,Frantz.

title: RE: Chameleon - help me improve this sound!
post_content: Gustavo, you mentioned you are a linux user. Did you try Rosegarden? You also need to install another program called Jack (as well as its GUI) to be able to read and write the MIDI and audio ports with little latency. title: RE: Chameleon - help me improve this sound!
post_content: IMHO, you and I need to reach a point where we don't have to think too much about technical things while playing, like fingerings, next chord or next note, in order to free our brain and focus on what we hear and feel.On that way, we should avoid midi and its quantization and use audio loopers instead.Thank you for talking about Reaper, I gave it a try again, and there is a function I like a lot, that I did not find under Ableton :- make a time selection- switch on the "Repeat" function- record=> you end up with all your "takes" !!  and can switch between them or spread them along the time lime if they are good.Ok that's basic, but the rediscover of that, in the context of "audio/live" (no "midi/quantize") recording,  it beats what I know of Ableton live. Edit: you play/loop until you're in time and don't need any quantization or other modifications.That, plus the audio and midi latency I got better in Reaper than with Ableton ... makes it a nice software todayHave fun,Frantz.

Edit: you play/loop until you're in time and don't need any quantization or other modifications.That, plus the audio and midi latency I got better in Reaper than with Ableton ... makes it a nice software todayHave fun,Frantz.Nice to know Reaper has less latency. I was considering Ableton Live due to it being marketed as being THE loop based DAW. But in Reaper you have the loop within selection thing, and I think there is a way in its settings to use it as a loop recorder. But since I have the Kaossilator 2 and KOPRO, I mostly use those when I want to do loop stuff. Maybe I'll try this week to do some loop based music on REAPER, see how that turns out. That piece of software is truly flexible. EDIT: Just found this:http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/mar12/a ... s-0312.htmSomething that may help recording: Options>Preferences>Tracks/Send Defaults set your Record Config to Stereo L+R and select Record Arm. That way each time you add a track (CTRL+T) it is ready to record.Also, this time I used midi just because I never had... I think its an excellent way of "writing" stuff. Like this week we are rehearsing Grover Washington's Just the Two of Us. And I believe I am very prone to forgetting how to do the intro. But if I record it in midi, I can hear it when my NS2 is connected and I can see the notes being played.

title: RE: Korgis - Everybody's got to learn sometime
post_content: Hi, I had a quick listen and there are 3 prominent keyboard parts which I would concentrate on if I were covering this:1. The piano sound. For this the CP80 with chorus 1 (set both dials to 12 o'clock) gets close enough to be convincing. I'd probably put this in my left hand.2. The string line. I think a moody mellotron string patch is what's required here. Stick this in the middle split3. Then there's the line in the refrain - 3 ascending notes at the end of each line. The timbre is somewhere between a clarinet and a flute. Might just get away with taking mellotron flute and rolling the freq knob back? This can go in the high split.Sounds like it's in C minor?

title: New NS2 Owner - Saving Layered Piano/String/Bass Splits
post_content: Hi, What a beautiful instrument this is!! A Newbie hear trying to figure how to  save a program consisting of a layer of strings ,piano and bass. Looking for a one-man gig setup of Strings and piano split to upper register with volume control of (strings only) via pedal and with Bass assigned to lower register.  Only want expression pedal to control string volume. Please advise if its possible on NS2, and if so how.Vr,Chuckiep

title: RE: New NS2 Owner - Saving Layered Piano/String/Bass Splits
post_content: 1. Press the slot A button2. Create your split3. Activate the piano section into up/hi area (check it only plays in the upper split)4. Activate synth in up/hi area5. Initialise the synth (hold shift and tap the init synth button to the right on the synth volume control)6. Set synth to sample mode and find a string sound7. Set synth volume and piano volume to suit (check it only plays in the upper split)8. Press slot B9. Activate synth section in Lo area10. Initialise the synth (like you did in step 5)11. Find a bass sound (check it only plays below the split).12. Press slots a and b simultaneously.You now should have bass in the left hand and the layered piano/strings in the rightBalance all your volumes (tap slot a to adjust the piano & strings then tap slot b to adjust the bass volume).Finally you want to assign your control pedal to the strings volume:13. Set the control pedal to 'max'14. Select slot a15. Hold the Ctrl pedal morph button and rotate the synth volume control down to 016. Release the Ctrl pedal morph buttonConfirm that the control pedal affects the volume of the strings soundHappy? Save it!

title: RE: New NS2 Owner - Saving Layered Piano/String/Bass Splits
post_content: Darren, Thanks so much for your help. I got the splits and layers working fine.

title: RE: New NS2 Owner - Saving Layered Piano/String/Bass Splits
post_content: Glad you got it going.

title: Help trying to create a particular sound
post_content: I have to do "Call Me Maybe" by Carly Rae Jepsen and having problems trying to get something for the swelling sound effect that stops abruptly just before the chorus.  Tried using white noise with a long attack but it doesn't have enough depth.  My verse patch is the pizzicato string sound from the Melotron library (I extended the release slightly) so looking to split the board and use the synth in slot b to cover this effect.The sound I'm referring to starts at 26 seconds in.Any ideas for something that's really going to kick it live?

title: RE: Help trying to create a particular sound
post_content: How about noise with a band-pass filter? Crank up the resonance and sweep up the filter frequency using the mod envelope while at the same time increasing the amplitude with the amp envelope?

title: RE: Help trying to create a particular sound
post_content: I'll give that a try tomorrow. Cheers!

title: RE: Help trying to create a particular sound
post_content: Did you grab the samples from this thread? They work very well.http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-user- ... t3296.html

title: RE: Help trying to create a particular sound
post_content: Hello!I've done a cover of this with my function band using the samples posted a while back.  They work great but we had to do some trickery as we needed it to be in a different key as we have a male singer! I ended up doubling the part with some other fast attack strings off the NS2 - which worked really well.In terms of the whooshing sound, I'm thinking its a filter thing too.  White noise and opening of the filter.  With the resonance set right it should give the desired effect.  I'm not sure if bandpass is the way to go, although that would produce a nice result too. It might just be a bog standard LPF sweep.  More than likely in the studio they just drew a volume ramp in pro-tools and cut the end off at the desired point rather than messing about on a synth (soft or otherwise).  So the attack idea might work well in tandem with this?If you manage to get it right, I'm gonna stick it in our version too! Since now you've pointed it out it sounds a bit odd without it!https://soundcloud.com/the-go-tones/call-me-maybeNicko

title: RE: Help trying to create a particular sound
post_content: I can get the effect but I want to somehow force the LFO to start it's cycle when I press the key otherwise I tend to find the oscillator is mid sweep when i hit the note.

title: RE: Help trying to create a particular sound
post_content: OK.Here's what I've come up with short of a better solution:Call Me Maybe.mp3Call Me Maybe 1 .ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 587 timesThe LFO is not controllable (unless someone knows different).  So based on the ideas above, Ive taken White Noise into the LP and I control the 'Whoosh' with the  Freq controller - I could also assign to the wheel i guess.To play it, I hold down a load of notes with the left hand in the low split and depress my sustain pedal then roll up the frequency.  At the right moment, I release the sustain to cut the sound then switch up to my patch for the refrain/chorus bit.

title: RE: Lady Gaga - Poker Face
post_content: I use 3 patches for poker face.  One for the intro/verse then a different one with a synth strings thing for the chorus then the third to cover the bridge bit where you have the bass synth from the verse with that warbly Egyptian riff over the top.I have a few patches to upload.  Just doing some YouTube videos to demonstrate how I use them live otherwise they might not make sense.

title: RE: Lady Gaga - Poker Face
post_content: Here is a single patch that covers the sounds in this tune pretty well.Start with the mod wheel up halfway.  The first distorted synth sound is played on the B above the upper split.  The pad for the chorus can be played with both hands below the split. For the modulated synth sound near the end of the song, simply pull the mod wheel back to normal and the distorted sound will morph into that.Enjoy--dj

title: SaxSection (Korg wavestation)
post_content: Hello NS forumers: today I created a patch based on a sample of Korg Wavestation's "SaxSection" preset, which sound like a soft Brass section with a distictive Sax-attack.The patch I built is more "clean" on slot A while the slot B tries to replicate the orginal WS patch (more effects)The sound can be useful for some soft jazzy accompaniment, particularly in the C2-C5 range.The Wheel is assigned to morph the Filter and "soften" the sound (but of course this as the whole patch can be altered to your needs, e.g. assigning Ctrl.Ped and/or Wheel to control also the Synth Volume for some nice "crescendo" control)Hope you like it and find it useful@admins: should the sample be posted also in the .nsmp section?NS2 Wavestation SaxSection example.mp3

title: Yamaha CS-80 sounds / Bruce Springsteen
post_content: Hello!This is my first post on this forum so please excuse any newbie mistakes : )I am the recent owner of the NS2 and couldn't be happier with it. I have a healthy amount of synth background from owning and using the Korg MS-20 for years / being a bit of a nerd.My current obsession is the keyboard sound on Bruce Springsteen's "I'm on Fire" and "Tougher Than The Rest". After doing some research I believe it is the Yamaha CS-80. Which leads me to my question.....Does anyone out there know much about the Yamaha CS-80 and/or the synth sounds on those Bruce Springsteen songs? Is there a way to get that keyboard sound on the NS2? Either through dialing in the sound or through importing a sample?Any assistance would be super helpful. I am going to keep looking and if I find the sound I will surly post it on the forum.Thank you!Eric

title: RE: Yamaha CS-80 sounds / Bruce Springsteen
post_content: Hello Heiseric and welcome to the forumCongrats on your new NS2 it really is an amazing instrument.I don't really know anything about the Yamaha CS-80, but I listened to the songs and I made a synth sound for I'm on fire. Hope it's okay for you.When I listened to the song the synth seemed to go a bit off pitch back and forth. I would personally do that with gently rocking the pitchbender back and forth, just very slightly. That seemed to get the best effect for me. I also put vibrato on the wheel, so you can use that instead if you want, but it didn't seem to be as good IMO.If you are curious how I made it. I just chose the FM synthsection. The first one gives you a sinus wave which makes that kind of sound. I then turned the shape knob on 50% and just added some attack and release. Lastly I added some chorus from the effect section and some reverb.But remember to use the pitbend (or vibrato from the wheel) to get that off pitch sound.I might try and make the sound for the other song for you later, but that is really hidden by all the other instruments playing, so it is a little harder to hear how it sounds exactly.I might also upload an mp3 later so people can hear how the patches sound.Hope this helps.Best regardsCbas

title: Donna Summer - I feel love
post_content: When playing around with the ARP and LFO recently I was trying to recreate a more modern, almost technoish version of a real Synth classic, changing the timing of the original riff a bit.While from 1977, it certainly was a massive Synth sound at the time and still is.So I was trying to get at least some bits and pieces of the Moog Modular Feast for a single player, obviously a "Himmelfahrtskommando", but nevertheless, and interesting to see how far the NS2 can take you (in particular without a (Step-)Sequencer.One big issue is the Sync of the Arpeggiator: If I don't hit the "one" within very few microseconds of the first beat it gets out of Sync. I tried also with Masterclock, Sync via USB-MIDI (the problem got worse!) maybe Ill try MIDI-DIN, slowing it to 80bpm, but still. Not really sure what's going on. Based on simple Sawtooth, I like the fatness of the sound. Fun to play around, but the sync issue keeps me for the moment from using it live...must have played it 50 times but once you miss it by a splitsecond it takes time to get backI feel love demo.mp3

title: RE: Donna Summer - I feel love
post_content: Hi Joannes, funny... I tried to build the same patch and incurred in the same issue; if I ever will have to play that song, either I play the bass line myself (joking!) or I would use an external arpeggiator (better if on my iPad)

title: RE: Donna Summer - I feel love
post_content: I had a go at this song some time back with the Stage 2. The limitations of the arpegiator in the Stage 2 make it very difficult to replicate the song exactly which previously led me to conclude that I had to manually play it. I have attached two files, one with the manual version (GLv4) and the other with arpegiator (GLv6). It's getting the double note at the front that is difficult and made more challenging by the fact that the LFO does not reset when you play the song. The option of LFO key sync is certainly something we could do with for this song and for the Stage 2 in general.I used delay and LFO filtering to help create some of the sound and have also added the option to use TREM by moving the mod wheelI've added some audio examples playing manually and with arp.GeoffI Feel Love GLv4 audio.mp3I Feel Love GLv6 audio.mp3I Feel Love GLv4.ns2pStage 2 Program (Manual version)(547 Bytes) Downloaded 609 timesI Feel Love GLv6.ns2pStage 2 Program (arp version)(547 Bytes) Downloaded 689 times

title: Contemporary pop: "DJ got us fallin' in love" & "Higher"
post_content: Hi folks,recently I've been playing some contemporary pop stuff for which I created the synth patches on the NS2 that I like to share with you:1.) DJ got us fallin' in love - Usher featuring Pitbull (link to video)DJ got us fallin.ns2p(547 Bytes) Downloaded 803 timesSamples used by this program:- Samp Lib Slot A : "P5 Saw Unison BR.nsmp" (this is the main sound in the middle zone, provided inNORD's libin the "Sequential Circuits Prophet 5" section)- Samp Lib Slot B: "Tekno Stack 1.nsmp" (this is the additional high sound for octaves in the lower left hand zone, I uses this in the chorus, the mod wheel opens the filter! title: Wind FX
post_content: Anyone already got a Wind FX patch?Thanks

title: RE: Wind FX
post_content: You mean the traditional WindFX of analog synths? I don't have such a patch yet but is quite easy to doYou need to use the White Noise sample and modulate the filter with the LFO (triangle wave), the filter should be a LP24 and have the cutoff freq low enough (depends also on the LFO  modulation depth) and no KeybTrack, the Resonance controls the "hiss"....Look also at this generic tutorial video that describes how to create a Wind patch (in a slightly different way, but basic concepts are the same) and try it yourself[youtube][/youtube]

post_content: Hi all,Down to the point, does anyone have any Yes Patches already made for any song in the Close to the Edge Album?Long Version:In the coming weeks I will be immersed on a project that consists on playing Close to the Edge on its full album length to commemorate its 40th anniversary. Unfortunately, its most likely we wont be able to do it on the exact day, but we will be trying our best. So I've been listening to Yes quite a lot on this last couple of years and I think I will base my playing from the Live at Montreux live album, since the Studio album is quite dull on keyboards at most parts. So I will try to immitate Wakeman's more "modern" playing and add some of my own falvor. So that is why I am asking for the patches. Also I am aware that is MY homework, but it'd be nice to have some starting pointsso not to start blank. Eventually I would end up modifying things to my taste (not necesarily to sound more wakemanish), so I'd share all of my patches with you guys, although I plan on using my MOPHO (or eventually a Tetra) for some leads, specifically I have in mind the hard lead on Close to the Edge (just before the really hard organ solo).Anyone has some useful scores available? A friend of mine has got the Yes Deluxe Edition Score Book, which supposedly has around 6 albums completely scored, but I do not know how precise it is. It would also be nice to be practicing based off on something digital for home use. I will dedicate myself to searching for good midis and pdfs but at the end those will only be the base, as I might just end up playing something different and the solos may be just an aproximation to wakeman's, depending on how the band feels about it.Saludos,Gustavo

title: RE: [REQUEST] Yes - Close to the Edge (full album)
post_content: Just in case anyone is interested, I found some excellent midi files for the album.Also, doing some research, Rick Wakeman only owned a Hammond C3, a Minimoog and an M400. (source) So looking up on the samples, I downloaded all M400 samples, all minimoog, setting up some B3 sounds, and trying out some simple leads (although I want to use my Mopho, I will not be able to bring it to the actual gig due to technical issues).I still do not have anything very solid, patch wise, But I think that I will end up with a few patches per song.

title: Toto - Child's Anthem
post_content: Hey guys!I always find new great sounds on this board, so I'd like to ask you if anyone could give some ideas for Toto's "Child's Anthem"[youtube][/youtube].I think that a grand total of 5 sounds is needed: the piano (of course), the synth brass sound for the piano solo part, the gliding synth at the end of the piano part, some brass sound for the "loud moments" and the "2nd guitar" sound.Besides the actual sound creation, my main concern is: how can I play all of this stuff? How should I split/layer the keyboard?My tools are a Nord Stage 2, a MIDI keyboard controlling the Stage (M-Audio Axiom) and, unfortunately, only 2 hands...Thank you.

title: RE: Toto - Child's Anthem
post_content: I have done a number of patches that require multiple sounds.  In some cases, you can use the controllers to Morph between two sounds in the same slot (you might be able to do this with the filter for the brass sounds, for example). In some special cases, I have had to use two programs to get all the splits and layers I needed for a patch, and put them next to each other so I can go back and forth between them with a single button push.  This is usually necessary when you need more than an octave or so to cover a particular part. I would recommend you figure out all the sounds necessary and then go to the samples and patches forums and see if any of those are close to the ones you need so you can just download and install them with a minimum of tweaking. I have created a number of patches which contain multiple different splits and layers for different tunes, so you could also check them out to use as examples for your own setups. Programming the Stage 2 is very intuitive, but it can be time-consuming as well, especially if you want the sounds to be a very close match to the song you are performing.Hope this helps.-dj

title: RE: Rock piano
post_content: Yeah, dialing in even just a little more high mids and highs will allow the higher frequencies to come out and your ear will pull the rest to the forefront.  every band situation is different though, because usually you're fighting the guitars for audio spectrum, and depending on their tone they could be in different places as well.  In my band when our guitarist uses a full, saturated tone I tend to dial up my highs, and when he uses a higher lead tone I emphasize the mids more, always seems to work..  The other issue is arrangement, if it's originals you're playing, you'll want to arrange the playing in such a way that the two instruments aren't competing too much for attention..  unless the piano is the driving force I'll drop back and fill the empty space more..  Just some ideas that may or may not be obvious and already considered.

title: Metronome
post_content: Hi,inspired by a post by anotherscott, I thought that indeed it should be possible to come up with some sort of metronome based on samples.So I recorded a metronome from 80-160bpm in 5bpm Schritten., set the loop accordingly, so just load a synth preset, load the sample and activate HOLD ON.Now when you hit the C2 key you'll get a 80bpm metronome and each semitone up 5bpm more. Switch to the other slot and you can play along.I recorded the metronome using a simple audio loop which was not really a good idea so it is very noisy, sorry for that, but was a long time of recording it so wanted to see if it is useful at all before doing a 100% proper version.Cheers!Johannes

title: RE: Metronome
post_content: Excellent idea. I did one with any sound with a very short amp decay and arp on =)

title: RE: Metronome
post_content: Niarf wrote:Excellent idea. I did one with any sound with a very short amp decay and arp on =)Exactly, marimba sample and arpeggiator is all you need (but.. personally I use a metronome App on iPad instead)Even better: arpeggiator striking the Beat "1" and delay set to have 3 repeats for "2-3-4" at lower volume, so you also get accent on the first beat. Just need to synchronize both Arp and delay to master clock but with different ratios (delay to be 4 times faster than Arp)

title: RE: Metronome
post_content: Marimba - nice! Indeed gets a perfect metronome sound. Delay is a great idea, only problem is the arp won't accept 1/1, so I tried with the LFO instead, not perfect but definitively usable when you need to show your drummer that you DID accelerate

post_content: Yes, certainly welcome.  The OS revisions make things a little confusing, at some point between 1.40 and 1.60 I believe they changed the format of the files that we share, so those that were made and exported from 1.60 weren't working on your NS2 until you upgraded. And as we've shown with the chorus-y reverb bug, not all OS upgrades are perfect.

title: RE: Just a few new patches
post_content: How did you make the synths string sound?

title: RE: Just a few new patches
post_content: titanium wrote:How did you make the synths string sound?If you want to analyse how a synth sound is constructed you can press and hold shift and turn the knobs of the synthesizer. The display then shows the corresponding parameters  without changing the values.Switch off all the effects (including unison) and listen to just one slot. That gives you an idea of how a patch works.This particular sound consist of two layers: slot A and BSlot A produces the essential attack part that would let you recognize it as strings, slot B thickens the sound to make it also a pad sound.A:String attacks are usually created by an envelope modulating the filter cutoff frequency by a short decay time.Here I’ve added  waveform modulation (shapeable sawtooth) done by the same envelope to increase the violin attack impression.The whole thing is multiplied by the unison function and the chorus-fx.To broaden the stereo image I used the pingpong  delay.B:This part is not necessarily supposed to be good sounding taken by itself. It should rather add components the A-part is missing.So I used permanent waveform modulation by LFO to make sure any interferences between A and B  wouldn’t lead to frequency cancellations.I used a slower attack time,  different filter characteristic, different delay-fx and some EQ.If you compare slot A and B playing just single notes you’ll notice how different the slots actually sound.A bunch of fiddle players all having their own sound …Cheers

My doubt is that we can't download programs 1.60 if we have an older version.in this program there is glide in arpeggio mode and I don't remember if this feature was present in the v 1.40,this list make me think that it was...Nord Stage 2 OS update historyv1.60 (2012-04-25)Pianos and Samples are now looked up by name rather than position, which allows for several new features with the Nord Sound Manager v 6.10.Fixed a bug where the Synth in mono mode could glide to a previously played note when sustain pedal is released.If the Stage 2 had been powered on for several days, the acoustic piano sounds could behave in a weird way.Rotary speaker speed morphs can now be operated via Global, Slot or Dual KB MIDI channels.When switching piano types, the model focus that is supposed to be the last one chosen sometimes was lost. Fixed...Sustain pedal now always sends MIDI CC64, value #127 when pressed fully down.Pitchstickfix - If Pitch Stick calibration fails during startup, the P-Stick is disabled.Fix for .nsmp velocity getting the wrong value, which could lead to issues sounding like notes were missing.Fix for the delay making strange sounds when programs were changed and the delay time was changed.Fix for the synth which could get stuck notes when playing legato.Changed how pending load works, dial is now active as documented.Fixed Extern MIDI Bank CC bug (cc00 and cc32 menus was mixed up).ciao!Ale

title: Joe Walsh's Lifes been Good Synth Solo
post_content: I'm having the hardest time recreating this patch. I think it was made with filter oscillation on an Arp Synthesizer. On an analog synth I would turn off the audio oscillaters. Any help would be greatly appreciated!

title: RE: Joe Walsh's Lifes been Good Synth Solo
post_content: mdlieb wrote:I'm having the hardest time recreating this patch. I think it was made with filter oscillation on an Arp Synthesizer. On an analog synth I would turn off the audio oscillaters. Any help would be greatly appreciated!Hello mdlieb,I believe that you're on the right track.However, I think rather than turning off the audio oscillators completely, that white noise is substituted.KB tracking routed to the filter cutoff frequency is important to be able to play the tonality of the sound.Virtual filters are notoriously bad at reproducing self-oscillating filter resonance,but I think that with some work you could pull it off.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Joe Walsh's Lifes been Good Synth Solo
post_content: Thanks for the reply. I tried the white noise but I'm having trouble pitching it. There are very distinct tones. So I've been filtering a sawtooth wave and dirtying it up with effects and compression. It worked out ok on the gig tonight but its not perfect. I'll just keep plugging away. thanks again...Mitch

title: RE: Joe Walsh's Lifes been Good Synth Solo
post_content: mdlieb wrote:Thanks for the reply. I tried the white noise but I'm having trouble pitching it. There are very distinct tones. So I've been filtering a sawtooth wave and dirtying it up with effects and compression. It worked out ok on the gig tonight but its not perfect. I'll just keep plugging away. thanks again...MitchThat may be part of the difference between virtual and real analog.The real analog needs just a little audio going through the filter to get it started into self-osc.Whereas with VA, it's probably just superfluous.I'm fairly certain that the original recording used an ARP Odyssey.I hope that you'll end up sharing this patch and maybe a demo of it with us at some point.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Joe Walsh's Lifes been Good Synth Solo
post_content: Cool, thanks.  Sound like you could use the wheel to control the filter cutoff on that one, but the resonance will be tough, as you said.-dj

title: RE: Joe Walsh's Lifes been Good Synth Solo
post_content: DJKeys wrote:Cool, thanks.  Sound like you could use the wheel to control the filter cutoff on that one, but the resonance will be tough, as you said.-djIt's a deceptively difficult sound to reproduce, even with the original instrument.Rather than the wheel controlling cutoff, it's important to have the keyboard scale control it, so the resonance can be played like an audio oscillator which will track the notes of the keyboard.The filter envelope also controls cutoff frequency with an immediate Attack, quick Decay, 50% Sustain level and immediate Release. I think this will give it that characteristic pop.Cheers, Hanon

title: Lead solo Nord homepage!
post_content: Hi everyone,I hope you can help me: I would very much like to know if somebady can create a patch on the nord stage 2 for the lead solo that you can hear on the front page of Nord themselves:http://www.nordkeyboards.com, first video in the right column named Greetings from Norway  (from Dag Selboskar). Really nice lead sound, hope you can help me out.regards, Laver

title: RE: Lead solo Nord homepage!
post_content: Anybody?

title: RE: Lead solo Nord homepage!
post_content: Hi Laver.Sounds like a moog sound to me. Check the samples it should be there.

title: RE: Lead solo Nord homepage!
post_content: Laver wrote:I would very much like to know if somebady can create a patch on the nord stage 2 for the lead solo that you can hear on the front page of Nord themselves:http://www.nordkeyboards.com, first video in the right column named Greetings from Norway  (from Dag Selboskar). Really nice lead sound, hope you can help me out.Hello Laver,I agree.That is a very beautiful, and magical lead.I suspect that its' beauty lies more with the player than the program, or instrument.It's a simple sound.To my ears:It's based on a saw type wave (probably virtual analog, rather than sampled), little, to no detuning.Monophonic mode, possible legato also with some glide added to simulate a vintage analog like the Minimoog as Shark suggests.I also hear a quick, shallow trumpet like attack, 24db low pass filtering, no KB tracking.This sound was done with the Wave (not simply because he's shown playing it in the video) but because it has AT controlled, LFO modulation of the VCA (tremolo) rather than vibrato (something the Stage series doesn't do).I believe the tremolo could be simulated on the NS2 by sending the Synth section through Effect 1 (Tremolo) and using AT to control "Amount" via the morph feature.The same type of lead sound re-emerges about 2:08 in the video, but using a pulse wave with a little resonance.I'd love to give this one a try, but.... "most of us know the rest...."I hope this gives a start. If one of the lucky NS2 owners will run with this and post back, I'll guarantee many "thanks"Cheers, Hanon

title: The Motels (80's Keyboard Unique Sound) - Help
post_content: I am a Nord Newbie, and hope I am posting this in the correct place.  If not, please let me know where I should post this. (Soon to a proud owner of a Nord Stage 2, this week). I have read similar posts in the very same section.I have been trying for a long time to get an exact replication of this awesome, very unique keyboard sound in the song "Only the Lonely" -  the Motels:I have come close with Korg, Roland, Yamaha, Alesis, & several VSTs but never could match that unique sound & tonal quality it has. I spent hours & hours trying. Also, I have never heard a single live, cover band that emulated it correctly either.  I too have been in many cover bands over the years but could never nail that sound down. If you listen very closely to the original, it has some percussion, organ, synth, piano, & some other hollow sound that makes so unique.I went as far as contacting Marty Jourard  who was the keyboard player for the Motels in the 80's:http://www.martymethod.com/martybio.shtmlWe emailed back and forth for awhile. He says he used a Prophet 5, but has long lost all his notes for the settings he used (bummer).  So I went and bought a VST of the Prophet 5 and never could even come close.  He may have used a Prophet 5, but I think it was layered with some other synth.My Question:Has anyone ever tried to emulate this unique sound (with success) in a sound patch created from the Nord Stage 2 ?When I get my NS2, this is one of the things I will look forwarding in "trying" to program.Thanks,SynthzGuy

title: RE: The Motels (80's Keyboard Unique Sound) - Help
post_content: Funny, I just worked on this last night.  I used an electric piano (Mark V) with FM 1.1 synth, effects and eq to taste. I don't know if it is up to the perfect emulation you are looking for but a good place to start.   Single slot.

title: RE: The Motels (80's Keyboard Unique Sound) - Help
post_content: DJKeys-Thanks... Look forward to giving that a try when I get my NS2 later this week. And yes, I am looking for an emulation as close as possible. I am hoping someone has nailed it.There is definely a percussion attack and organ tonal quality and some other unique sound that can be heard more distintive in the upper register.I hope this post generates alot of interest and response... as I think it is a much harder programming challenge than it seems upon first hearing it.Thanks for the reply.SynthzGuy

title: RE: The Motels (80's Keyboard Unique Sound) - Help
post_content: Hello All,not that this will be much help.I recognize the sound as a sequential circuits prophet 5:bank 1 program 8 "Percussive Organ" (File 1 factory presets)But with the following tweaks:Cutoff frequency reduced very slightly.Filter envelope amount reduced.VCA release amount increased slightly.The filter resonance is turned up to the point of self oscillation, and is used as an upper harmonic in the sound.This is why it's such a difficult sound to reproduce with VA (VA doesn't have a real resonant filter, it only simulates one)I heard a group playing this cover in a Brown Derby restaurant/ lounge back in the '80s and it sounded perfect.The keyboardist was using a Roland JX3P (my point is that the sound is easy to reproduce on analog gear)Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: The Motels (80's Keyboard Unique Sound) - Help
post_content: I will continue to look into this over the next week or so and let you know what I find out--dj

title: RE: The Motels (80's Keyboard Unique Sound) - Help
post_content: frantzkb wrote:I want to edit you post and add  "if i give hime all the settings"It would be more acurate !You've always done quite admirably all on your own.Here's the patch sheet of the original sound from Sequential Circuits:P5_Percussive_Organ.pdfPatch Sheet for Percussive Organ(128.57 KiB) Downloaded 588 timesThe performance notes say:1-8: Percussive OrganOSC A: up 3 octaves + a perfect 5th"Square wave, 40% audio out"OSC B: up 1 octave (basic pitch)"Triangle wave 70% audio out"MOD WHEEL selection is set for a vibrato effect.Move wheel up slightly (1/8th to 1/4) to engage vibrato"but not used in the song"PULSE-WIDTH on OSC B is set at 5, this allows for switching of waveforms."I assume this allows the patch to be shifted to being a farfisa-ish square wave organ. Once again, not used in the song"For proper effect, OSC A must be a square wave (set at approximately 5"50% duty cycle, or square"and listen for dropout of the octave --the 2nd harmonic).NOTES:Adjust the filter ENVELOPE AMOUNT to change amount of percussion effect and brightness of tone."much reduced in the song"Adjust filter CUTOFF to change overall brightness of tone."perhaps increased slightly in the song to counteract the reduction in ENVELOPE AMOUNT"I was wrong in my earlier post about the resonance being turned up to self oscillate.I know that this technique is used extensively in other synth organ patches like that of the Oberheim OB-X and Xa "Feels Good, Van Halen" .It would appear that it's not used at all in this patch.Cheers, Hanon

post_content: Here is what I came up with using a pulse wave and epiano on one slot and the DX Piano sample on another. The DX sample is at a low level and is the percussive part of the sound. title: Sample Editor: Choosing one sample vs all samples
post_content: Hi!I´ve sampled 6 instruments, and I want to make 2 .nsmp versions, one straight forward (No loop), and one with Long loop.When I was finally done doing this, I realized that the "No loop" was only set for one of the keys, not all.How can I do this for the entire range, instead of selecting No loop on one and one sample/key?

title: RE: Sample Editor: Choosing one sample vs all samples
post_content: Organ Morgan wrote:Hi!I´ve sampled 6 instruments, and I want to make 2 .nsmp versions, one straight forward (No loop), and one with Long loop.When I was finally done doing this, I realized that the "No loop" was only set for one of the keys, not all.How can I do this for the entire range, instead of selecting No loop on one and one sample/key?Hello Organ Morgan,Welcome to the forums,In the Sample Loop/Stop tab, there is a section called "Apply on All"If you click this with "No Loop" bulleted, it will set "No Loop" for all samples.Apply_Loop.PNG (48.35 KiB) Viewed 1997 timesCheers, Hanon

title: FX - Matrix12 Pitched Voltage
post_content: Tonight I want to post something unusual, an experimental sound: some days ago I found some multisamples (in MP3 format) of various Vintage synths and I wanted to try and convert  them in .wav then use in Nord Sample Editor.One multisample that captured my attention is this "typical" Matrix 12 "Pitched Voltage" sound which recalls Kraftwerk-like atmospheres but can also be creatively used in many other ways, I think.Here's the Patch, the Sample and an Example: enjoy!Matrix 12 Pitched Voltage.nsmpThe (multi)Sample(103.11 KiB) Downloaded 1002 timesMatrix12V-pV  MM.ns2pThe patch (slot A has Arpeggiator and Delay ON & linked to Master Clock; slot B = slot A + Filter modulation by LFO)(547 Bytes) Downloaded 675 timesMatrix12 Pitched Voltage (arpeggio example).mp3PS: if you want to try and play the "pure" sound just switch off the Arpeggiator and Delay, it is also interesting to use the LP or  BP filter and change its frequency while the arpeggiator goes (either manually or  via the LFO, better if synced with Master Clock)

title: EP Attitude
post_content: I downloaded some nice sounds from this site. Thanks for them. As a result I felt the need to also upload something. Here are some EP enhancements.The Stage2 EP sounds are nice but I needed some extra attitude. The easiest trick was to introduce some velocity controlled "attitude" on top of them. I created six different attitudes (samples) that can be used together with any of the Stage2 EP sounds. The correct settings for the samples are included in the attached program or synth setting files. The samples are a bit lean for most purposes to be used alone.The idea is thus to combine one of the Stage2 EP sounds with one of the attitudes. The program and synth settings refer to sample 999. You should turn the SYNTH - OSC sample selection knob to pick one of the attitude samples. Save your own version of the program (or synth) when you kow where the samples are stored and which one of them is most useful to you. (In the synth settings you may also need to adjust the SYNTH - LEVEL knob since that setting is not inclued in the ns2n file.)Some tuning options:- use SYNTH - LEVEL to reduce the amount of attitude- use SYNTH - FILTER - FREQ MOD 2 - MOD ENV to make the sound less responsive to velocity- use SYNTH - FILTER - FREQ to add attitude also in the low velocity notes- use SYNTH - OCTAVE SHIFT to change the style of the attitude (1 octave lower may be useful)- use SYNTH - MOD ENV - DECAY to limit attitude to the beginning of each note- use split to eliminate the attitude from one end of the keyboard- use MORPH ASSIGN to control the attitude settings (e.g. CTRLPED to SYNTH - LEVEL)JuhoEP Attitude.mp3

post_content: Very nice and a good starting point for Pads in general! Thanks well deservedI  modified it to get a Warm Pad, just by taking only the slot A sound (to leave a Synth section free for further split/layer), removing filter Mod Env on Frequency (to eliminate the "bowed" effect) and lowering cutoff to circa 250Hz (but assigning Wheel to morph it, so that when I want to open it... )You may also want to switch to the LP24 filter to make it "darker"Here is what I obtained:Warm Pad MM.mp3EDIT: I updated the patch, change made: increased attack time on AMP ENV

title: RE: saxophone sounds
post_content: Hello all,While I'm relatively new to posting here, I visit quite often.  It's a great forum.  Thanks to you all for the great info and the time you've put in to making this forum so great!I am also waiting with excitement for the new sax/brass samples from Clavia.  I'm confident they'll be great at whatever they attempt, I just hope they consider us performing in R&B bands.  It seems like so many other companies focus on orchestral brass or solo lines that don't really cut it and I've never been able to get them to be useful on stage.  The only instrument that has helped me be successful is my MotifXS. As of now I'm pretty much lugging it around for my brass patches.  By layering several different programs together for different situations (small brass ensembles AND solo instruments, esp. bari-sax) you an get pretty great, expressive natural brass sound out of it for various R&B situations whether it be James Brown stabs (with or without falls), Jungle Boogie-type lead lines, supportive melodic lines, and even 'padding' situations.  Of course, handwork on the pitch bend and mod wheels is important.The thing that concerns me is the Nords inability to transpose more than and octave in either direction.  For splits you need to be able to play a bari-sax way up there on the actual key bed but you've got to be able to transpose it a couple to a few octaves down to keep it in it's natural register.  Most brass ensemble samples/programs I've come across are missing the ever important lower end to give them the power and density they need to work.Does anyone know if there is there a place where I can make suggestions to them directly?  I'm assuming the only workaround is if they include a strong enough lower end in the samples of small, medium, and large brass ensembles because we won't be able to compensate for it on the back end without being able to transpose as much as needed.Does anyone have any ideas or other workarounds?  Man, if they get this right for my purposes I'll be able to go with just my Stage to many, if not most of my gigs...Thanks in advance,GRod

title: RE: Lady Gaga synth tone
post_content: alancondie wrote:.... Any help you can give me would be so much appreciated.Many thanksAlanHi Alan,While I can't send you a synth patch "my NSEx isn't compatible with your NS2".I can give you some tips on how to create the sound.Possibly one of our great NS2 owners could even do it and share the patch.I took a square wave multi 5.0, 50% duty cycle, no filter modulation, filter resonance "emphasis for you Minimoog fans" all the way off, filter cutoff around 12KHz, amp envelop sharp attack, max sustain, medium release, no velocity modulation.Overall patch should be monophonic like a lead synth. The portamento, or glide should be very low as to be imperceptible.The mashed up element to the sonic character "for my version" was created by ring modulation in the effects section, but in the original, I feel it was the oscillators and filter being slightly modulated by a noise waveform.My gut instinct says the original sound is a Moog Voyager.This sound demo was done with my NSEx.While this is FAR from spot on, it tends to get the point across.I'm confident that another member could take this to the next level.JUST_DANCE_SOUND4.mp3I hope this helps.Cheers, Hanon

title: Minimoog-like synth lead?
post_content: Hi!I've been looking for a synth lead that sounds like this -http://www.box.net/shared/2sx5gnoauz- but the world of synthesizers is brand new to me, and I keep getting lost in all the buttons. Is it possible to make a lead sound like this on the NS2?Thanks,Andreas

title: RE: Minimoog-like synth lead?
post_content: Hello Andreas,Welcome!I only have the previous model "Nord Stage Ex" the patches aren't compatible with the NS2.I think I can get you started twisting the right knobs for this Lead sound.Start with a SAW wave "between TRI and SQUARE, to left of FM"Set the voice mode to "MONO" and Glide knob to about 2 (these are important to lead-type sounds)Remove any Detune from the oscillators.Set the Filter for LP24 and KB-TrackSet the Filter Frequency at 932HZSet the Resonance to 8 (this, combined with the Gide, gives it that distinctive plaintive vocal character)Set the Amp attack to 8ms, Amp Decay at Max, Amp Release at Min.No Filter modulation. Except for Frequency control by Mod Wheel via Morph.This is how mine ended up sounding:Minimoog_NSEx_Lead.mp3Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Yamaha P200 pianosound/pacthes
post_content: jakob1979 wrote:Hello.Does anyone know if I can get a "Yamaha P200" piano sound, to the Clavia Nord stage 2 ?sincerely,JakobHi Jakob,Welcome to the forum!The short answer is "yes you can".The more involved answer is, if you carefully sample the P200 and use the Nord Sample Editor "NSE" software,you can create a sample that be used be either your NS2, or NE3 instruments.The downside is, that the resulting sample will only be a single velocity layer and the sample resolution may be a little less than original.In other words, it'll never sound quite the same.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Shine on you crazy diamond
post_content: Don't know if it helps, but this is my "Shine On"-Intro-Live-Setup (unfortunately not only NS2 sounds needed, but a Korg 01RW, a Korg M3 and a Minimoog Voyager connected via Midi):Basis:Korg 01W Program A27 Analog Pad (the one and only Pad out thereNS2 Synth1: Solina ViolinsKorg M3: French Cathedral Church OrganAditional SoundsNS2 Synth2: Solina Strings +3Oktaves restricted to the left side of the Keyboard (by pressing one Bassnote you get one very high note -> better than having the whole chord up very high)NS2 Organ 1: some mid registers with Leslie (sounds gets more movement through this)Korg M3: MelotronVibraphoneMinimoog: Effectsounds and later Solo or alternative Doubling the Basenotes with a Taurus-like soundwhen I'm back from my current tour I anyway planned to sample this - but my take a few weeks from now.
